title: Learning Logical Forms
description:
One of the holy grails in computational linguistics is to achieve
both the detailed levels of analyses that are only possible with
hand-crafted grammars that support the construction of logical forms,
while improving the robustness, and in particular, the coverage of such
grammars.
This project will address this goal by using supervised learning to
acquire a mapping from natural language strings to their logical forms.
 


We intend to use the Redwoods treebank for this purpose (Oepen et al,
2002). This is a treebank containing sentences from scheduling
dialogues, e-commerce emails, and tourism texts. Each utterance is
annotated with all its possible linguistic analyses, as predicted by the
 English Resource Grammar (ERG, Flickinger, 2000), as well as a
hand-picked preferred analysis. The syntactic analysis is based on HPSG,
 and there are several semantic representations that this HPSG supports, all of which are notational variants of each other.  Specifically, these include MRS (Copestake et al, 1999), DMRS (Copestake, 2009) and Semantic Dependencies (SDPs, See SEMEVAL 2015, task 18).

The model we
use to estimate logical forms from NL strings will not use features from
 the HPSG analysis, as we want the model to handle NL strings that
receive no parse in the ERG.  Instead, you will adapt an existing model for learning mappings from NL strings to one of these semantic representations, using an existing model of your choice.  For instance, you could use the model of (Kwiatkowski, 2012), which has already been tested on much smaller corpora (e.g., the Geoquery corpus) to learn the MRS notations.  This model has already been used to learn logical forms look slightly different (e.g., they don't underspecify semantic scope). 
 

Kwiatkowski's model exploits the transparent
syntax/semantics interface of CCG to learn string to logical form
mappings. In essence, the task of deriving a logical form for a
sentence boils down to the task of supertagging. But so far, this model
 has been tested on very simple linguistic phenomena on small corpora
(Geoquery and ATIS). These corpora don't contain several kinds of long
distance dependencies that appear with relative frequency in Redwoods.
And although Geoquery contains a small number of sentences that feature
control, the logical forms that are assigned to them abstract away from
this. So this project will test whether Kwiatkowski's model can scale to more complex NL phenomena.

Adaptation
 of the model to the Redwoods treebank involves writing a CCG lexicon
that supports underspecifying quantifier scope, in contrast to the model
used for Geoquery and ATIS, where the target logical forms fully specify
 semantic scope.


To evaluate the system we will use a combination of (a) an unseen
portion of the Redwoods corpus (i.e., a set of strings which is covered
by the ERG), and perhaps also (b) a set of NL examples which aren't covered by the
ERG (e.g., I man came in who I met), for which we
semi-automatically constrruct and MRS for representing its meaning. We
can use existing evaluation metrics for comparing RMRSs to MRSs for
assessing the quality of the results of our model on this test corpus.
goal: To implement and test an existing model of semantic parsing on the Redwoods corpus
completion_criteria: The student should deliver the following: (i) the design of a model for learning logical forms; (ii) an implementation of this model; (iii) evaluation of the model against held-out test data from the Redwoods corpus.

title: Automated Test Case Generation for OpenCL programs
description: The project will require students to automatically generate test cases such that the the test cases achieve code coverage or input partition coverage over OpenCL programs. The LLVM framework is a good starting point to parse OpenCL. Open source OpenCL benchmarks such as parboil will be used for evaluation.
goal: To automatically generate test cases for OpenCL programs  (open source benchmarks) that is adequate with respect to code coverage or input partitions
completion_criteria: Automated test case generation for 10 OpenCL benchmarks showing coverage achieved.

title: Modelling Biological Systems as Communicating Processes
description:
The Continuous pi-Calculus (c-pi) is a process algebra for modelling behaviour and variation in biochemical systems. Essentially, it is a programming language to describe interacting processes from molecular biology. Key features are its expressive succinctness; a dynamic communication topology between process elements; and a mathematical semantics in ordinary differential equations (ODEs).

There is an accompanying Logic of Behaviour in Context (LBC) which expresses possible properties of these processes as they react over time. Once a biological system has a description in c-pi, it is possible to automatically check whether or not it exhibits those properties: applying the technique of model-checking from hardware and software verification to investigate biochemistry.

This language and its logic are the subject of current research in Edinburgh, with examples from systems biology and tools for simulation and analysis. There are multiple undergraduate and MSc students currently working on c-pi projects, and this project builds on those.

The goal of this project is to design and build continuous pi models for a range of biochemical systems, exploring the possibilities and limitations of the calculus. There is a small catalogue of existing models at https://cpi-catalog.000webhostapp.com/index.php : as well as adding to these, you might want to enhance its online presentation. This will help guide the further development of continuous pi, and you will have the opportunity to be involved in this ongoing research project.

Potential modelling domains include: inter- and intracellular signalling; regulatory cascades; metabolic pathways; and the endocrine system. Finding suitable examples will involve surveying existing process algebra models of biological systems, as well as searching repositories of biochemical reactions for new systems for which the continuous pi-calculus may be particularly suited. Large international repositories like BioModels are a natural place to start, as they are easily accessible on the web and hold descriptions for tens of thousands of models of biological systems. The project is open-ended, and will require a fair amount of self-directed research in the literature and online databases.
goal: Build a suite of computational models of biochemical systems in the Continuous pi-Calculus, a programming language for biomolecular modelling.
completion_criteria: Two or more descriptions of biological processes expressed in continuous pi, with tables and graphs of their behaviour obtained using the existing simulation tools.

title: Computational modelling of multi-state biomolecules involved in memory
description:
This project would be jointly supervised with Melanie Stefan in the Centre for Integrative Physiology, and would be an excellent introduction to applying new techniques of biological modelling to a complex biological system.

When we learn, synapses in our brain get stronger. This strengthening is mediated by Calcium influx into the neuron at the receiving end of the synapse and the subsequent activation of a protein called Calcium/calmodulin-dependent kinase II (CaMKII). CaMKII regulates a number of postsynaptic proteins, ultimately leading to a change in the molecular composition of the synapse and the cellular microstructure around it (Lisman & al., 2002). The regulation of CaMKII itself is fascinating: It is activated by another protein called Calmodulin (if Calmodulin is bound to Calcium), but it can also activate other instances of itself (by adding a phosphate group at a particular site) and thereby become Calmodulin-independent. This auto-activation is dependent on the structure of CaMKII, where six subunits form a ring, and each subunit in the ring can activate its neighbour. In addition, a CaMKII subunit can modify itself (by adding a phosphate group to another site) and thereby become inaccessible to calmodulin.

While we know a lot about the individual biochemical steps involved, a lot of questions remain to be answered: In particular, how do regulation and autoregulation events work together to regulate the overall function of an individual CaMKII molecule, or even a population of CaMKII molecules? This is an area where computational modelling can provide useful insights.

CaMKII is an example of a "multi-state biomolecule", i.e. a molecule that can exist in a large number of possible, functionally different states. This results from combinatorial combinations of individual events or modifications that can happen (for instance, calmodulin binding and unbinding, phosphorylation at two different sites, conformational change, etc. - all of this for every subunit in a ring of six). Only in recent years have computational modelling techniques for biological applications caught up with this complexity. In particular, the advent of rule-based and particle-based modelling frameworks has made it possible, for the first time, to generate and explore detailed models of complex signalling molecules like CaMKII (Stefan & al., 2014). Insights gained from modelling the 3D structure of CaMKII have been used to inform a model at the rule-based level (Stefan & al. 2012).

In this project, you will use some of those modelling techniques to address an as yet unanswered question about CaMKII: Given the imbalance in concentrations, with CaMKII much more abundant than its activator calmodulin, how can a population of CaMKII molecules ever become activated at all, and does CaMKII autoregulation play a role in this context?
goal: To build a computational model of CaMKII using a rule-based modelling system.
completion_criteria: A model of CaMKII in which there are two phosphorylation sites per subunit implemented in a rule-based language (e.g. Kappa or BNGL). Some results about CaM binding to this model under various conditions.

title: Predicting success of Github software teams from activity logs
description:
Collaborative problem solving by online crowds is a recent phenomenon which is generating interest from multiple perspectives: social science, economics, and computing. Large crowds with no central coordination are able to solve problems ranging from content generation in Wikipedia to open source software development, collaborative mathematics, and to science and research itself. It is important to ask how these online crowds are able to do complex work, how they organize themselves into teams, and what factors define team success. This project will focus on team formation and activity, and examine the success of teams of software contributors on Github.

The approach will leverage large scale, detailed activity logs from Github projects, and develop machine learning models which distinguish the stream of activity by successful teams from teams which made an unsuccessful attempt. We will aim to use action events and categories in the log, and also incorporate language processing on the commit messages and/or code trying to further place activities in a semantic context. The project will also identify and examine different definitions of success eg. project popularity or ending in package creation such as R CRAN packages.
goal: A machine learning model which predicts success of a Github project team by observing their activity logs
completion_criteria: - Identify the scope of Github projects to examine (small vs large teams/projects)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            +

- Extraction of properties which summarize activity log patterns                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              +

- Identify one or two success criteria for projects                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           +

- Analysis of how the properties differ in successful and unsuccessful teams                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  +

- A machine learning model which can classify a new activity log into potentially successful and unsuccessful teams. Ideally such a model will aim to identify the potential outcome as early in the project development process as possible.

title: Language identification from speech
description:
We have been developing systems for automatic speech recognition across multiple languages.

When such systems are deployed, it is important to to be able to detect the language of an incoming audio stream since metadata with this information is often not available (or if it is available is frequently incorrect).  The aim of the this project is to use deep neural network approaches to identify the language of spoken recordings.  

The project will use the Globalphone corpus, which contains recordings in 23 languages, and the approaches to be explored will be based on deep neural networks.  In addition to finding architectures that work well for this problem, one interesting question would be to compare language recognition approaches (classify a recording into one of (say) 20 languages), versus language verification - is the presented recording in language X or not.

L Ferrer et al (2016). "Study of senone-based deep neural network approaches for spoken language recognition", IEEE Trans ASLP 24:105-116, https://doi.org/10.1109/TASLP.2015.2496226.

Kaldi - www.kaldi-asr.org

Globalphone - https://www.uni-bremen.de/en/csl/projects/current-projects/global-phone-language-models.html
goal: Development of a system to automatically detect the language of spoken audio
completion_criteria: Build an evaluate a language identification system on globalphone.

title: What’s in a title? Developing a Title Classification Algorithm for Scientific Papers
description:
The Technical Problem:



The goal is to build a sentence classification algorithm for deciding whether a given statement belongs to one of the two classes, as described below. Then, the student is expected to crawl more titles and use their (hopefully accurate) classifier to generate more data.



Background:



Compared to the main body of an academic paper published in a research journal, or even its abstract, the paper’s title has a very small footprint in terms of page space. Nevertheless, as the first thing that a reader encounters, and as the data that is invariably captured in electronic data bases, the title assumes an importance that is only rarely explicitly realised by researchers publishing in these journals. A ‘good’ title enhances the chance that a paper is found and cited. A paper that is never found or cited means that the research it reports will never influence the work of others, and so is, ultimately, wasted. Many successful researchers know this, and therefore spend significant effort crafting the titles of their papers before submitting them to journals. Historians and philosophers of science are also interested in paper titles, precisely because they betray, either consciously or unconsciously, how the authors view their own work and how they perceive the potential communities of readers of their work.



Broadly speaking there are two kinds of paper titles, at least in the experimental sciences: (1) ‘E. coli swims faster in viscous polymer solutions’, or (2) ‘Bacterial swimming in polymer solutions’. The first kind tells us, in a complete grammatical sentence, the basic finding of the paper; the second kind outlines the broad area of investigation, and is not a sentence. Anecdotally, working scientists repeatedly note that titles of the first kind is increasingly displacing titles of the second kind, especially in the life sciences. Preliminary quantitative research using ca. 18000 titles of biology papers from a single journal classified by a human


reader suggest that this ‘displacement’ happens in a rather abrupt transition in the late 1960s.



This project is aimed at devising and using machine learning algorithms to investigate what was (and still is) going on vis-à- vis title choice, starting from the observation outlined above.




Staff:



The main supervisor would be Shay Cohen (http://homepages.inf.ed.ac.uk/scohen) in Informatics, with a collaboration with Wilson Poon from the School of Physics and Astronomy (http://www.ph.ed.ac.uk/~wckp).


​
goal: developing a title classification algorithm
completion_criteria: development of a title classifier and application of it on data the student crawls from other resources

title: Algorithms & Data Structures Visualisation
description:
This project is intended to build on a previous one proposed and carried out by Chimwemwe Kadzuwa and then by Yaohui Shao. The open source software he built is available via the Inf2b page http://www.inf.ed.ac.uk/teaching/courses/inf2b/resources/adsSoftware.html. Here is Chimwemwe's original proposal, slightly edited to reflect changes as the project progressed:  One of the stumbling blocks for novice programmers and early computer scientists when implementing software is a lack of intuition surrounding algorithms and elementary data structures that reside at the core of Computer Science. Every computer scientist should have a firm grasp of algorithms used for searching and sorting. In addition, this should be complemented with a thorough understanding of common data structures such as stacks, queues, graphs and trees. Currently attempts have been made to visualise the processes algorithms undergo to perform common tasks. Unfortunately, these attempts display very low level representations of processes , often leaving users bewildered. Building intuition about an algorithm often firstly requires attaining a high level understanding of its basic operation. Design and implement an application that will teach users about algorithms and data structures. It should display visual representations of algorithmic processes in an intuitive manner. The application should allow the user to construct inputs which can be given to algorithms and have the results subsequently displayed.  The app should also teach users about data structures. The application should be highly interactive allowing users to perform common operations on well known data structures. The aim of the project under proposal is to extend the software both to further algorithms and data structures as well as the nature of the information it provides.

The main desirable extension is to make the software available on a server through a web interface, however this would be the hard version of the project.  For the easy/moderate version  auto-scaling of the graphics can be added and some other algorithms.

If this project is undertaken by an MInf student then the first year can focus on the aspects described above and the second year on integrating this software with the software form another project "Algorithms workbench for Inf2B".  At some stage the project would be rated as at least hard.

Please note that it is a precondition of this project that all the code is open source and the result is placed on a public repository such as GitHub.
goal: Extend existing software (in Java) to help students inunderstandinbg algorithms.
completion_criteria: For the hard version, successful deplyment on a virtual server.  For the easy version the addtion of extra functionality such as described above.

title: Database Support for Minority Language Policy Research
description:
This is a continuation of a previous MSc project, the software for which is available at https://github.com/araishikeiwai/seeker; this is built using the Ruby on Rails web framework.   The original project proposal was as follows:

The EU requires member states to produce reports on their minority languages (roughly every three years). A committee of experts then produces an evaluation report and this is followed by a recommendation from the committee of ministers; see http://www.coe.int/t/dg4/education/minlang/Report (the reports are all in English).

The documents all follow a set format (for each type) and are mostly in pdf. However there are by now many of them so that a researcher in minority languages who wishes to extract comparative information is faced with a very lengthy task since the data is spread in the text. The documents are of varying sizes but not enormous; a sample varies from 57KB to 2.1MB. Example questions are: (i) Show all Committee of Experts recommendations under article 7b. (ii) Show all sections relating to Scottish Gaelic.

This project has two aims:

1. To carry out research and recommendations on appropriate tools. The most likely solution will be either to adopt a relational database approach or a weblog infrastructure (part relational, rest free form), a possible combination is MongoDB and Node.js

A background consideration is that any solution should be adaptable to other scenarios. A particular future one is concerned with the Gaelic Plans that are required to be produced by various bodies in Scotland. These are not in any fixed format but some abstract structure common amongst them and the EU documents will be considered if time allows. (This feature makes the project particularly suitable for MInf students.)

2. To implement enough functionality identified in (1) as a proof of concept. Ideally documents in word and html format should be handled but for this pilot study it is acceptable to restrict to pdf format (ensuring that the extra functionality can be added at a later time).

Both phases will involve some consulting (arranged via the project supervisor) with Prof Rob Dunbar or Prof Wilson MacLeod from Celtic and Scottish Studies who will provide more detailed user requirements.

It is a condition of this project that all software used is public domain and that any new software will also be declared as public domain, the software must be placed on a publicly accessible repository such as github. The main components will be a server (provided as a virtual machine) with web based methods for queries, providing both administrator and user roles. The software must be fully documented, including any functionality that is either missing or is not optimal due to time constraints. This is very important as it is intended to build on the results with a follow up project and a migration to other infrastructure, thus the project would have a future use.

All students interested in this project must contact the proposer for a discussion. Please note that no knowledge of minority languages is required.

The existing software achieved the main aims of importing and searching pdf documents but requires improvement in terms of functionality, this will be a principal aim of this iteration of the project.  The first task will be to ensure deployment of the existing software on an Informatics virtual sever.  If time permits the scope can be extended to incorporating Gaelic plans that are a requirement from public bodies within Scotland, knowledge of Gaelic is not required for this.

Please note that it is a precondition of this project that all the code is open source and the result is placed on a public repository such as GitHub.
goal: Design and implement a database and tools for searching a body of documents.
completion_criteria: A significant addition to the existing software and full deployment on an Informatics virtual server.

title: Topics in multi-agent learning
description:
A second group meeting for this project will take place on Wednesday 4 April at 2pm in room 2.06, Informatics Forum.

Note to interested students: There will be a group meeting for this project during which interested students can ask questions. The meeting will take place on Thursday 15 March at 10am in room 2.06, Informatics Forum.

Multi-agent learning is concerned with the design and analysis of algorithms which enable autonomous agents to learn how to interact with one another. This includes a team of agents which must learn to collaborate in order to complete a given task, as well as agents which are in competition and must learn to solve tasks in the presence of adversaries. Reinforcement learning has emerged as one of the principal methodologies used in multi-agent learning. Other useful paradigms include evolutionary approaches and techniques for opponent modelling. A recent tutorial by Albrecht and Stone provides an overview of existing algorithms (http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~larg/ijcai17_tutorial).

I am interested in supervising projects addressing problems in multi-agent learning, including algorithms for efficient multi-agent reinforcement learning and communication, as well as theoretical and empirical analyses of multi-agent learning processes. Difficulties range from 'Easy' to 'Hard', depending on project.

An abstract template for a project in this category looks as follows:

  1. Specify an environment (i.e. state space, possible actions, state transition dynamics, observability conditions)
  2. Specify a task to be completed by the agents (e.g. reaching a goal state, optimising a utility function, converging to some equilibrium point); the task should be such that solving it requires non-trivial interaction between the agents
  3. Specify the learning algorithms used by the agents to solve the problem; justify your choice
  4. Implement and evaluate the system; describe when the algorithms succeed or fail to solve the problem

    The 'Easy' instantiation of this template would be to test simple multi-agent learning algorithms in simple two-player repeated games (see tutorial). A more challenging instantiation would define a complex domain and task (such as domains inspired by realistic applications) and test more advanced multi-agent learning algorithms.
goal: To specify, implement, and evaluate a multi-agent learning system.
completion_criteria: At a minimum:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +

- Specify an environment                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      +

- Specify a task to be completed by the agents                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                +

- Specify the learning algorithms to solve the problem                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        +
- Implement and evaluate the system; describe when the algorithms succeed or fail to solve the problem

title: Better ski maps via domain-specific modelling: concrete syntax, design and automated layout
description:
Ski resorts have multiple pistes, which skiers access using lifts. Traditional ski maps - see [1] for example - are topographical. They can be confusing to interpret, especially under stress or in poor conditions; for example, it can be difficult to answer questions like:

Q1) Can I reach this lift from that piste, or are they just geographically close? (This is particularly hard when the map is at small scale, which it typically is for large ski domains.)

Q2) In which direction does this piste run? (This is particularly a problem for short piste sections where neither end is a lift; sometimes this is disambiguated with arrows, but putting arrows on every piste is impractical in the traditional setting.)

Q3) How can I get from A to B satisfying a constraint such as "nothing harder than a blue run"?

For skiers who wish to stick to pistes, most of the topographical information is irrelevant, so we may contemplate better ways to display and exploit the relevant information. An obvious inspiration is the London Tube map, and this connection has been made in an artistic context (see reference [2]). It would be desirable to be able to use the same basic information about a ski resort to produce both types of map, and to use it in different ways. Therefore this project will start by defining a simple domain-specific modelling language (DSML) for ski resorts, in which the model elements are lifts, pistes etc. This part will be done in cooperation with any student(s) taking the related projects (with the obviously similar names): the DSML will serve as the interface between the software developed in the different projects.


The focus of this project is to develop a usable concrete syntax for the DSML, along with an automated layout algorithm. That is, design a representation of the modelled information so that, given a model in the DSML (a collection of model elements describing  all the lifts, pistes etc. for a particular resort, along with  appropriate information for each), a non-topographic map can be generated that allows a skier to answer Q1-Q3 more reliably.



I would want the software produced in this project to be engineered carefully, well tested and documented and released under an open source licence, in order that it can be built on at a later date.
goal: Develop a domain-specific modelling language to describe the pistes and lifts in a ski domain, and use this as a basis for generating clear, non-topographic maps
completion_criteria: A domain-specific modelling language to describe the pistes and lifts in a ski domain has been developed, and from a model in this language, of the complexity of a medium-sized ski resort, clear, non-topographic maps of carefully considered design can be generated.

title: Designing and Developing a Technology-Based Tool to Help Children with Autism Cope with Changes
description:
One of the core characteristics of children with autism is “insistence of sameness” or “restricted and repetitive behaviours and interests” [1]. For example, some individuals with autism may have rigid preferences for food (e.g. eating only specific items) or everyday objects (e.g. using a particular type of shampoo). Routines around daily activities may become real rituals, followed in tiny detail. Consequently, sometimes minor changes such as moving from one activity to another or a slight change in daily routine can cause distress [2,3]. Other changes, such as going on holiday, moving house or changing school may be extremely challenging.

The goal of this project is to design and implement a technology-based tool to support children with autism overcome difficulties when changes occur. The tool is not expected to address all kinds of changes, but rather to focus on a specific category of changes. The student is expected to design the tool based on a review of relevant literature and on consultation with people with experience in working with children with autism (e.g. researchers, practitioners and/or parents). The completion of the project also involves implementing and evaluating the tool.

A possible approach for this project may be:

  1. Understand the domain and problem by reviewing relevant literature
  2. Extend the understanding of the domain and problem by consulting with people with experience in working with children with autism (e.g. through interviews, focus groups, questionnaires)
  3. Derive a set of requirements for the tool based both on the literature and data collected from people
  4. Develop a paper or low fidelity prototype
  5. Conduct formative evaluation with potential users. The formative evaluation may include practitioners, parents, and/or children with autism or, in their absence, typically developing children (TD)
  6. Revise the paper prototype
  7. Time permitting, redo steps 4-5.
  8. Develop a working prototype
  9. Design and conduct summative evaluation. This evaluation may include experts in autism (e.g. researchers, practitioners and/or parents) and/or typically developing children

The difficulty of the project is variable, depending on the approach taken. If interested, please fill in this Google Form. We will assess your replies and, if you are suitable, we will contact you for a quick chat.

Note*: User studies may require Ethical Approval.
goal: To design, develop and evaluate an educational technology based tool for children with autism
completion_criteria: A high-fidelity prototype for a technology-based tool that helps children with autism cope with changes                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       +
Evidence-based evaluation of the prototype

title: The complexity of interlacing polynomials
description: Interlacing polynomials is an important combinatorial technique to show the existence of certain objects. It was introduced by Marcus, Spielman, and Srivastava in 2013 and is used to solve a number of important open problems. However, there is no efficient algorithm known to find these objects, once shown to exist. This project is to investigate the computational complexity of this question.
goal: To understand the computational complexity of interlacing polynomials
completion_criteria: Formulate the algorithmic version of interlacing polynomials and investigate its complexity.

title: Mandelbrot Maps: Web application for exploring fractals
description:
The Mandelbrot curve is a dense, interesting shape. Zoom in on any portion of it, and you see a different dense, interesting shape; or sometimes a tiny almost-duplicate of the original shape, nested inside the original. This process can be continued forever.The Mandelbrot curve indexes the Julia curves. Each point on the complex plane used to display the Mandelbrot curve generates a corresponding Julia curve. Astonishingly, the Julia curve for a given point usually resembles the appearance of the Mandelbrot curve near that point.Mandelbrot Maps, written in 2008 by MSc student Iain Parris and updated in 2009--2012 by MSc and UG4 students Sky Welch, Hannah Taub, Alasdair Corbett, Edward Mallia, Taige Liu, Charlie Wu and is a web application that lets one explore such shapes (and beats any similar application on the web or in the Play store). The most recent version is

Fractal Maps

available for Android from Google Play.This project is to improve the existing application. Possible areas of improvement include:

  • Improved presentation of Tan's theorem (see below).
  • Improve the Android implementation, or reimplement for iPhone. See how high a rating you can get in the Android or Apple store.
  • Make educational videos using the current system. See how many hits you can get on You Tube.
  • More robust web engineering.
  • Port it to display on Microsoft Surface, Puffersphere, or other unique device.
  • Exploit GPUs to make it run faster.
  • Exploit multi-core architecture to make it run faster.
  • Exploit multiple computers over the web to make it run faster.
  • Port from Java to Flash or Javascript, or exploit other web technologies.The application should be suitable for use in public engagement, such as the Science Festival, or student recruiting.

The system can be improved to better illustrate Tan's theorem relating Mandelbrot and Julia curves, which states that the Mandelbrot curve and the corresponding Julia curve at the same point look almost identical when suitably magnified and rotated; this requires an improved user interface that supports the necessary magnification and rotation.The project involves opportunities to develop skills at mobile computing, touch interfaces, web programming, GPU programming, multicore programming, and distributed programming, all of which will be increasingly important in the future.
goal: Improve the existing Mandelbrot Maps application for exploring Mandelbrot and Julia curves, available through Google Play for Android.
completion_criteria: An implementation of Mandelbrot Maps incorporating Tan's theorem or one of the other improvements described above.

title: Interaction Capture in Virtual Reality Environments
description:
Machine learning techniques that can make use of a large set of motion capture are recently
becoming powerful tools for synthesizing realistic human movements in virtual
environments. For example, the phase-functioned neural network (PFNN) [1], can produce
realstic interactions between the body and terrains or urban environments on-the-fly that
follows the user instructions given by game-pads. The PFNN architecture provides a fast,
compact and stable framework for interactively controlling characters. However, neural
networks are good at interpolating but not at extrapolating, and especially can not reproduce
actions that have not been learned. Thus, collecting a wide variation of motion capture data
becomes the key issue when applying such a technique for arbitrary scenes.
When applying such a technique to indoor scenes where the character needs to sit on chairs,
pass through narrow corridors and open the door, and avoid obstacles and other people in
the room, the data capture process becomes the bottleneck. In particular, we face the
following three major challenges: First, the body markers might become invisible for the
cameras if they are occluded by objects, so having complex environments seems to be
infeasible. Second, some objects also are not always available due to the bulky sizes or
might be quite costly. Third, the way we naturally move and interact is implicitly influenced
by the ambience of the environment in which we are. Therefore, it often becomes
cumbersome to set up proper environments inside the capture area in order to record motion
data for different scenarios.

In this research, we propose a new method which eases and improves the process of motion
capture by transforming these tasks to be performed in virtual reality rather than purely in
the real world. The above mentioned issues can be overcome by using virtual reality in
many situations. By only rendering virtual obstacles and virtual humans in the virtual
world, we can capture realistic interactions between the human and objects and other
humans without suffering from occlusions. The ambience of the environment can be easily
switched by adjusting the textures and lighting conditions as well as the background objects.
The motion capture setup for our proposed research is visualised in Fig. 1. The user operates
in the real world while having the body markers attached to its body and wearing the HTC
Vive headset (right image). The skeleton is then transformed from the real scene into a
virtual scene using motion capture (left bottom image). For constructing the virtual scenes,
we use the Unity3D graphics engine [2] which easily allows designing complex, detailed
and high-resolution environments. In addition, a large collection of environments, furnitures
and items for interaction can be obtained from the Unity3D Asset Store. The motion capture
will be done by combining the VICON optical system and the Perception Neuron MoCap
system [3], which also provides a ready-to-use plugin as integration for Unity3D. This is
assumed to make the software development process very convenient. Inside the virtual
scene, a camera is attached to the head joint of the character skeleton, which is then used to
generate the view for the user in virtual reality (left top image). This view is finally returned
to the HTC Vive headset of the operator in the real world, so it becomes possible to
interactively navigate and perform actions inside the virtual world.
The main advantages of this method are that arbitrary environments and ambient settings
can be constructed quite easily, different objects for interaction can be directly used, and

multi-sensory visual and auditory data can be recorded simultaneously while capturing the
joint movements. Thus, the linking between user actions and the environment does not need
to be fitted after the raw motion was captured, but can be recorded at the same time.
In order to capture physical interactions that involve contacts, we will make use of props
where the virtual objects will be aligned to. In addition, 3D printing can be used to generate
some real-world objects of virtual models for easing interaction tasks.

The data collected data will be used to train a novel neural network architecture that can
handle not only cyclic but also for rather acyclic movements. In summary, the results of this
research can be used as a flexible method for capturing and creating procedural animations
for collision-aware in-door and out-door movement with virtual characters, object
manipulation and scene interaction in complex environments.
We will also do data augmentation by making use of fast inverse kinematics techniques developed by a member
in our group [4], by adapting the motion to objects with different geometry or characters
with different proportion.
goal: Collect human motion data in a virtual environment and apply it for constructing a model of a virtual human that walks and interacts with the environment.
completion_criteria: Collecting data and developing a human model that can interact with the environment.

title: Learning Software Models to Predict Malicious Behaviours
description:
Applications sometimes contain malicious code and it is a continuing challenge to detect bad applications before they are admitted to app stores like the Google Play Store or Apple's App Store.  Present tools for anomaly detection work using a mixture of methods, running apps in sandboxes to see if they do something suspicious, or examining sequences of instructions to look for errant behaviour.  Sandboxes can be defeated by apps which don't predictably behave badly or make a delay before doing so, and code inspection is fooled when new sequences of instructions are used.

The idea of this project is to build a new static detection mechanism which uses a combination of structured models which characterise behaviour more abstractly, constructed from inspecting code or from using execution traces.  The intuition is that the notion of bad behaviour doesn't evolve as quickly as the form in which that behaviour is expressed: one piece of ransomware does pretty much the same as the next, although the way it is coded can look superficially very different.   Structured models that may be considered include include Markov chains and finite state automata; in recent research we have been comparing these with recurrent neural networks.

The coding tools and languages used are less important than the methods.  Most existing tool and libraries are provided in Python.  A range of datasets and pre-existing tools will be provided.  One new dataset we may examine in this project is the "SHERLOCK" data described in the paper by Mirsky et al.

Before expressing interest in this project, you should look at the two key reference papers and see if you can follow them, or believe you could gain a strong understanding given a minimal amount of further study. 

An exact problem to tackle will be refined in the early stages of the project, depending on facilities available and the student's background.  This is why the difficulty rating is "Variable".  The underlying data analysis tasks may not ultimately be too difficult, but understanding the context deeply, designing and planning the experiments and plugging together the right tooling will be challenging.


PLEASE EXPRESS INTEREST EARLY TO JOIN A GROUP MEETING TO DISCUSS THE PROJECT.
goal: Using a combination of machine learning and formal models, build a classifier to decide if an Android application (or run of an application) is malicious
completion_criteria: Constructing a classifer using the suggested techniques which achieves good results on test data (what "good" means depends on the context, the evaluation for the project will need to make a case for this).

title: Android front end for benchmarks supporting parallel programming models
description:
Over recent years GPUs have been recognised as powerful parallel computing engines not only for graphic processing but also for general purpose computing. This trend brought forth a range of parallel programming models such as OpenCL or CUDA which allow programmers to develop code independent of the execution device. An OpenCL program for example can be executed on CPU or GPU without changing the source code.

With increasing popularity and compute power of embedded devices such as smartphones, the demand for using parallel programming models in an embedded environment grew. Many recent studies evaluate how various embedded platforms handle OpenCL programs in terms of performance and energy efficiency[3,4]. To support this demand, a standard suite of benchmarks for embedded devices with the capabilities of using parallel programming models would be of great benefit. 

The goal of this project is to take a well known and widely used benchmark suite which already supports parallel programming models and port it to an embedded Android device. For that purpose, existing benchmarks need to be cross-compiled for the ARM architecture and an Android application must be written to be used as an execution front-end. Once this step is completed, various optimisation strategies can be applied to improve energy consumption and performance of the OpenCL code on the given mobile platform, e.g. thread divergence, single vs. double precision, loop unrolling, tweaking the features of the OpenCL wrapper program, etc.

Examples of benchmark suites considered for this project are Parboil[1] and Rodinia[2]. Multiple students can work on this project while each is focusing on a different benchmark suite.

​NOTE: The project is marked as moderate since the OpenCL optimisation is not as straight forward as implementing the app. However, the app alone will likely only get you enough marks to pass this project. The optimisation is your chance to score higher marks.


GROUP MEETING: There will be a group meeting setup to discuss your suitability for this project. Please study the provided references to know what to expect.

The group meeting will be on Tuesday the 3rd of April 3pm - 4pm in AT 3.07.

If you could be so kind as to fill in this short form regarding your skill set. It will give us a head start for the meeting:

https://goo.gl/forms/nBt1M57P7QJrXPeH3
goal: Implement an Android front end for a benchmark suite supporting parallel programming models such as OpenCL
completion_criteria: Implement an Android application which serves as a front end to executing Parboil or Rodinia benchmarks.

title: Model Checking 1-Counter Machines
description: 1-counter machines are like finite automata, but with an extra unbounded counter containing a natural number. This counter can be incremented, decremented and tested for zero. Properties of such machines can be specified in temporal logics (in this case the very simple logic called EF). Example: The property `It is possible to reach some state from which the computation can never stop' can be expressed as EF(not EF(stop)). We have developed a new and more efficient algorithm for checking properties of 1-counter machines.The task of this project is to implement the new algorithm and to test it.
goal: Analyze the performance and the limitations of an algorithm for EF model checking of 1-counter machines.
completion_criteria: - A prototype implementation of the model checking algorithm.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +
- Evaluation on several case studies.

title: Learning about human hand motion
description: The objective of this project is to train a network in a neural network such that it can reproduce realistic 3D finger motions, given some control signal.  For the training data, the Polhemus Liberty magnetic motion capture system will be used.  The finger movements will be collected and either a convolutional network, a recurrent network or a network that combines the two will be trained.   The motion of grasping and moving objects will also be collected as the control signal. Once the network is trained, regression between the control signal and the hidden units of the hand model will be generated such that the complex hand motion can be reproduced only from simple control signals.  The system can be applied for VR systems and computer games.
goal: Produce a supervised/unsupervised framework for hand motion and manipulation
completion_criteria: - Generate a database of hand motion                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          +
- Create a neural network using the captured data.

title: Evaluation and comparison of static software verification tools
description:
The standard approach to verifying that software has been implemented correctly is to run a series of tests and check that the observed behaviour is as expected.    In virtually all cases it is impractical to exhaustively test software for all possible inputs, so testing usually cannot guarantee that software is bug free and does exactly what it should.   In contrast, static software verification tools analyse the logical structure of programs and provide mathematical guarantees that programs have certain desired properties and/or fully meet their specifications.   Traditionally static verification techniques have been difficult and expensive, and their use has mostly been justified only for applications that are safety or security critical.  In recent years there has been much improvement in static verification techniques and they are starting to be used more widely. 

This project concerns a class of tools where the user writes logical formulas to describe expected behaviour and the tools use fully automated reasoning engines to check whether programs have the expected behaviours or not.     Some such tools target standard languages such as C [6], Java [5] or the SPARK Ada subset [7].  Others such as Why3 [1] and Dafny [2] work with simpler languages and can be easier to learn and use.  

The basic aim of the project is to explore the ease of use of these tools: the eventual hope of the researchers developing these tools is that virtually any programmer should be able to use such tools.   These tools are not quite there yet and one project goal is identifying ways in which these tools still need to be improved.   The proposed approach is to first work through tutorials on one or two of the tools and then to apply each tool in turn to one or more common case study programs.   The choice of case study programs is open.  For example, they could be algorithms the student has covered in previous courses.   It is not necessary for the chosen case study program(s) to be particularly complicated.  In total they may have no more than a few dozen lines of code. 

The project does not require the student to understand how these tools work: it is fine if they are treated as black boxes.  

If the student has an interest in automated reasoning, the project could optionally explore how the tools work and/or look at how proof assistants such as Isabelle/HOL [3] or Coq [4] can be employed to interactively complete more difficult verification proofs.    If these options are pursued, the difficulty of the project rises from `Easy' to `Moderate', `Hard' or even `Very Hard'. To make the project tractable, very likely it would focus on program verification using a single tool.
goal: To assess the ease of use of current static software verification tools
completion_criteria: The basic goal is to statically verify some case study program using one or two of the tools and to compare and discuss the respective verification efforts.  Further goals include  explaining something about how the tools work and/or completing program verification tasks that requires the use of a proof assistant.

title: OwnHome: Retrofitting Security and Privacy Measures to Smart Home Devices
description:
There is a current fad for Internet-connected consumer home devices --- power sockets, light bulbs, toys, fridges, kettles, toothbrushes, security cameras, and so on --- which are at the moment a bit novel, but have emerging longer term benefits for the future once they become more reliable, interoperable, usable and trustworthy.  At the moment none of these aspects are addressed well, and security and privacy are a particular failure point.  Devices are sometimes remotely exploitable.  They routinely share invasive details about our personal behaviour with connected cloud services, sometimes beyond what is reasonable even for crowd-sourced functionality provided.  (Many examples have been covered in the media, Dhanjani's book referenced below is a good overview.)

The idea of this project is to build a protective infrastructure around a small selection of smart gadgets, to "retrofit" security and privacy measures and implement independent control mechanisms. 

  • Security, in the sense of limiting or preventing remote control, might be provided by firewall techniques, ranging from simplistic packet filtering (blocking all access) to application-level firewalls which use packet inspection and understand particular device protocols (to insert  additional controls, or work around protocol bugs).
  • Privacy, in the sense of preventing or limiting data sharing, can be provided again with firewalling methods, or by more sophisticated privacy-enhancing techniques which try to obfuscate, mix, or add noise to shared data.
  • Idependent control mechanisms: many devices are provided with dedicated web and smartphone clients which run on the local (home) network both to initiate Internet connection but also to access the devices afterwards.  The APIs and control protocols are sometimes open but in other cases may need to be reverse-engineered to discover how interaction works and to gain access to deivces independently of the vendor supplied path.  Depending on the sophistication of the protocols and cryptography implemented, an independent control may not be possible, or may require spoofing methods to emulate a cloud server endpoint.

Although the methods are general, the exact techniques will depend on the collection of devices chosen and how they operate.  The project can build on previous investigations (conducted in student projects here and work elsewhere) into penetration testing and other security and privacy investigations.  References and pointers will be provided.

As a "stretch goal", it would be useful to retain Internet-enabled and centralised control of such protected devices,  perhaps by using a small server running on a Raspbery Pi running home automation software (such as Home Assistant or OpenHab).

This project is rated as Variable difficulty.  Implementing very basic security controls (for example, firewalling off certain IP address ranges) would be Easy.  Reverse engineering complex protocols or implementing privacy-enhancing technologies would be much more demanding, tending to Hard/Very Hard, involving both conceptual and engineering effort.

Note:  the investigations and system being constructed here is designed for research purposes to help understand security and privacy requirements and existing devices.  In general, reverse engineering or using a device without allowing data sharing may violate a vendor's Terms and Conditions.  The project should also pay attention to this aspect.


PLEASE EXPRESS INTEREST EARLY TO JOIN A GROUP MEETING TO DISCUSS THE PROJECT.
goal: To build a protective network security infrastructure around a suite of smart home and IoT gadgets to limit external control and manage data sharing
completion_criteria: A protection infrastructure which covers a minimum of 3 types of device, with a clear specification of what it provides compared with directly connecting smart home devices to the Internet and their controlling apps.

title: Rank Aggregation and related problems
description:
We consider a problem which is familar to all program committee members; the problem of taking a collection of individual rankings of papers (one for each member of the committee), and merging these to obtain a global ranking which is as consistent as possible with the individual rankings. In this conference setting, it will usually be the case that each list only contains a subset of items (so is a "partial ranking"), and that each item only appears in a few of the lists. The "Rank Aggregation" problem has been studied in prior papers, mainly for the scenario of web rankings. Various measures have been considered by previous researchers.  I also have an idea of an alternative measure, when the target output is an Accept/Reject partition, not an overall ranking.

Two early references for Rank Aggregation are the papers of Dwork et al listed below. They were motivated by the scenario of web page rankings coming from different search engines, and the problem of combining those to obtain a good overall ranking. They discuss some typical measures used to calculate the quality of a global ranking.
They define the K-distance between a full proposed ranking r on items {i_1, ..., i_n} and a partial ranking q on some subset of those items, as being the number of i, j pairs such that r(i)< r(j) but q(i) > q(j), and write this as K(r,q).

If we have a full global ranking r and a collection of (probably partial) input rankings q_1, ..., q_m, then the Kemeny score SK(r; q_1, ..., q_m) to be the sum of K(r, q_j) over all j. The goal, when presented with a collection of input rankings q_1, ..., q_m, is to compute a full ranking r which will minimise the value of SK(r; q_1, ..., q_m). This is described as the problem of computing the Kemeny optimal ranking, and is known to be NP-hard in two cases: either when (q_1, ..., q_m) consists of 4 or more "full lists", or when it consists of a large number of partial lists. These details are presented in "Rank Aggregation revisited", and experimental results are given in "Rank Aggregation for the Web". There are many follow-up papers, many giving algorithms with approximation guarantees, and we will look at some of those.   

Another problem that could be investigated relates to an alternative measure to judge the quality of a Accept/Reject partition of the papers (with respect to the partial rankings of the reviewers).  This problem is connected to the (NP-hard and "hard to approximate") problem of computing the Minimum directed cut of a given graph, subject to a bound on the size of the cut.  This means the Accept/Reject problem is NP-hard and also "hard to approximate" in the general case, but we might consider restricted subcases and/or an experimental study.

Apart from the papers listed below (and related publications) I also have two sets of notes, one by Bob Fisher, the other by myself, looking at alternative ways to measure the "quality" of a overall ranking (or a partition into Accept/Reject).  These give rise to different approaches. 

Theoretical directions that could be considered might be to study the problem of "3 full lists" to determine whether it is p-time or NP-hard (though I think this is quite a challenge), or to come up with a very simple algorithm and analyse it in the presence of "limited errors", with the hope of proving a "high probability" of it reconstructing the true ranking. Also, given the connection between rank aggregation and the "Minimum-Arc Feedback Set", we could also pursue the open case of that problem (also very difficult).

Experimental directions could involve studying the performance of various heuristic algorithms (possibly Dwork's, more likely mine/Bob's, best if you cover more than one!) on a collection of large randomly-generated committee-member-with-errors examples. 

I have ticked "moderate" for difficulty, but really the project fits somewhere in the range moderate -> very hard, depending on whether you are interested in experimental or theoretical work, and the details of which specific problem you focus on.  Even if you take the experimental route, you will need to do some reading of theoretical papers.

I'm willing to take 1-2 students for  the project. 

If you are interested in taking this project, please read reference [1] or [2] at a minimum, and email me to set up a meeting to discuss your thoughts (after reading the paper).  I'll only  tick students as suitable if I've discussed the projects with them and talked about their algorithms background.
goal: To investigate the feasibility of Rank Aggregation, and/or related problems.
completion_criteria: Either new theoretical results for special cases of the problem, *OR* new experimental results together with a consideration of likely implications wrt the complexity of the problem.

title: Collecting Comparable translations from social media
description:
Many images, videos, and websites get shared on social media platforms such as Twitter and Facebook. Many of these shares would contain a sentence from the user to express what is in the shared link. In many situations, the same link is shared by users who speaks different languages, especially for images and videos. Although the text expressed by the users are usually not identical, but most likely they will be carrying the same meaning.

In this project, we are interested in developing an effective method for following social posts (mainly tweets) that carry the same link with users' comments in different languages. An example of this would be sharing a video of a goal by Messi. One user's comment in language A can be "This is an awesome goal by Messi". Another user in language B can share the same link with comment "Amazing third goal of Barcelona". We hope that this work can lead to identifying many sentences of different that can be comparable in meaning to be used later in applications such as cross-language search, or even machine translation.

Check similar work in [1] which used similar idea but limited to tweets with text in multiple languages.
goal: Collect tens of thousands of sentences of comparable meaning in different languages
completion_criteria: Parallel text of comparable corpora in at least two different languages

title: Lecture Transcription
description:
Many university lectures are now recorded, and lecture subtitling has many benefits including improved access for people with hearing impairments, an improved experience for people for hom English is not their first language, and the potential to search, link, and browse lecture content based on what was said.

This project will build on the speech recognition systems that we have constructed in the Centre for Speech Technology Research (CSTR) for tasks such as transcription of TED talks, multi-genre broadcast recognition, and meeting recognition. These systems are based on deep neural network acoustic models (of various types) and use the Kaldi open source speech recognition toolkit.

This project will be based on a set of 700 Edinburgh MOOC videos (about 50 hours duration) which have human-corrected transcriptions.  This videos cover a diversity of subjects.

During 2017-18, a project pre-processed the MOOC data and built and evaluated initial systems for this task.  This project will further develop the systems, for example by adaptation using domain-specific data, and exploring its adaptation to live lecture recordings. This will involve the exploration of different adaptation approaches, at both the acoustic and linguistic levels.


References:
1. Kaldi open source ASR toolkit.  http://kaldi-asr.org
2.  P Swietojanski et al (2016). Learning Hidden Unit Contributions for Unsupervised Acoustic Model Adaptation, IEEE Trans ASLP, 24:1450-1463.  
3.  P Bell et al (2013). Multi-level adaptive networks in tandem and hybrid ASR system.  IEEE ICASSP.
goal: Develop and evaluate a lecture transcription system for recordings of Edinburgh University lectures, and explore acoustic model or language model adaptation strategies for this data.
completion_criteria: Development and evaluation of a system to transcribe lecture recordings.

title: Feminism discussion on Twitter after the death of Hugh Hefner
description:
Hugh Hefner died in 2017, and his death was highly controversial, since many people have seen him as a symbol for freedom to women, while others seen him as a person who objectified women and made them sold as products.

A collection of 1 million tweets were collected in the following 10 days to his death. In this project, it is required to analyse:

  • Build a stance classifier to detect if a tweet is supporting the guy views or against them (this is different than sentiment analysis)
  • Find the most viral tweets circulated about his death
  • Find the common features among the group of users supporting him compared to those against him
  • Identify feminist accounts and find their stance towards Hefner
  • Extract the main topics discussed around his death.


The outcome would be a full report on the discussions after his death, similar to the work on this paper which analysed the discussions on social media during the US election 2016 [1]
goal: Observe the discussions topics and dynamics related to feminism after the death of Playboy owner Hugh Hefner
completion_criteria: A full report that can be used to write a paper

title: Tool to assist with assessing evidence for academic misconduct.
description:
This is a contiuining project to develop a system that will be available to Informatics staff.  Here is the original proposal:

MOSS is an online system for testing software similarities. The user submits a set of files (code) and the system proceeds to test all pairs for similarities (it is sophisticated and is not fooled by such things as changes of variable names or movement of blocks). In general this is a good way to bring to the user's attention possible collusion/copying. However it is subject to the problem that if each one of n types of similarities are not in themselves that unlikely then for a large class there is a reasonable probability that there will be a pair in which all n similarities appear. Since MOSS only looks at pairs the user of the system does not get to see that the single similarities are in fact not too surprising and so it is difficult to assess the significance of seeing them altogether in one pair of files. Going through the entire set of files manually to examine the evidence is extremely time consuming and usually not realistic.

The major aim of this project is to produce a tool that automates much of the process with the user directing the system at which types of similarities to consider. Ideally the tool should also be able to carry out some form of normalisation of the input code to improve detection. It should be able to work with submitted code files in at least some of the major languages used in the School.  Another significant aim is to assess the strengths and weaknesses of MOSS.

A first version of this project was carried out by an MSc srtudent in 2016-17 and it is hoped tha further development will be carried out by another MSc student during the  current academic year  (2017-18).  The version proposed here will continue from the previous completed one adding further functionality and further testing to ensure a robust system.  The nature of the new functionality will be agreed between the student and the supervisor.

Note that the degree of difficulty depends on the exact nature of the new functionality and can be varied from moderate to very hard to suit the student.

Please note that it is a precondition of this project that all the code is open source and the result is placed on a public repository such as GitHub.
goal: A tool to help in assessing the probabilty of similarities in software submissions and display them.
completion_criteria: A system that extends the previous one by adding siginificant new functionality.
