title: Implementing and comparing quasi-polynomial time algorithm for  solving parity games
description:
Parity games are two-player games on a labeled graph, with important applications in automated verification and model checking.

It has been a long-standing open problem whether these games can be solved in polynomial time.


Very recently, a breakthrough paper by   Calude, Jain, Khoussainov, Li, and Stephan 

("Deciding parity games in quasipolynomial time",   to appear in STOC 2017,

  https://www.cs.auckland.ac.nz/research/groups/CDMTCS/researchreports/

 ) has established the first quasi-polynomial time algorithm for

solving parity games.     Quasi-polynomial time  means running time  2^{O( (log n)^k)) for some fixed constant

k, where n is the encoding size of the input.   This is a substantial improvement over the prior best sub-exponential time

algorithms for parity games.

(There has subsequently been further simplification and improvement in the space complexity of the problem,

 by Jurdzinski and Lazic,  arXiv:1702.05051, 2017.)


The aim of this project is to implement these new quasi-polynomial time algorithms for parity games,

and to compare their performance to prior algorithms  whose worst-case running time is not as good,

but which may nevertheless perform better is practice.

The prior algorithms are already implemented in publicly available software (PGSOLVER, available

on GITHUB.)


An extra special project would attempt to extend the algorithm for parity games to more general

classes of games (such as mean payoff games), but this is likely to be very challenging, and

not a requirement of the project.



In more detail

A parity game is given by a none-labeled directed graph.   The nodes are partitioned into two sets: the set of

nodes belonging to player 1 and nodes

belonging to player 2.    Each node is also labeled by a positive integer, defining the "priority" of that node.


The game starts in a particular node, v_0.   The player to which node v_0 belongs starts, and chooses an immediate neighbor, v_1, such that (v_0,v_1)

is a directed edge of the game graph, and "moves" to v_1.    The game then continues in the same fashion from node v_1, and so forth, for ever.

This forms an infinite sequence of nodes  v_0, v_1, v_2, ......   called  a "play".


Player 1 "wins" the infinite play of the game if  the largest "priority" number that occurs infinitely often during the play is odd.

Player 2 wins if the largest "priority" that occurs infinitely often is even.


These games are "memorylessly determined", meaning that either one player or the other has a deterministic memoryless/positional "winning  strategy" starting at each node.

A memoryless strategy is one which chooses exactly the same "move" out of a given node, irrespective of the history of play up to the point where that node is encountered.


Although the rules of parity games may appear strange at first, these games play a very important role in the theory of model

checking, automata theory, and verification.    The algorithmic problem of determining which

player has a "winning strategy" starting as a given node plays a key role in model checking certain temporal/modal logics (modal  mu-calculus), and

it has been a major open problem whether this problem is solvable in polynomial time.


The recent breakthrough paper(s) on which this project is based provide the first quasi-polynomial time algorithm for this problem.
goal: The main goal of this project is to implement a new
completion_criteria: A working implementation of the new quasi-polynomial time algorithm for solving parity game.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  +

Experimental comparison of the new algorithm with prior algorithms, which have already been                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   +
implemented and are available in publicly available software such as PGSOLVER (available on GITHUB).

title: On-line Forum for InfBASE
description:
InfBASE is a student helpdesk where 1st and 2nd year undergraduate students in the Edinburgh University School of Informatics can get support on core pre-honours courses [1]. The helpdesk is staffed by experienced tutors during the semester and Revision Weeks, every day between 11 am and 3 pm. The tutors have different expertise (i.e. with some of the core pre-honours courses) and provide their availability within the working hours by using the InfBASE website. Whenever they have questions, students need to check the availability of tutors with the needed expertise, and then drop in to ask them their questions.

Since it was first launched, experience with InfBASE has shown that the support provided by tutors is very valued by students. However, InfBASE suffers from some inefficiencies:

  • The tutors’ workload is very variable, with little demand from students at the start of the semester and very high demand before coursework submissions and especially during Revision Weeks;
  • Some of the tutors’ effort is wasted on replying to the same question or discussing the same exercise with different students;
  • Students can work together as a study group and help each other during InfBASE, but this is under-exploited.

To address these issues, but also increase the availability of InfBASE outside the 4 weekday hours, to more students, and potentially extend it for 3rd and 4th year undergraduate students, this project proposes the development of an on-line forum for InfBASE. The forum could include:

  • A question and answer (Q&A) area where students will be able to post questions and get answers from InfBASE tutors, but also other students. Facilities such as tagging, searching, ranking and marking as favourite could also be made available. The forum would require InfBASE tutors to filter out incorrect or offensive student replies.
  • An area where resources (Word/PDF documents but also multimedia and audio/video and links to Lynda.com [2] online courses) could be uploaded by InfBASE tutors and other students.
  • A chat where students could discuss their questions with InfBASE tutors
  • Calendar facilities where students could request to book a face-to-face appointment or an on-line meeting with InfBASE tutors
  • An area where on-line meetings could be set up through integration with the university’s Blackboard Collaborate tool [3]
  • Channels for different years and on different topics

To develop the InfBASE forum, we propose the following steps:

  1. gathering requirements for the InfBASE forum from InfBASE tutors and students

  2. reviewing existing forums used in education (e.g. for a Q&A area, students could explore StackOverflow [4] and AnswerGarden [5])

  3. closely involving tutors and students in the design of the InfBASE forum by using Value-Sensitive Design [6] and Participatory Design [7] methods

  4. developing a prototype of the forum

  5. performing a usability evaluation of the prototype with InfBASE tutors and students.
goal: Design, development and evaluation of an on-line forum for the InfBASE Informatics student support service
completion_criteria: For each student, the following deliverables:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +

- A list of requirements for an InfBASE forum, gathered from InfBASE tutors and students                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      +

- A comparative review of tools used in education for addressing certain chosen functionality found as important during requirements gathering                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                +

- A prototype of the chosen functionality for the on-line InfBASE forum                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       +
- An evaluation of the developed functionality with InfBASE tutors and students in our school

implementation of at least one polynomial time algorithm for \r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               +

deciding polynomial or exponential growth for both NFAs and for\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +

CFGs, and experimentation with these algorithms\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +
to see how they perform on various instances.

title: Compiler Instruction Scheduling Online Tutor
description:
This project is for someone who is deeply interested in compilers. 

Instruction scheduling determines the order of instructions, late in the compiler's backend. There are several algorithms to accomplish this which have different tradeoffs and are suited to different machines. This project will build an online system to show students how instruction selection works. Users will give some example code and will be able to see how different selectors work on that code, with step-by-step animation.

At the end of this project you will understand the details of instruction selection in enormous detail. 


BTW, I have said that this project is suitable for more than one student.  If more than one person wants to do it, they will just take different aspects of compilers each.
goal: To build an online system to help students learn and understand instruction scheduling
completion_criteria: A website demonstrating the use of data flow analysis.

title: MPs voting records and their social media activities
description: The aim of the project is to analyse Twitter data of current MPs and find any correlation between their voting records or political allegiance.
goal: find correlation between voting records and Twitter activity
completion_criteria: Analysis of Twitter data using various NLP techniques (the data has already been downloaded).

title: Topic models and scientific document structure
description: The aim of this project is to analyse topic model representation of various sections of computer science documents available on ArXiv in order to understand 1) the complexity of the documents; 2) which sections of the document are more/less focused on a given topic.
goal: analyse the distribution of topic models in computer science documents available on ArXiv
completion_criteria: provide the analysis of topic distribution in scientific documents

title: Drive Android input replay based on live screen output analysis
description:
Mobile devices are the future of modern embedded computing. Many software and hardware solutions are currently being developed by both industry and research in order to make it faster, better and more energy efficient. One major area that has to be understood in detail for this effort are mobile workloads. What does the system I want to improve actually run? For this purpose interactive mobile benchmarks are needed that can be replayed over and over for various devices and system configurations.

In previous work[1] a methodology is introduced that greatly helps with analysing interactive mobile workloads on Android. This is done by capturing system events and video output of workloads running on an Android device. The collected data is then analysed offline in a second step and evaluated with the goal of improving user experience and energy efficiency of the device by tuning the CPU frequency governor. User input sequences of issued input and corresponding system responses are automatically detected by a video output analysis and provide valuable information on execution performance.

However, the presented tool is rudimentary in the way it is able to execute for different system configurations. The input replay and analysis of resulting screen output are decoupled and executed one after the other. For a more realistic replay scenario, however, a combined version is needed. In the desired version, the replay module would issues an input and while the system processes it, the video output analyser goes over the live video stream and detects when the corresponding system response has happened. It then signals the replay module, that the next input can be send.

This project comes with some challenges concerning the system setup. The replay currently runs from a Linux machine, while the video recording is done on a Windows machine. The device used for the experiment is a Qualcomm Dragonboard and would be provided for the project. Also, if you choose this project you need to be able to work with a code base containing various scripts and programmes written in Java, Python, Bash, PowerShell and C.

GROUP MEETING: There will be a group meeting setup to discuss your suitability for this project. Please study the provided references to know what to expect.

The group meeting will be on Tuesday the 3rd of April 4pm - 5pm in AT 3.07.

If you could be so kind as to fill in this short form regarding your skill set. It will give us a head start for the meeting:

https://goo.gl/forms/nBt1M57P7QJrXPeH3
goal: Merge a system to replay Android inputs with an offline screen output analysis tool, so that they both run in parallel and one drives the other.
completion_criteria: Replay and video analysis modules run in parallel and drive mobile workload execution. The system should be able to handle different CPU frequency settings.

title: understanding the use of explicit negative feedback in information retrieval
description: In exploratory scientific literature search users often have difficulties stating explicitly what type of documents they are looking for, however, they often good at stating what it is that they don't want. The aim of this project is to run a user study comparing two systems for scientific literature search based on ArXiv: one with positive only feedback provided by the users by clicking on a document that they like; and one with both positive and negative feedback where the user can explicitly state that there are certain documents that they are clearly not interested in.
goal: conduct a user study of a system for scientific literature search that contains both positive and negative feedback, and analyse the data
completion_criteria: successful completion of the user study

title: GAN/VAE for generating novel policies/rewards
description:
Generative Neural Networks including GANs and Variational Autoencoder (VAE) are a recently red hot topic in machine learning. Yann LeCun calls them the most important recent idea in machine learning (https://www.quora.com/What-are-some-recent-and-potentially-upcoming-breakthroughs-in-deep-learning). The idea is to use a a pair of deep neural networks to learn a generative model for data (contrast a conventional generative model such as Gaussian Mixtures). 

Commonly GANs are applied on images, with the effect of being able to use the neural net to sample new images within a given category (such as new faces, new images of rooms in your house, etc)

In this project, we will explore the idea of applying GANs on policy models or reward functions.  

Policy: Suppose your simulated robot arm has learned models (trajectories) for how to touch different objects in the room, or how to throw objects at different targets; or your you have trained up a bunch of different AIs that have slightly different strategies for playing games such as tic-tac-toe. Apply a GAN to model this space of models and sample novel policy models. 

What can we do with this? Aside from qualitatively observing the cool new behaviours our robot has come up with, the most exciting potential is to use it as a learnable prior to dramatically accelerate future model learning. This is significant because the sample-inefficiency of policy learning is one of the biggest barriers in deep reinforcement learning today.

Rewards: For reinforcement learning agents tasks correspond to new reward functions. Each new task defined by the user requires the agent to learn to optimise it, which costs time and samples (environmental interactions, causing wear and tear on your robot).  In inverse reinforcement learning agents try to learn the reward function.  Learning a generative model on past learned reward functions allows the agent to propose its own putative reward functions, and learn to optimise them, in advance of being requested to solve it by the user. 

This project is to explore whether building a deep reinforcement learning agent which can make up its own goals, and learn to solve them can eventually learn faster and better than a conventional agent that waits for the user to impose new tasks/reward functions on it.

Done well this project will certainly result in a publication.


Notes: 


1. Recently, ML related projects have a high number of applicants, more than I can feasibly meet individually. Therefore I will arrange a group meeting with everyone who has registered interest on 28th March 2018 in order to discuss the project. For the same reason I will strictly enforce the pre-requisites.
goal: Explore generative neural nets applied to Policy/Reward generation
completion_criteria: 1. Train an RL agent on multiple tasks. 2. Train a GAN/VAE on their policy reward/reward models. 3. Apply GAN/VAE to accelerate new learning.

title: Program splitting to Improve Instruction Locality
description: To achieve the goal, the project will entail splitting the large program into several chunks, such that the chunks fit in the instruction cache. The student will then execute the chunks separately with the test cases (in a particular order given to them for improved instruction re-use) while storing the intermediate results. The project will need to implement a method for automatically identifying places to split the program in chunks and storing the intermediate results. Places of split identified should try to minimize the number of data dependencies between the splits. \r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  +
goal: The goal of the project is to improve execution time of test cases for large programs that do not fit in the instruction cache.
completion_criteria: The student will use 3 to 4 very large programs (> 30K lines of code)  for this evaluation. The implementation should split the large program in chunks and launch test execution on these chunks while storing intermediate results. The student should have compared time gains between executing all the test cases over the program split in chunks versus whole.

description: The student will evaluate if executing test cases over the program in chunks that fit in the cache is faster than executing the whole program with the set of test cases.

title: Design of a dynamically controlled particle swarm algorithm
description:
Metaheuristic algorithms aim at solving optimisation problems by a combination of random and local search, prior knowledge, and the accumulation of partial information acquired during run-time. The algorithms are usually featuring a population of sub-optimal solutions. In Particle Swarm Optimisation (PSO [1])  each of these solutions is represented by a particle in the space of all solutions, and the dynamics of the particles determines the performance of the algorithm. In the project, principles like criticality [2], (an)isotropy and (in)homogeneity are to be controlled and tested in their effect on the behaviour of the algorithm. For this an existing version of the PSO algorithm is to be extended and tested of a number of standard benchmark functions.

If more than one student is assigned to this project, a similar study will be conduction with a different algorithm such as differential evolution (also easy) or ant colony optimisation (harder).
goal: Design, testing and control of a dynamically controlled particle swarm algorithm
completion_criteria: A particle swarm algorithm with the described features is to be implemented and tested in a number of benchmark problems

title: Sentinal : next generation annotating of video data.
description: Many tools already exist for the temporal annotation of events occurring in a video file. Typical examples will support playback of video at various speeds and allow the user to map key strokes to specific event classes than can then be annotated onto a timeline that follows the video. This works for a great many conditions but performs poorly when we also need to capture where in the image (i.e. spatially) an event is occurring.\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      +
goal: Develop an intuitive interface to spatial and temporal annotation of events happening in a video file.
completion_criteria: An implemented system that supports video play back while recording screen/mouse events on a timeline.

description: We want to develop Sentinal to fill this gap. A simplest solution would allow a user to select a behaviour or event and tap onto the screen. More efficient methods would combine some basic tracking elements. This is probably best suited to a touchscreen / tablet app although we are happy to explore options more broadly.\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      +

The Kivy (Python) UX toolkit http://kivy.org/#home may be an ideal start.\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              +
NOTE: This project involves an external company (Actual Analytics Ltd). Anyone interested in the project should discuss it with the supervisors in advance of selection.

title: How informative are retinal ganglion cell responses about visual stimuli?
description:
Individual neurons in the retina respond to light in different ways, for instance, some neurons signal light onsets, others light offsets [e.g. ref 2 and 3]. Here we will ask how much information a population of retinal neurons contains about stimuli.

For this project have data from experimental collaborators where responses of 100s to 1000s of RGCs were recorded under different stimulation conditions. Using methods from information theory [ref 1], in particular mutual information, we will assess information content, and ask what role individual cell types play in the encoding.
goal: To measure how information content in the retinal population response
completion_criteria: Quantification the information about a stimulus in at least one data set recorded from a mouse retina.

title: An interpreter for audited computation
description:
Audited computation refers to software systems that are able to log and subsequently examine information about their computation history: this includes the origin of data, an explanation of the computation that produced it, whether it is confidential or not, etc.
Such information can be used for various purposes: for scientific applications, knowing how experimental data was processed is crucial to improve trust; in security, we can use computation history to develop smart access control policies; for debugging purposes, knowing how wrong results were obtained allows us to spot and understand bugs more easily.

The traditional approach to audited computation is to store the computation log by means of ad-hoc instrumentation of a given program: this is error-prone and requires a lot of effort. There are however recent proposals of core functional languages with built-in logging and auditing, including the Calculus of Audited Units (CAU [1]) and the Provenance Inspection Calculus (PIC [2]), which provide auditing as a first class primitive without the need for ad hoc instrumentation.

Your task is to write a prototype implementation of a small functional language based on CAU or PIC, and provide an experimental evaluation of the additional computational cost of auditing; since we expect at least a linear slowdown under straightforward implementations, you will also investigate smarter evaluation techniques to mitigate it (the supervisor will be happy to discuss this topic: some ideas for CAU can be found at [3]).
goal: Implementation of an interpreter for a core functional language with history logging and auditing, and evaluation of its performance.
completion_criteria: At a minimum, you will:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       +

(1) Implement a parser, an interpreter, and a pretty printer for either CAU or PIC.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           +

(2) Write a few test programs and use them to analyse the additional computational cost (space and time) of auditing. Your analysis should highlight the inefficiencies of a direct implementation of CAU or PIC and demonstrate the gains achieved by your optimisations.

title: Cross-platform app development with ahead-of-time compilation
description:
Recent estimates of smartphone OS share report that more than 99% of smartphones run either the Android or iOS operating systems. Worldwide, Android devices outsell iOS devices in the ratio 80:20, but in some countries, such as the UK, the ratio is more like 50:50. Inconveniently for app developers, the two platforms have entirely different software ecosystems, with Android offering Java or Kotlin for app development in Android Studio and iOS offering Objective-C or Swift for app development in Xcode. Because these two entirely different software ecosystems are used, many apps which are available for both Android and iOS exist in two entirely different versions; one for iOS and one for Android. This adds a significant increase in cost when developing a new app and presents an obvious software maintenance headache when new features are to be added to the app, requiring them to be implemented consistently both on the Android and iOS platforms.

An alternative approach is to use a mobile app SDK which supports both the Android and iOS platforms. This allows only a single codebase to be used, making app development and maintenance easier. Several such SDKs exist to support cross-platform development but many of these offer JavaScript as the implementation language, which brings with it many legacy problems of the JavaScript language. Improved app performance and security can be achieved by selecting an SDK which uses a compiled programming language which is transpiled ahead-of-time into native code for multiple platforms. One new offering in the cross-platform app development SDK market is Flutter, which supports the Dart programming language, allowing a single Dart source code project to be compiled for both Android and iOS.

The purpose of this project is to test the effectiveness of the Flutter platform in practice by developing a Dart implementation of the location-based game project from the UG3 Large Practicals and comparing it with the direct Android implementation produced last year in terms of ease-of-development, code size and complexity, and robustness and performance of the end-product apps.


Note: This project requires the use of a Mac platform to run Xcode.  The School of Informatics does not provide these so ​before applying for this project please ensure that you have a Mac to run Xcode.  An iPhone or Android phone would be useful, but are not essential.  You should have taken the Software Engineering Large Practical or the Computer Science Large Practical in UG3.
goal: To assess the effectiveness of a cross-platform SDK for Android and iOS development.
completion_criteria: A completed Dart app for a location-based game which is compared against the Android-only version which was developed for the Large Practicals last year.

title: Firewall administration, the game
description:
I am no longer accepting new registrations of interest as of Sunday 1st April for this project because I will be out of town part of the next week and will not be able to meet with students.

Managing the Firewall policy rules for a large network is quite challenging even for a skilled system administrator. Firewall policy rules contain constructs such as chains, rule ordering, and networking concepts. All of these are incredibly challenging to teach to new potential system administrators.

The goal of this project is to create a game that simulates the problems firewall administrators face on a daily basis and helps a student learn about the various aspects of firewall administration in a game type environment. The game would be used to help teach students what network administration actually looks like. It would also be used in research studies to create a realistic environment to test new approaches in network administration.

A player might start trying to secure a single computer that contains valuable data. They might then move on to handling a network where they get continuous tickets from users and alerts about new attacks that they need to manage. Information visualization approaches might also be integrated to assist the player in understanding what is happening on the network.

A potential work program for this project would look like:

1. Learn about firewall administration by doing a literature review, going through tutorials, and setting up a small test system to test out various configurations. Come up with some theories about what you think people need to know about firewalls.

2. Mock up a game that targets specific aspects of firewall administration

3. Test the mock-up on a small number of other people.

4. Design and build the game.

5. Evaluate the game by having others play it.

The game can be in any format that matches the target population. So a computer game, web game, or app are all acceptable.

This project can be undertaken by more than one student at once. However, I will require the students to select different Firewall applications to base their games on. For example: IPTables, Cisco, pf, ipfw, and ipfilter.

This project has a wide range to the difficulty. It could be a quite simple project for someone with game experience or a good understanding of firewalls. There are also some research aspects to it, so a skilled student could make the game more advanced or do actual publishable research on it.

MInf: For MInf students, the second year would involve a large-scale evaluation of the game either with a large group of people or a comparison study with other games.
goal: Create a game that emulates the experience of being a security system administrator in charge of managing Firewall policy rules.
completion_criteria: A program which emulates the typical duties of a Firewall system administrator in a game like environment. Play testing with other students.

title: Kotlin versus Swift for app development
description:
A recent, and very welcome, advance in the app development ecosystem is the availability of modern, strongly-typed languages for app development. Apple announced the Swift language as a supported language for iOS development in 2014 and Google announced Kotlin as a supported language for the Android platform in 2017. The availability of these languages has meant that developers have access to programming languages which support a cleaner development style which allows them to write more concise and more reliable software.

Two early-stage projects exist which offer the possibility to cross the development tracks to use Swift for Android development (the SCADE development platform) or Kotlin for iOS development (the Kotlin/Native/CLion project). In the light of these possibilities, it could be a good idea to compare and contrast Kotlin and Swift as app development languages. This project proposes to do this by creating a Swift version of the location-based game which was developed in Kotlin in the Computer Science Large Practical in UG3. Having two separate implementations of this app will make it possible to compare the development experience in Kotlin and Swift in terms of the code quality of the two projects, noting aspects which were more difficult in one paradigm than the other, and to comment on the tool support which is provided in the two development paths.


Note: This project requires the use of a Mac platform to run Xcode.  The School of Informatics does not provide these so before applying for this project please ensure that you have a Mac to run Xcode.  An iPhone would be useful, but is not essential.  You should have taken the Computer Science Large Practical in UG3.
goal: To compare the Swift and Kotlin programming languages through the development of the same app on both platforms.
completion_criteria: A comparison between a Swift and a Kotlin implementation of a location-based game app.

title: An interface for Axiom.
description:
This project will be the second iteration of a continuing effort.  Here is the original proposal:

Axiom is a powerful computer algebra system which was at one time very expensive but is now open source (see http://www.inf.ed.ac.uk/teaching/courses/ca/ for more information). The current interface is purely terminal based and suffers from some oddities when attempting to edit input. The aim of this project is to carry out a study of available alternatives (e.g., emacs mode at https://github.com/ustcscgy/axiom-environment) and ideally provide a fully documented implementation of an interface that gives reliable editing facilities. It is unlikely that it will be possible to produce a modern graphic interface as part of the project but the feasibility of this would make a good case study.  See  http://www.inf.ed.ac.uk/teaching/courses/ca/ for more information on Axiom.


The first iteration has focused on a web based interface that interprets Axiom's output using its abulityh to produce LaTeX commands amongs other features.  It also provides bette oinput editing facilities.  The second iteration will extend the available features (e.g., better capturing of error and warning messages).  Ideallhy it will also allow the possibility of using Axiom on a rmeote machine, e.g., a user can work on his/her laptop while running Axiom on a DICE machine.  The exact features set will be identified through discussion with the supervisor.

The degree of difficulty depends on the exact feature set and can vary from moderate to very hard.  If the project is undertaken by an MInf student then the first year can be of moderate difficulty but the second year would be of at least hard difficulty.

Please note that it is a precondition of this project that all the code is open source and the result is placed on a public repository such as GitHub.
goal: Ideally produce a modern interface to Axiom.
completion_criteria: Significant extasion to exisitng functionality as well as somew new features.

title: Direct estimation of fundamental frequency (F0) from speech waveforms with neural networks
description:
Prosodic features such as stress and intonation/pitch play important role in human speech communication. In computer-based speech synthesis, synthesising appropriate prosody is vital to make the sound natural. The problem is that corresponding physical features such as fundamental frequency (F0) are
still difficult to estimate from real speech signals. In contrast to existing F0 estimation algorithms that are based on periodicity analysis either in time
domain or in frequency domain, this project seeks to develop a deep neural network that takes raw waveforms as input and estimates F0 as output.
goal: To develop a DNN-based system that estimates fundamental frequency (F0) directly from speech waveforms.
completion_criteria: Develop a system that automatically estimates smooth F0 contours from speech, and carry out evaluation experiments.

title: Participant management software for HCI and project students
description:
I am no longer accepting new registrations of interest as of Sunday 1st April for this project because I will be out of town part of the next week and will not be able to meet with interested students.

The core of this project is to build a website where students (or researchers) can post studies and potential participants can look through the list and sign up for studies. "Researchers" could be many types of people in Informatics, including HCI students, project students, or even students for other courses where students need to test the usability of software on people.

For user-facing projects, normally the last step is to perform an evaluation with humans to make sure the project is usable. But for project students, it can be challenging to find friends willing to spend time evaluating their project. On the other hand, there are quite a few UG1, UG2 and UG3 students who would like to get a closer look at what mostly complete final projects look like. There are also quite a few project students who might be interested in trading evaluation time (evaluate each other's projects).

A participant management system helps solve this type of problem without constantly emailing a list. Students with projects they want to evaluate post the project on the management system along with some basic facts about the evaluation such as how long it will be, if you have to have passed a specific class first, and if they are providing financial compensation. Then all the potential participants who have registered interest in that type of project are sent an email. They can then log into the system to register interest and sign up to do the evaluation.

For this project, the student will be building a website including the client side interface, back end server code, and database. The choice of language and technologies is up to the student.

Some of the issues that must be addressed in the project include:

  • Requirements gathering
  • Authentication of researchers/participants
  • Searching through projects
  • Researcher/Participant communication
goal: Build a web (or app) application that lets students advertise studies and participants to sign up for them.
completion_criteria: Software that allows a researcher to post a project and a potential participant to sign up for it.

title: Learning to play Backgammon
description:
There are many ways of learning strategies for playing games from agent simulations.  This project will investigate a particular method---Monte Carlo Tree Search or MCTS---for learning to play Backgammon.  The rules of the game are here:

https://www.pagat.com/beating/cheat.html

Your tasks would be as follows:

1) Build a  game and simulation environment for Backgammon (or find an existing implementation that you can build on).

2) Design and implement an agent (or agents) that play Backgammon, via simple heuristics-based methods.

3) Design and implement a model for  learning to play Backgammon (e.g., MCTS, or you could also use Deep RL).

4) Evaluate these models against some baseline (e.g., the heuristics-based agents you developed in the first place, or random play).
goal: To use a MCTS or a similar approach to learn to play Backgammon
completion_criteria: Implementaiton of a Backgammon simulation environoment; implementation of heuristics-based players; testing and evaluation of a player that has learned its strategy from game simulations.

title: Automatic detection and classification of human head gestures
description: Non-verbal gestures such as facial expressions and body gestures play an important role in human-human communication. This project considers head gestures (such as nodding and shaking) in dialogue conversation and seeks to develop a system that analyses motion capture data of head movements to detect events of head gestures and classify the gestures automatically.  A bootstrap machine learning approach based on deep learning or hidden Markov models will be explored to cope with a large amount of data. If time allows, clustering approaches will be explored to find various gesture units automatically.
goal: To develop an automatic annotation system of human head gestures on motion capture data using machine learning techniques.
completion_criteria: Develop an automatic annotation system of head gestures on head motion data, carry out evaluation experiments, and analyse the result.

title: Tucker-2 Decompositions for Neuroscience Applications in Python
description:
The activity of populations of neurons is typically hard to interpret. Matrix and tensor decompositions provide useful tools to decompose neural activity into meaningful elements. These elements have utility for compactly describing and for classifying the data. In particular, the Tucker-2 decomposition can factorize spatiotemporal neural data into trial-independent spatial and temporal modules and trial-dependent activation coefficients.

The Tucker-2 decomposition is a versatile tensor factorization that is applicable in conjunction with constraints such as non-negativity and orthogonality. Notably, different constraints can be used for different factors. Python packages supporting various mixed constraints are currently lacking.

The goal of this project is to implement a Python package for Tucker-2 decompositions subject to versatile constraints and its validation on simple artificial data. The project can be extended to include analysis of real-world neuroscience datasets.
goal: Implement and validate a Python package for Tucker-2 decompositions subject to various constraints aiming at neuroscience datasets
completion_criteria: Completed Python package for Tucker-2 decompositions with a focus on neuroscience applications and validation thereof.

title: Deep Neural Decision Trees
description:
This project would suit someone interested in machine learning, decision trees and/or neural networks. Scaling machine learning to big datasets with parallel/GPU computation, building interpretable ML models.

We recently noticed that the venerable decision tree model can be encoded in the forward pass of an appropriately constrained deep neural network, and thus DTs can be trained with back-propagation rather than conventional methods like ID3/C4.5. Explore this connection in practice and in theory. 

  • Can we adapt any theoretical results for DT learning to help understand DNNs/obtain theoretical guarantees about DNNs? 
  • What are the pros and cons of learning a DT via ID3/C4.5 versus SGD and Backprop?
  • Can we use distributed implementations of SGD backprop to outperform existing DT training implementations in terms of scaling to big data?

  • Can we we use GPU implementations of SGD backprop to efficiently train DTs?
  • How does a SGD-trained Neural Decision Tree compare to a conventionally trained DT in accuracy?
  • Explore using Neural Decision Trees to train interpretable, rather than black-box, neural networks.


This has the potential to be of great interest to industry, which often requires interpretable models. Neural Decision Trees can provide interpretability, but scalability and open-source of DNN optimisation platforms. 

The project is labeled "EASY" because any reasonable student should be able to do a basic version of this project. However if done to a higher standard by a good and motivated student, this project will certainly result in a publication.

We have a pretty good implementation you can start with, or write your own from scratch.

The reference below is to the ICCV'15 best-paper-prize-winning article on deep neural decision forests, which is somewhat related. Ours is a more faithful model of a decision tree realised as a DNN, which conveys much stronger advantages of interpretability, etc.


Notes: Recently, ML related projects have a high number of applicants, more than I can feasibly meet individually. Therefore I will arrange a group meeting with everyone who has registered interest on 28th March 2018 in order to discuss the project. For the same reason I will strictly enforce the pre-requisites.
goal: Implement, Test, Evaluate and Improve our Neural Decision Tree Model
completion_criteria: Implement and benchmark NNDT for accuracy and execution performance.

title: A research publications scraper
description:
The Networks research group in Informatics maintains an online presence at https://networks.inf.ed.ac.uk/ The wep page contains a list of publications section, which at the moment is being updated manually by a single person. The administrator has to keep up to date with a growing and changing number of members and periodically email each of the current members to enquire if they have new research papers accepted for publication, so as to keep the web site fresh.

The goal of this project is to build a web scraping tool that will crawl the list of group members and respectively their personal web pages, Google scholar profiles, PURE entries, etc., in order to gather all new publications authored by these. Based on the information collected, the tool will automatically update the group's web page on a daily basis, seeking to avoid duplicate entries and order the papers by publication date.
goal: Build a web to dynamically update the list of publications of the Networks@Inf group members.
completion_criteria: A web crawling tool that can update the list of publications of all group members on https://networks.inf.ed.ac.uk/.

title: Designing a front-end for a functional custom-language
description:
Lift is a novel language for expressing data-parallelism developed in Edinburgh. The language is very small and is mainly based on lambda-calculus. The main goal of this project is to write a standalone frontend for the Lift project. This will be based on an existing prototype frontend developed in a prior project.

This will involve writing a Lexer and Parser for our small language. Part of the project will also deal with aspect of language design. For instance, we might look at language features such as polymorphism, parametric type and possible integration with other widespread languages such as C.
goal: Implement a front-end for the Lift language and integrate it with the IntelliJ IDE
completion_criteria: Implementation of the Lift language support in IntelliJ.

title: Dissecting Wireless Heart Rate Monitors
description:
Networked devices with embedded sensors and software that can monitor personal health are becoming more and more popular. At the same time, increasingly more open hardware platforms and drivers enable individuals with minimal networking and programming skills to compromise the security of commodity web-connected IoT devices and the privacy of their users. Discovery of such weaknesses constitutes a major roadblock towards adopting IoT at scale in public health services.

The goal of this project is to identify the most common security vulnerabilities present in a range of wireless heart rate monitors. Once such pitfalls have been uncovered, the student will investigate security mechanisms that could be built into devices with limited capabilities to increase their robustness.
goal: Investigate the security vulnerabilities of a range of Wireless Hear Rate Monitors
completion_criteria: An analysis of the critical security vulnerabilities encountered and possible solutions.

title: The distribution of roots of random polynomials.
description:
In various forms of research it is imporant to know the distribution of the complex roots of random polynomials.  There are theoretical answers when the coefficients are drawn from certain probability distributions but other cases remain very hard to analyse.  For this project we would consider polynomials of a given degree drawn uniformly at random with integer coefficients from the interval [-B,B] where B is a chosen parameter.  A further technical condition is that the polynomials do not have repeated roots (easily arranged) and the gcd of their coefficients is 1 (again easily arranged).  The hypothesis to be tested claims that if we have two discs L and S inside the unit disc with S inside L then the average number of roots in S is no more than the ratio of the area of S to that of L multiplied by the average number of roots in L.  

Extensive experiments carried out by Zhao Zheng under the proposer's supervision suggest that we need to modify the hypothesis, but in a way that is still useful.  There was one surprising finding that was out of line with the others.  The experiments were carried out using an off the shelf root finding package that relied on Laguerre's method.  However this method can miss roots or report complex numbers as roots when in fact they just give a value close to 0. The aim of this project is to implement an exact method of root finding and test the hypothesis, in particular is the result that was out of line still present?  The downside of a toitally reliable algorithm is that it cannot be as fast as numerical methods that accept some unreliabilty.
goal: Implement an exact root finding algorithm and test a hypothesis on root distribution.
completion_criteria: An implementation of an efficient reliable root finding algorithm and experimental results.

title: Optimise and parallelise stencil kernels for GPUs/multicores
description:
Stencil computations are used widely from physical simulations to machine-learning. They are embarrassingly parallel and perfectly fit modern hardware such as Graphic Processing Units. Although stencil computations have been extensively studied, optimizing them for increasingly diverse hardware remains challenging.

In this project, we will gather a series of stencil benchmarks and develop several optimised parallel implementations targeting GPUs and/or multicore CPUs. Depending on the student interest, we will target OpenMP, OpenCL or Cuda, and implement various optimisations techniques.

This will be the opportunity to learn more optimising parallel application on parallel hardware.
goal: Implement and optiimise stencil computations for different parallel hardware
completion_criteria: Parallelise and implement stencil applications

title: Learning how to retarget human motion to characters
description:
Motion retargeting is a process to adapt human motion to virtual characters.  As the sizes of virtual characters are different from the real humans, simple retargeting based on the joint angles can easily result in body parts penetrating different body parts.  Methods based on inverse kinematics and spatial relationships have been developed but the results my not be satisfactory in some situations according to the context.   Currently, such wrong retargeting are mostly fixed by human animators.  Such a manual fixing results in significant amount of manual labor and automating this process can be very beneficial for animation companies. 


 


In this project, the student will work on a machine learning approach for fixing the motion retargeting process. Different techniques based on Gaussian processes and neural networks will be explored.
goal: Creating a neural network structure that retarget human motion to virtual characters
completion_criteria: Constructing a network that can generate motion of different people.

title: Lecture transcription correction interface
description:
Automatic lecture transcription is very useful, but speech recognition typically has some errors.  The aim of this project is to design and implement a web interface that enables users to correct automatic transcriptions.  The project should 

  • ​design a basic interface to present transcribed lectures (including video, audio, subtitles, any other information) using web standards
  • design an interface to allow users to correct specific speech recognition errors
  • to come up with a specification of the system
  • implementation of the system, and extensive testing against the specification
  • design and execution of a user-based evaluation
goal: Design, implementation, and evaluation of a web interface that allows the correction of lecture speech transcripts by multiple users.
completion_criteria: Development of a tested working demonstration system

title: Text-driven head motion synthesis of animated agents using neural networks
description: The project aims to apply recent technologies of neural networks to automatically learn typical motions of human heads during conversation and associate the motions with the utterance of the speaker, so that the learned model can generate head motions of an animated agent from text. In the literature of animated talking faces, a lot of studies have done to create natural lip motions that are synchronised with speech  (i.e. lip-sync). The current project, however, put more emphasis on the synthesis of natural head motions, which has not been studied that much compared with lip-sync regardless the fact that head motions play crucial roles to make synthetic talking heads natural. We will be particularly interested in the neural network models that are able to learn typical head motion patterns (trajectories) in a unsupervised manner.
goal: To develop a system that is capable of synthesising a lifelike talking head from text using neural networks
