completion_criteria: Develop a text-driven talking face system, create video clips for evaluations, and carry out objective and subjective evaluations.

title: Strava - Cycle Route Finder
description:
Strava is one of the world's most popular networks for athletes recording exercise data from millions of users worldwide. It is capable of using data from devices that capture GPS tracks and a whole host of other biometric data whilst exercising and is very popular among casual, amateur and professional cyclists. In this project you will be working with data obtained from Strava from Edinburgh and Glasgow for the year 2016.

The aim of this project is to develop an algorithm to learn the most popular routes cycled by users and to create a Strava compliant route database system to add these routes to Strava via their API. The project is challenging because many exercise journeys are fragmented into segments that need to be connected intelligently to make sensible routes. Notably, this is not a route-prediction challenge the likes of which are handled by services like GoogleMaps, rather an automatic analysis of real-user data to create real-world route maps that are of practical use to cyclists. These "real" routes take into account human factors that are not included in current route prediction approaches including aesthetic and safety issues that are not readily apparent from other convergent data (such as car use data, accident hot-spots). The possibility exists to compare the real-world inferred routes to those predicted by established artificial networks to assess just how different user-derived routes are from those often suggested by online mapping tools. If effective this approach could be deployed through Strava Labs as an App for end-users.
goal: To develop an algorithm for reconstructing popular ride routes from Strava user data
completion_criteria: - development of an approach to extract and anneal Strava segments to form routes                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +

- application to Edinburgh & Glasgow 2016 data                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                +

- comparison of approach against at least one other automatic prediction method                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               +
- upload of routes onto Strava through their API

title: Algorithms workbench for Inf2B
description:
The aim of this project is to extend the fucntionality of open source softwware built by Eziama Ubachukwu and later by otgher students later on which can be obtained via the Inf2B page http://www.inf.ed.ac.uk/teaching/courses/inf2b/resources/adsSoftware.html (this is not the latest version).


Here is the original proposal:

Inf2B has a thread on Algorithms and Data Structures in which many fundamental algorithms are introduced along with their worst case runtime analysis. Algorithms are given by means of pseudocode. It would be useful to have a system that enables students to implement algorithms in a language quite close to pseudocode and then enables them to experiment with runtime studies (perhaps also space used). The tool must make this process as convenient as possible thus encouraging experimentation. For example if a student wishes to compare quicksort with mergesort he/she should be able to express these in the course pseudocode and then ask for runtimes based on data created either by the student or the system. After that timings should be produced both in tabular form as well as plots. The system should also determine the constants involved in the standard upper bounds. A refinement would be to enable the student to ask for the timings of sections of the code so that the critical parts can be identified.

It is hoped that the project (which is currentluy in its third iteration) will be ported to a virtual server with a web interface during the current academic year (2017-18).  Whatever is the case there will be a range of desirable extensions that can be agreed between the student and supervisor.  As an example, the system has the capability of creating pdf reports which can then be incorporated by the student into a document that is edited so that notes and observations on experiments can be recorded.  It woudl eb desirable to have a lecturer account mode so that exercises/experiments can be suggested or set as part of assesment with a submit facility linked for the student answers.

Please note that it is a precondition of this project that all the code is open source and the result is placed on a public repository such as GitHub.
goal: Add significant new functionality to a tool that enables students to study the performance of algorithms.
completion_criteria: A significant extension to the existing software (underlying algorithms, interface).

title: Learning neural embeddings of newsworthy personalities and issues
description:
There are many instances where one wants to infer something about a person, for example, her demographic attributes, personal preferences, or finding other people who are similar. This project aims to use neural networks to learn low dimensional vector representations of people which can then be input into some of these predictive problems. Such neural embeddings have been explored for users on social media. This project will create embeddings for newsworthy people and issues.

Embeddings for social media users are created with a variety of goals related to advertising, predicting likes, behaviour or political opinion. On the other hand, there is value to creating such representations of newsworthy people such politicians, celebrities, and business leaders while simultaneously also representing newsworthy issues in the same latent space. Such representations are of value to political and social scientists, economists and like. For example, an economist would be interested in knowing if two legislators are apriori positive about a particular issue to then ask if political logrolling could be involved on a bill.

The scope of this project is to learn such embeddings from a large news archive containing articles published by the New York Times over a 20 year period. The tasks involved are to identify and disambiguate newsworthy people over the entire archive (there is metadata to aid this step), find mentions of these people in the text, and extract their quotes as a proxy of their views. Further to that is extraction of the topic or news issue that is being spoken about and linking people to issues, creating a network structure. Then the task is to estimate embeddings for people and issues using a neural network model to explain the text as well as network structure. The student will explore previously developed models for social media users, and make any improvements as necessary.
goal: To use neural networks to learn a low dimensional vector representation of popular people in the news
completion_criteria: - Extract people and issue mentions from news articles                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        +

- Create a network of people and issues                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       +

- Implement a model for learning user embeddings based on one of the previously proposed frameworks, but making changes as per the network and evidence available for this problem                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            +
- Evaluate the embeddings using some predictive task

title: Testing language inclusion via Kurshan's construction
description:
Buchi automata are similar to finite automata, except that they accept infinite words instead of finite words.
Given two Buchi automata A and B, the language inclusion problem asks whether L(A) ⊆ L(B).
This question is computationally hard (PSPACE-complete), but modern tools like RABIT

http://www.languageinclusion.org/doku.php?id=ramseysimsub
can solve nontrivial instances by a variety of methods (Ramsey-based
antichain techniques, simulation based automata minimization, etc.).

A partial approach to language inclusion testing has been described by Kurshan
(see paper). Given automaton B with n states, Kurshan’s construction
builds an automaton B' with 2n states such that Complement(L(B )) ⊆ L (B'), i.e., B' over-approximates the complement of B.
This yields a sufficient test for inclusion, since L(A) ∩ L(B') = empty implies L(A) ⊆ L(B)
(though generally not vice-versa). This condition can be checked in polynomial time.

The question is how often Kurshan's technique can prove inclusion,
in cases where it holds. I.e., in most instances, some instances, or hardly ever?
Also, is Kurshan's algorithm faster on these instances than the RABIT tool?
Is it worth applying existing automata minimization techniques to A and B'
before testing whether L(A) ∩ L(B') = empty ?
 
The task of this project is to implement Kurshan's algorithm in Java within the
existing framework of the RABIT tool, test it on a large number of randomly
generated instances and to analyze the results.
goal: Implement and test Kurshan's algorithm in the framework of the RABIT tool
completion_criteria: 1. Implementation of Kurshan's algorithm for language inclusion in Java, within the framework of the RABIT tool.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              +

2. Testing the performance of this algorithm relative to existing algorithms in the RABIT tool, on randomly generated instances according to the Tabakov-Vardi automata generator.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            +
3. Analysis and graphical presentation of the data obtained from the experiments.

title: Topics in agents modelling other agents
description:
A second group meeting for this project will take place on Wednesday 4 April at 2pm in room 2.06, Informatics Forum.

Note to interested students: There will be a group meeting for this project during which interested students can ask questions. The meeting will take place on Thursday 15 March at 10am in room 2.06, Informatics Forum.

The design of autonomous agents which can interact with other agents to accomplish tasks in complex dynamic environments is one of the core areas of research of artificial intelligence. Such agents must be able to reason about the unknown beliefs, intentions, and behaviours of other agents based on their observed actions and other available data. A recent survey by Albrecht and Stone (https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.08071) provides an overview of the existing methodologies and concludes with a section on open problems.

I am interested in supervising projects in this general area, especially projects addressing open problems from the AS survey. Project goals are flexible and may include the comparison of existing methods and the development of novel methods.

There are two types of projects that could be generated from the survey:

  • Choose one of the modelling methods discussed in Section 4 of the survey (e.g. policy reconstruction, plan recognition, classification, etc.) and compare existing algorithms from that category in multi-agent simulation experiments.​ For example, algorithms could be compared based on prediction accuracy, learning speed, and ability to generalise.
  • Choose one of the open problems discussed in Section 5 of the survey and develop a novel approach to address the problem. This involves the design of new modelling methods (or modification of existing methods) and evaluation in multi-agent simulation experiments.

Ideally, the experiments are done in an interesting interactive environment that requires effective modelling of other agents to be successful. Examples include classic games (e.g. chess, checkers, poker), commercial video games (e.g. Starcraft), adaptive user interfaces (in which the interface agent adapts by modelling the human user), and simulations of autonomous vehicles.

Projects in this category require creativity, perseverance, and hard work, but have the potential to generate novel results.
goal: Flexible, depending on project.
completion_criteria: Flexible, depending on project.

title: Automated Source Code Rejuvenation
description:
Programmers rely on programming idioms, design patterns, and workaround techniques to make up for missing programming language support. Evolving languages often address frequently encountered problems by adding language and library support to subsequent releases. By using new features, programmers can express their intent more directly. As new concerns, such as parallelism or security, arise, early idioms and language facilities can become serious liabilities. Modern code sometimes benefits from optimization techniques not feasible for code that uses less expressive constructs. Manual source code migration is expensive, time-consuming, and prone to errors.

Source code rejuvenation, the automated migration of legacy code is a new approach relying on tool support for this task. While refactoring improves structurally inadequate source code, source code rejuvenation leverages enhanced program language and library facilities by finding and replacing coding patterns that can be expressed through higher-level software abstractions. Raising the level of abstraction benefits software maintainability, security, and performance.

An example of source code rejuvenation is detecting and rewriting a user-defined linked list data structure along with its operations (insert, find, ...) into an equivalent form provided by the C++ standard template library, thus lifting the level of abstraction.

Several projects are available in this area dealing with different aspects of source code rejuvenation, e.g. involving container data structures, iterator ranges, graphs, and so on. The project can accommodate various levels of difficulty from easy to challenging. The projects are suited for UG4 and MInf students.

Note: An easy project still requires all the essential skills and knowledge!
goal: To develop a set of (compiler) tools for rejuvenating programming idioms
completion_criteria: Tool successfully transforms one or several benchmark application(s) comprising a particular low-level programming idiom and raises its abstraction to e.g. match a feature provided by the STL

title: Regression for fast approximate Bayesian inference with implicit generative models
description:
Increasingly complex generative models are being used across the scientific disciplines, ranging from biology and physics to the health sciences and computer vision. A common difficulty with generative models is the large computational cost to learn (infer) their parameters.

So-called likelihood-free inference, or approximate Bayesian computation, yields solutions when other methods cannot be used. But these methods are rather slow and their applicability is limited to inference of a handful of parameters only.

Approximate Bayesian computation produces approximate samples from the posterior distribution. Regression is widely used to adjust the samples as part of a post-processing procedure with the aim of increasing the accuracy of the estimates, see e.g. [2] for a recent review.

The goal of this project is to use regression not only to increase the accuracy of the estimates but also to accelerate the inference.
goal: Use regression to accelerate and improve the quality of the inference
completion_criteria: - Building on previous work, robust software that uses regression as a module to accelerate approximate Bayesian computation                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  +
- By extending previous work, detailed validation on benchmark inference problems

title: A Blockchain-based Lecture Attendance App
description:
International students studying in the UK are required as a condition of their general student visa to prove that they are engaging with their degree programme and attending classes, lectures and tutorials as required. This includes participating in the requirements of the course including submitting assignments, attending meetings with tutors, and attending examinations. For some of these activities, attendance is recorded (for example, tutorials and examinations) whereas for others it is typically not (principally, lectures). It might be helpful to allow students to (optionally) record evidence of their attendance at lectures using a mobile phone app which records the user's location during the lecture times for their selected courses only (at other times the user's location is not recorded, for privacy reasons).

The GPS location recording technology on a smartphone is not accurate enough to determine which room in a building the device is in, but together with reverse geocoding it can be used at least to determine the user's location as a street address. While this cannot be used to prove that the user attended a lecture, it can at least be used to argue that they were in the lecture building, as opposed to somewhere else, thus providing some evidence of attendance and engagement. (No system of this kind can ever absolutely prove attendance beyond all doubt because it is after all only recording the position of the device, not the owner of the device, and in addition it is of course possible to spoof the GPS location of a device, but it provides more than the zero evidence of attendance which a student has at present.  A possible way to strengthen the evidence that the user is where the device is would be to use the fingerprint sensor of the device and require the user to authenticate themselves with a fingerprint at the start and the end of the lecture.)

The app should provide a secure login mechanism so that the location information records are associated with a named student. The app would be configured with a copy of the Informatics timetable, which the user can use to identify the courses which they take. During the lecture times for those courses -- typically a 50 minute period -- the app records the user's location, and determines an average location over the lecture period, which is used to determine their location as an address, using reverse geocoding.  Other statistical information about this average location could also be recorded, such as the standard deviation, to give further proof of being at a fixed location for a fixed period of time.

This location information, and the identity of the user, is recorded in the blockchain to give a permanent, timestamped proof of the attendance data. Anchoring the data in the blockchain provides compelling tamper-proof evidence that the lecture was attended at the advertised lecture time, and that this information has not been altered after the fact, because it is computationally infeasible to do so. It should be possible to review the location records later, and show them to anyone who has the proper legal authority to ask for them.

The app which records the location information could be implemented for an Android phone (using Java or Kotlin) or an iPhone (using Objective-C or Swift). The blockchain could be accessed through the Tierion API to produce a Chainpoint timestamp proof, or it could be accessed via a different approach.
goal: To produce a mobile phone app where lecture attendance information is stored in the blockchain.
completion_criteria: The project will produce a smartphone app which allows lecture attendance to be recorded using blockchain technology.

title: Insect Inspired Robotics
description:
This is new style of project, exploring an alternative way to teach some of the material previously covered in the course Intelligent Autonomous Robotics.

A small group of students will be jointly guided through the acquisition/extension of skills in programming autonomous behaviour in real robots, and in understanding relevant biological mechanisms of control. This will be developed into individual projects to implement and test specific insect-like capabilities on robots.

Example target behaviours could include: foraging and return to the nest in ants; visual hunting in dragonflies; escape behaviours in crabs; abstract pattern learning in bees; place learning in fruitflies.

Depending on the student's interests, the focus could be on replicating the sensory or motor systems, on the algorithms that underly robust behaviour in complex environments, or on modelling the underlying neural circuits. There would be scope for subsets of students to work together to develop different aspects of a single system, or for students to work individually on their own complete robot model, but discussion and interchange of ideas and methods will be strongly encouraged throughout. It should also be possible for projects to be extended for a second year as an MInf.
goal: To build and programme a robot system that replicates the ability of insects to interact adaptively and robustly with the world
completion_criteria: Demonstrate a working robot system that emulates insect behaviour

title: Evaluate the round-trip engineering of Yatta's UML Lab tool
description:
Round-trip engineering is a term for software development in which models, e.g. in UML, are developed simultaneously with code, e.g. in Java. As discussed in the Software Design and Modelling course, although round-trip engineering tools have been in existence for over a decade, they still tend to be fragile and difficult to use, because properties of bidirectional transformations are still controversial and difficult to ensure, and good languages for writing bidirectional transformations do not yet exist.

Yatta's UML Lab tool, which is free for academic use though not open source, claims to have particularly good round-trip engineering facilities. This project will evaluate the claim. The student will:

- search the literature for any related academic papers or documentation pertaining to the design or intended properties of UML Lab's round-trip engineering

- investigate the behaviour of the tool, with respect to standard properties of bidirectional transformations (correctness, hippocraticness etc.)

- develop a collection of examples with which to illustrate and test the behaviour (either demonstrating that a particular property does hold, or that it does not)

- add these examples, where appropriate, to the Bx Examples Repository, along with appropriate artefacts

- critically evaluate the behaviour of the tool.

This project will suit a student who: is taking Software Design and Modelling, covering precise UML modelling and concepts of bidirectional model transformations; is comfortable working with complex, Eclipse-based software, even where documentation may be out of date. Given this background, the project need not be especially challenging, though it has scope to be made so by doing it particularly well..
goal: Investigate the functionality of  Yatta's UML Lab tool, with particular reference to its round-trip engineering capabilties, and critically evaluate it by use of a test suite to be developed.
completion_criteria: Precise statements have been made about which bidirectional transformation properties are/are not possessed by UML Lab in given application scenarios, supported as appropriate by illustrative examples.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     +
These illustrative examples have been added to the Bx Examples Repository, along with appropriate artefacts.

title: Experiments in Social Signals Analysis for COPD patients
description:
Compulsive Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is an umbrella term for respiratory conditions such as chronic bronchitis, emphysema and upper airways obstruction. COPD is a challenge for the National Health Service [1] - it accounts for the second largest cause of emergency hospital admissions (one million bed days and 21% of all respiratory beds each year in the UK); these admissions account for 54% of the total £800 million spent on COPD; and worryingly, in 2007 the British Lung Foundation estimated around 75% of COPD cases remain undiagnosed.

The RESpeck device is worn as a plaster on the chest and measures continuously respiratory rate/effort and activity types. After local processing the data is transmitted via a mobile device to the server for analysis. This project will investigate methods to analyse the data to derive social signals from the sensor data such as periods and types of activities, and number of speech episodes, which when combined with the physiological parameters will provide a better estimate of the patient’s condition.

This project will analyse the COPD data set and develop a scorecard which combines the physiological and social signals and correlate this to the patients’ condition as reported in the diaries.
goal: Develop a scorecard which combines respiratory rate/effort and social signals from COPD patients
completion_criteria: Software which combines physiological parameters and social signals to produces a score which is correlated with reported conditions.

title: A modal logic for continuous probability distributions
description:
A Modal logic for continuous probability distributions

When it comes to robotic agents operating in an uncertain world, a major concern in knowledge representation is to bet- ter relate high-level logical accounts of beliefs and action to the low-level probabilistic sensorimotor data. Perhaps the most general formalism for dealing with degrees of belief in formulas, and in particular, with how that should evolve in the presence of noisy sensing and acting is the first-order logical account by Bacchus, Halpern, and Levesque (BHL) [1999]. The main advantage of a logical account like BHL is that it allows a specification of belief that can be partial or incomplete, in keeping with whatever information is available about the do- main, making it particularly attractive for general-purpose high-level programming. 



Our starting point is the logic OBL [Belle et al., 2016] for reasoning about degrees of belief and only knowing, the latter modality allowing a succinct char- acterization for the beliefs of a knowledge base, and an earlier paper on reasoning about continuous probability distributions [Belle and Levesque, 2013]. 

Background / Prerequisites

- A very strong background in mathematical logic, especially first order logic and modal logic
- Strong foundations in probability theory




A First-Order Logic of Probability and Only Knowing in Unbounded Domains. Belle, V.; Lakemeyer, G.; and Levesque, H. In AAAI, 2016.

Reasoning about Continuous Uncertainty in the Situation Calculus. Belle, V.; and Levesque, H. J. In IJCAI, 2013.
goal: Developing a modal logic for subjective probabilities
completion_criteria: A successful thesis puts together some formal definitions in an expressive first order logic, and studies semantical properties.

title: A first-order logic for moral responsibility and blameworthiness
description:
A first-order logic for moral responsibility and blameworthiness

Morality and blame are intricate concepts with deep philosophical foundations. Imagine a trolley going down a road, on the path to harm 5 people. Suppose you could pull a lever that moves the path of the trolley but end up hurting one person. Would you do it? What's the amount of blame that should be accorded to you for pulling / not pulling the lever?

When it comes to autonomous agents perhaps there is some hope of rigorously formalising morality and blame.

A successful thesis puts together some formal definitions in an expressive first order logic, and studies semantical properties. It is also possible to focus solely on he formalisation of actual causality.

Background / Prerequisites

- A very strong background in mathematical logic, especially first order logic and modal logic
- Strong foundations in probability theory


http://www.cornell.edu/video/joe-halpern-moral-responsibility-blameworthiness-intention-formal-definitions


A First-Order Logic of Probability and Only Knowing in Unbounded Domains. Belle, V.; Lakemeyer, G.; and Levesque, H. In AAAI, 2016.
goal: Developing a first-order modal logic for morality
completion_criteria: A successful thesis puts together some formal definitions in an expressive first order logic, and studies semantical properties. It is also possible to focus solely on he formalisation of actual causality.

title: Fair Machine Learning
description:
Machine learning now plays an important role in many areas of society, but do we accidentally create a machine learning system that happens to be morally bad (like implicitly using race to discriminate)? If so, how can we avoid it? This project is about exploring approaches to train machine learning models with a certain degree of guarantee that the trained model will not use some sensitive factors (e.g., gender, ethnicity) implicitly. As an example, CNNs to predict human ratings of facial attractiveness is a topical application in computer vision. Can we build such a system that is guaranteed to not even implicitly use ethnicity in its prediction?

Notes: 

1. Recently, ML related projects have a high number of applicants, more than I can feasibly meet individually. Therefore I will arrange a group meeting with everyone who has registered interest on 28th March 2018 in order to discuss the project. For the same reason I will strictly enforce the pre-requisites.

2. FYI, This project will mainly be supervised by my postdoc Yongxin Yang.
goal: Implement a proof of concept fair machine learning system using adversarial domain adaptation.
completion_criteria: Implementing an Adversarial Domain Adaptation [Ganin, 16] for face recognition in which discrimination for identity is preserved while discrimination for another factor (e.g., ethnic) is eliminated (in ADA, domain factor becomes undistinguishable through a GAN-style training).

title: Parameter inference in dynamic models with noisy starting conditions
description:
Systems biology models can be described using sets of chemical equations, which can be simulated using ordinary differential equations, or simulated stochastically. The models are governed by a potentially large number of free parameters, many of which are hard to determine experimentally. In principle, the free parameters may be fit by minimising the discrepancy of the model to data, but typically there are large uncertainties in parameters (Gutenkunst et al., 2007). However, there are some directions in parameter space in which there is small uncertainty, meaning that the model's behaviour depends crucially on a few directions in parameter space. Finding these directions allows the variability in the behaviour of the system to be predicted, even if the parameters cannot be known precisely.

The ultimate aim of this project is to apply a sloppy parameter analysis to a model of the interactions between calcium and calmodulin fit to calcium imaging data (Faas & al, 2011). This would lead to a joint publication with Guido Faas. Two MSc students have worked on the project already. The first student learned how to run the simulations such that we could find the sloppy directions when compared to the fitted model presented by Faas & al. (2011). The second student implemented the model of calcium uncaging and calcium fluorescence needed to fit with the fluorescent time series data supplied by Guido Faas. However, there were problems fitting the model to the data, and we discovered a fundamental problem that would be the focus of this project: At the start of each experiment, calcium is released from a caging molecule using a flash of light. However, it is not possible to control the amount of calcium released precisely. Thus the starting conditions of the ODEs describing the chemical reactions are unknown, making it difficult to fit each theoretical trace to the experimental trace. Should we introduce one "nuisance" parameter for each simulation? Is it possible to scale each trace?

If we can answer these questions, we will be able to run Monte Carlo Markov Chain (MCMC) algorithms to explore the shape of the parameter space. Sloppy analysis suggests it will be an ellipsoid, but it may have a more complex shape. Knowing the uncertainty in parameters might be able to resolve an experimental controversy over the value of some of the calcium-calmodulin binding parameters.
goal: Understand how to infer parameters in dynamic models when the starting conditions are unknown
completion_criteria: * A proposal for how to deal with the noisy starting conditions                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               +
* An implementation of the proposal

title: High-dimensional Bayesian optimisation for learning in generative models
description:
Increasingly complex generative models are being used across the scientific disciplines, ranging from biology and physics to the health sciences and computer vision. A common difficulty with generative models is the large computational cost to learn (infer) their parameters.

So-called likelihood-free inference methods yield solutions when other methods cannot be used. But they are rather slow and their applicability is limited to inference of a handful of parameters only.

We have recently shown that combining nonlinear regression with optimisation (Bayesian optimisation) accelerates the inference by orders of magnitude [1]. The scalability of the approach to joint inference of multiple parameters, however, has not yet been established.

The goal of the project is to investigate how existing algorithms for high-dimensional Bayesian optimisation (e.g. [2] and related work) perform in high-dimensional parameter inference.
goal: Adapt algorithms for high-dimensional Bayesian optimisation to high-dimensional parameter inference and establish their performance
completion_criteria: (1) Following reference [1], adapt existing algorithms for Bayesian optimisation to parameter inference.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      +
(2) Investigate the performance of the algorithm on benchmark inference tasks.

title: Unit Conversion in Machine Translation
description:
Human translators may choose to convert units during the translation, for instance converting between the imperial and metric system, or between currencies. In human-translated parallel data, we thus find translations like this:

Mi hermano estaba conduciendo a 100 km/h.
My brother was driving at 60 miles an hour

Neural sequence-to-sequence models are able to extract patterns from human translations and learn to translate new text. However, their ability to learn unit conversion from data is unlikely to generalize well, and generalization errors are possible:

Mi hermano estaba conduciendo a 85 km/h.
My brother was driving at 85 miles an hour.

This project will analyze unit conversion and the translation of numbers in neural machine translation. It will start with an analysis of parallel training data and baseline MT systems to investigate how common conversion phenomena are in human translation, and to what extent they are problematic for MT. Finally, it will develop techniques to improve unit conversion in MT, for instance via data augmentation or the integration of a rule-based component.
goal: Analysis of unit conversion in parallel data and baseline MT systems, and development of better unit conversion
completion_criteria: - analysis of unit conversion and number translation in parallel data                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         +

- evaluation of unit conversion in baseline neural MT model                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   +
- development and evaluation of MT system with improved unit conversion capability

title: Blind assistive system: Recognition and haptic-depth
description:
The project would involve researching how to best achieve the set out principal goal, hence the following stage description is purposefully vague:

[1] Investigating and prototyping the required hardware:
> Haptic depth representation could be embedded in a headband, indicating proximity to an object with pressure in that direction. The resolution is to be experimentally determined (vertical as well as horizontal). The array of drivers behind these small pressure actuators could be linear solenoids.

> Depth information could be obtained using the Kinect. The placement of it (or them) on the users body is also to be experimentally determined.

> The processing would ideally be done on a portable Raspberry PI, subject to the computational needs.

[2] Processing of the sensory data/ experimenting with user interface:
> Translating the depth information would need to be robust and reliable - processed using OpenCV.
> Various strategies for environment and object recognition - to, for example, warn the user about objects at different depths and relative speeds (the user could request more information about the environment - this would be auditory).

 [3] Reporting:
> Report findings in dissertation.

[4] Lab testing:
> Depth image analysis evaluation.
> Tactile sensor performance evaluation.
> Test participants.
> Report findings in dissertation.

[5] Field testing:
> Test visually-impaired participants.
> Report findings in dissertation.
goal: Design, build and evaluate a tactile headband that helps blind people navigate robustly and reliably, by using depth to detect and recognize various objects / environmental features and signaling this to the user with tactile stimulus.
completion_criteria: Deliver the product and all the reports.

title: Streaming parallelism in Scala
description:
Stream processing is a programming paradigm that allows easy representation of data processing pipelines. Once specified, these pipelines can then be parallelised. Several specialised languages have been developed that aim to make writing stream processing programs easy, providing abstractions that are appropriate to the problem. However, this requires a new language to be used by developers.Scala is a functional programming language which is inherently compatible with Java. It provides sufficient abstractions to allow streaming parallelism to be represented in a natural, native fashion.The goal of this project then is to implement streaming parallelism in Scala. In itself, this is not enormously difficult. However, to make parallelism efficient, pipeline elements must be load balanced. Consider the case when one element is a bottleneck. In this case its predecessor element will completely fill its queue and will stall, similarly successor elements will stall. The bottleneck element could be replicated to increase throughput. These load balancing issues apply to the whole programming graph, leading to difficult problems in managing the ideal balance. An excellent implementation will attempt to approach this ideal balance.Must be very good at programming in Scala already.


Please, do not ask about this project if you are not already a proficient Scala programmer.

Do you know what implicit means in Scala? If you have to look it up then this project isn't for you.
goal: To develop a streaming parallelism library Scala.
completion_criteria: Minimal criterion is to produce a usable streaming parallelism library\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      +

in Scala, together with a small number of example applications.\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +

A good project will implement dynamic load balancing/pipeline\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               +

replication.\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                +
An excellent project will consider optimising parallelism parameters.

title: Compiler Parallel Dependency Online Tutor
description:
This project is for someone who is deeply interested in compilers. If you can read chapters two and three of Optimising Compilers for Modern Architectures by Kennedy ( http://www.amazon.co.uk/Optimizing-Compilers-Modern-Architectures-Dependence-based/dp/1558602860) and think 'Wow, I love it,' then this is for you. Otherwise, not so much.

Dependence analysis is crucial to the performance of modern architectures, but it can be difficult for students to understand the details and get a firm, intuitive grasp of how various techniques work. This project hopes to bridge the gap, giving students a website that will allow them to type in example code and see how different analysis techniques operate on the array and scalar references in the program. The website should accept some reasonable input language and allow users to explore the code for different dependencies, showing graphs and charts where appropriate. As many different analysis algorithms as possible should be included.

At the end of this project you will understand the details of dependence analysis in enormous detail.

A similar project was done last year about data flow analysis (http://ayrtonmassey.com/proj/)
goal: To build an online system to help students learn and understand dependence, direction and distance vectors for compiler analysis of parallel programs and loop nests.
completion_criteria: A website demonstrating the use of dependence analysis.

title: Shared Memory Parallel Programming Tutor
description: Shared memory (or "multi-threaded") parallel programming can be hard to understand, for beginners and professionals alike. Simply executing a program doesn't always help much - there are often far more potential executions than can examined by any realistic testing framework. Before looking at the complexities of real languages, courses such as Parallel Programming Languages and Systems (PPLS) begin by introducing very simplified versions, which get to the heart of the underlying issues of atomicity of operations, thread interleaving, and memory consistency models. Even for very simple programs in very simple languages, the range of potential behaviours can be quite surprising. The aim of this project is to develop an interactive educational tool which will allow students to play, replay, rewind and generally interact with the simulated execution of such simple programs, in order to better understand their behaviour. A good place to start will be to look at the simple "co, await, sequentially consistent" programs introduced early in the PPLS course, and the simple underlying parallel machine model they assume. At the heart of the Tutor will be a simulator for such a system, with facilities to allow the user to control and investigate executions. This could be extended with a more game-like interface, which sets challenges for the student, with more sophisticated programming constructs, or with more complex (and realistic) memory consistency models.
goal: To build a GUI based tutoring application which helps students to understand the complexities of shared memory parallel programming, through interactive exploration.
completion_criteria: A basic level of completion would have a simple system implemented which allows exploration of concurrent threads of straight-line code, sequentially consistent semantics, and a simple "await" style synchronization mechanism. More advanced projects could extend the range of program structures catered for, and the consistency models allowed.

title: Parallel Task Scheduling Tutor
description: In parallel systems, task scheduling is the problem of deciding when and where to run the tasks which make up an overall application. There are a range of variants of the problem: for example, the tasks may all be known in advance, or they may emerge dynamically; the tasks may be independent, or they may have dependencies which constrain when they can execute; communication between tasks may be free, or expensive; the set of available processors may be homogeneous or heterogeneous. There are also a range of proposed algorithms and heuristics for the problem. The aim of this project is to build an educational Java application which allows the student to play with the task scheduling problem in an engaging and interactive way. For example, the student could be challenged to play the role of task scheduler, allocating to tasks to resources in simulated time, competing with standard algorithms, etc. Key features will be an intuitive and engaging interface, a range of difficulty levels and a range of problem variants.
goal: To build a game-like Java application which allows students to explore the challenges inherent in scheduling interdependent tasks across a set of processors.
completion_criteria: A basic level of completion would have at least one simple variant of the problem implemented, with a simple but appealing interface (eg drag and drop), and good feedback on success (or otherwise). This will be straightforward for a good programmer, so there is room for creativity once the basics have been achieved.

title: Parallel Skeleton Library for DICE
description:
Writing parallel programs which are correct and efficient is widely acknowledged to be a challenging task. The use of parallel algorithmic patterns (or “skeletons”) to abstract and simplify this challenge is growing in popularity. Each pattern captures the core structure of a class of parallel algorithms. The programmer specializes the pattern to a particular situation by writing some type definitions and sequential code, while the pre-defined pattern implementation handles the hard work of providing and optimizing the necessary parallel code.

While several skeleton based systems have been constructed, they tend to rely on quite complex software frameworks, and/or more modern versions of tools (eg compilers and libraries) than are provided in the School's standard DICE set-up. This makes them troublesome to use in teaching contexts, both because non-standard versions and packages must be made available and maintained, and because the corresponding complexities can be hard for students to understand and investigate.

The goal of this project is to design and implement a "DICE-friendly" parallel skeleton library, which will allow students already familiar with C/C++ to investigate the world of skeletons without having to wrestle with the additional complexities of non-DICE friendly implementations. Design inspiration and examples can be drawn from existing skeleton libraries.
goal: To build and evaluate a C skeleton-based parallel programming library which is compatible with the standard DICE software setup.
completion_criteria: A basic completion would involve a simple library, with at least one skeleton-oriented bulk data type, two or three of the classic skeletons, some examples of these in action, and a Pthreads parallelized implementation which achieves modest speed-ups on multicore DICE lab hardware.

title: Examining how regional variations in protein expression in the human brain map onto psychiatric diseases
description:
Some background information I have received from Prof. Douglas Armstrong:

"The synaptic proteome is widely believed to be the molecular machine that underpins the core functions of neurons – the integration and transfer of information from one cell to another. Perhaps unsurprisingly it is enriched for proteins whose genes are linked to a wide range of human neurological conditions. However GWAS datasets from these conditions map less clearly onto the synaptic proteome often with weak or no significant enrichment. The synaptic proteome can be subdivided, on the basis of network topology  into clusters that each have enriched functional associations. We hypothesised that these topological communities form natural groups for gene set analysis and contain information not only about protein encoding genes with a mechanistic association with the phenotype but also with interaction partners whose role is important but less obvious. We combined 30 published synaptic proteomic studies from 2000 to date to obtain a list of 6500 molecules. We retrieved protein-protein interactions (PPIs) for combined list and built the most complete up-to-date PPI networks for presynaptic and postsynaptic compartments. We then divided this proteome up into sub-communities on the basis of network topology. We analysed three large Genome Wide Associations Studies of genetic associations with human cognitive ability or educational attainment. A single community was found to have a significantly enriched association with educational attainment (n>100,000) and this was then replicated across the other cohorts. The community contained half of the synaptic glutamate receptors. However, the glutamate receptors (as a group) are under strong evolutionary selection pressure and showed no significant association with the phenotype on Genome Wide Association analysis (GWAS). The majority of the signal in the community arose from other proteins in a dense subgraph closely linked to the glutamate receptors."

The project's aim will then be to use the results and the data the previous excerpt mentions in conjunction with existing publicly available datasets in order to investigate correlations between regional variations in protein expression in the human brain and psychiatric diseases.
goal: To examine how regional variations in protein expression in the human brain map onto psychiatric diseases
completion_criteria: Hypothesis testing: Statistical evaluation of whether brain expression profiles show regional specific enrichment for disease association - or not.

title: Bayesian experimental design and active learning
description:
From [1] "Experimental design has very broad applications across the natural, medical and social sciences, as well as in engineering, business and finance."

Bayesian experimental design uses the Bayesian learning machinery together with utility functions to decide what experiment and/or measurement to perform.

Different utility functions have been proposed in the past according that are optimal for learning, model comparison, or prediction tasks. The goal of the project is to investigate the practical differences between these utility functions.
goal: Investigate practical differences of classical Bayesian experimental design strategies
completion_criteria: - comparison of classical Bayesian experimental design strategies on at least two toy problems

title: Learning over HOL Light dependency graphs
description:
Recently, the use of lemma dependencies has had an implicit, yet significant, impact on the way many interactive theorem proving users carry out proof. For instance, this forms the backbone for the machine learning infrastructure that allows Isabelle's sledgehammer [2] to suggest the appropriate theorems to be sent to automatic theorem provers when trying to discharge proof steps automatically. 

Yet, despite this success, the use of such dependencies has been relatively limited. In particular, no one has exploited the fact that the information is available as a (huge) graph that could be used to explore the structure of formalized theories, extract useful meta-information such as the centralities (measures of importance) of various concepts and, ultimately, be used for machine learning.

The aims of this project are to:

  • Translate the HOL Light dependencies (that will be made available as JSON objects) into an appropriate format (e.g. graph database) that will enable the formalized libraries to be explored interactively and at scale in order to gain useful insights into the relationships between various concepts and carry out suitable automated learning and discovery tasks (e.g. link predictions and lemma ranking or even concepts discovery) during proof.

Note: Any interested student must discuss the project with the supervisor in order to be considered for it.
goal: Explore the (directed) dependencies between HOL Light objects as a graph and carry out discovery tasks in support of interactive theorem proving
completion_criteria: Robust mechanisms and tools for systematically generating Isabelle dependencies as reusable and shareable datasets; Design and implementation of algorithms for exploring any Isabelle development graphically and interactively and for the predictions/discovery of concepts (e.g. lemmas) that can then be suggested to the user (or sent to automated tools) during interactive proofs.

title: Speak to me! - eye-contact recognition and synthesis for lifelike conversational agents with personalities
description:
Lifelike conversational agents aim to facilitate human friendly man-machine interface so that humans can communicate with machines in much the same manners as the communication between humans. There have been a lot of attempts to make virtual agents more natural, e.g., synthesising photo realistic facial images, realistic lip movement, realistic facial expressions and head movement. Most of these attempts mainly focus on a one-way direction of communication, i.e., from agent (machine) to human. On the other hand, eye contact requires bidirectional processing - when a human looks at the agent, the agent should detect the gaze and stare back at the user, with reasonable actions such as beginning conversation, changing facial expressions, and nodding.
The proposed project investigate a mechanism for recognising the user's eye contact and controlling eye gaze of the agent to establish eye contact with the user. We hypothesise that the way how the eyes move and how eye contact is established/broken during conversation depends on speaker's individuality and personality.
goal: To develop a lifelike conversational software agent that is capable of establishing eye-contact with the user.
completion_criteria: Develop an eye-gaze recognition system from video images, and                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +

develop an animated agent that is capable of controlling eye gaze                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +

during speaking and listening. Carry out objective and subjective                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +
evaluation experiments.

title: Neural Networks for Software Testing
description:
The ultimate vision for researchers in software testing is to completely automate the testing process.
Although there has been considerable progress, over the past few decades, in automating test input generation and test execution,
automatically checking the correctness of test executions remains unsolved.
This problem of assigning a `pass' or `fail' verdict via inspection of extremely large sets of internal states and outputs
is referred to as the test oracle problem in the literature. 

The goal in the project is to solve the test oracle problem for a given software by automatically classifying test executions.
To achieve this goal, the project will leverage recent advances in neural networks that have been successfully applied to challenging classification problems
in other domains. We will achieve our goal via the following objectives:
1) Identifying important subsets of observations in test executions to feed to neural networks;
2) Encoding the observations in an input format that is efficient and useful for the neural network; and
3) Designing  a classification model that predicts verdicts with high accuracy.
goal: Automatically classifying test executions as pass or fail
completion_criteria: The project should at the minimum achieve objectives 2 and 3 for a single large software and existing set of tests. Objective 1 can be avoided at the start; the student can assume that only the test outputs are important observations to feed to the neural network. An exceptional project will also achieve Objective 1.

title: Tackling algorithmic bias
description:
Algorithms play a key role in the functioning of autonomous decision systems, and so concerns have periodically been raised about the possibility of algorithmic bias [1].

Systems are currently in charge that decide bank loans, criminals’ incarceration, and the hiring of new employees, and it’s not difficult to envision that they will in the future underpin most of the decisions in society. Despite the high complexity entailed by this task, there is still not much understanding of basic properties of such systems. [3]

While biasses in general are unavoidable and can be useful in optimisation (see the no-free-lunch theorems [2]), there are also examples of undesirable and counterproductive algorithmic biasses, which require particular attention.

In addition to the relations between the different types of biasses, the project will consider the question whether fairness-utility trade-offs necessarily exist, how to reduce them in algorithm design, and how to deal with indirect cases, where biasses arise through latent variables. The project will include a substantial part of conceptual work, i.e. a discussion of different types of biasses, approaches and algorithms, but the main part will be a case study on a given (or, if preferred, a self-chosen) data set. The are no requirements on the computer language to be used.
goal: Discuss both necesary and unfair algorithmic biasses based on an in-depth analysis of a medium-size data set
completion_criteria: Provide evidence related to the question whether fairness-utility trade-offs are unavoidable based on a particular data set and a particular set of classification algorithms.

title: A symbolic algebraic simplification system for high performance code generation
description:
Generating high performance code requires compilers to perform advanced simplification of arithmetic expression found typically in array indices. Examples of such simplifications includes anything from folding constant (e.g. 2+5 = 5) to simplify modulo operations (e.g. (x × y + z)/y = x + z/y  if y!=0).

In the context of Lift, a language we are developing in my group, we have already implemented such a system. However, we are now reaching the limit of what it can do. We therefore, want to explorer a new design for our simplification mechanisms and possibly use existing solvers for this problem.
goal: Implement an algebraic simplifcation system
completion_criteria: Achieve proper simplifcation of arithmetic expressions.

title: Collective behaviour in a robot swarm
description:
The main determinant of the situation of a robot in a large swarm is the behaviour of other robots. In order to cope with the reflexivity in swarm control, in addition to programming and control theory, also principles of self-organisation were considered. This means that the robots negotiate their actions based on competition as well as cooperation within the swarm. While these principles are theoretically well understood, it is still a challenge to apply them in real robot swarms and to combine them with any goals of the swarm system (e.g. surveillance, path finding or material transport). The project will study the realisability of mechanisms for self-organisation in a robot swarm and the compatibility of these mechanisms with task-related behaviour. The two main task of the project

  1. analysis of and benchmarks for swarm behaviour
  2. modelling and control using reaction-diffusion equations (requires some background in PDEs)

will be distributed between the students working on the project. Other task will be possible, but are not required. It is planned that the project includes experiments with a large scale swarm of Mona robots, but it should be considered that, if robots are unavailable at the start of the project, then project will run as a simulation study.
goal: Demonstrate self-organisation of behaviour in a large robot swarm
completion_criteria: Completion of the individual projects does not depend on the realisation of the main goal of the project nor on other subprojects. Completion criteria for the above tasks would be                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           +

1. design or improvement as well as test a vision system that is able to identify desired behaviour in a robot swarm                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          +
2. estimation of the number of robots required in order to physically simulate the a reaction-diffusion system in different contexts.

title: Re-engineering a hotel for rodents: Location system design and rebuild.
description:
Background

Rodents used in laboratory research are usually housed in small groups in cages where they eat, sleep, drink, groom, and interact socially. Moreover, animals are often placed in these groups from weaning and are therefore likely to establish high-order social. Typical studies then extract them from the group for behavioural analysis which is stressful and very artificial. Sponsored by the NC3Rs, a UofE spin-out company Actual Analytics Ltd has created a home-cage analysis system where the animals remain in their social group (see Bains 2016). The system exploits RFID identify chips that are injected into the rodents, an array of RFID detectors under the homepage and IR video recording. 

​


​Commercial Nature

None: This is an industry sponsored project, a confidentiality agreement and IP agreement will need to be signed. A public dataset will be made available for the purposes of project write up and demonstions. 

​Project(s)

The current system is based on a windows operating system. For a number of technical and commercial reasons we want to explore migrating the system to a linux/unix environment. This will involve the rebuilding and testing of the low level driver units used for the RFID detection system, the redesign and rebuilding of the video capture and compression systems and the addition of new components, for example live reporting to a central feed for multiple install system (typical deployment is 4 or 8 systems).
goal: Redesign and reimplement the components used in a modern laboratory data capture system.
completion_criteria: Optimse and evaluate a new linux based driver for the RFID field

title: Analysis of large scale extracellular neural recordings
description:
Large scale, high density microelectrode arrays (HD-MEA) now allow the simultaneous recording of the activity of thousands of neurons, both in vitro and in vivo. These arrays record the extracellular voltage changes produced by neurons with thousands of closely spaced channels at near cellular resolution, providing an unbiased sample of neural activity [1-3].

In such recordings, the activity of each neuron can be seen as a small deflection in the extracellular potential (a spike) - and it is a major challenge to then reconstruct the activity of single neurons from this mixture of noisy signals, a process called spike sorting [1].

Here we will develop and improve methodology to solve this and related problem efficiently for large data sets with tens of millions of individual events, and raw data in the order of 100s of GB. 

Two projects are available, one on assessing data compression methods, and one on optimising spike sorting using ground truth data.

This project is marked as be 'variable', and it will be easy to obtain sufficient results for a dissertation, since an extensive code-base already exists (Python and C++). There are however ample opportunities to contribute and test novel ideas, especially for students with a good machine learning background and interest in complex data analysis.
goal: Implement and test methodology to improve spike sorting in large scale MEA recordings
completion_criteria: Implementation of appropriate methodology, testing and validation on one synthetic and one real data set.

title: Evaluate the usability of a security or privacy tool
description:
I am no longer accepting new registrations of interest as of Sunday 1st April for this project because I will be out of town part of the next week and will not be able to meet with interested students.

One of the reasons people do not use security and privacy technologies is due to a lack of usability. While we know at a technical level how to do things like encryption, secure protocols, e-voting, and access control; often the benefits of these technologies are not seen by average users because the technologies are not well designed from a usability perspective.

In this project, the student will:

1. Decide on a security or privacy tool to test. The tool must be user facing, but "users" can include people like developers, system administrators, security students, or other non-traditional user groups.

2. Perform a usability evaluation on the tool. The evaluation will likely involve multiple smaller evaluations such as a heuristic evaluation by the student themselves followed by a user evaluation possibly using the think aloud protocol or a larger survey-based evaluation. The evaluation part will also involve deciding what "usable" means in the context of the tool.

3. Write up the outcomes of the evaluation and think about how to improve the system.

4. Mock up an improved UI for the system. The mock-up does not need to be fully functional. It could be done using paper or wizard of oz style (pay no attention to the man behind the curtain).

5. Evaluate the new UI compared to the prior one.

There are many security and privacy technologies that could be chosen for this project. The following are a few ideas to get you started. The Simply Secure blog (linked below) is also a good place to start looking for ideas.

  • User awareness tools intended to help the general public learn how to be secure.
  • Email encryption plugins. There are any number of email encryption plugins that are challenging for people to use or that have poor defaults. Enigmail is one of the most common, but others could be chosen.
  • ​DKIM signature verification on Thunderbird.
  • Certificate warning interfaces on any of the web browsers.
  • SSL/TLS APIs
  • E-voting

MInf: For the second year, the student has a few options. They could put more effort into actually implementing their recommended changes into the software. They could extend their evaluation to more software of the same type. For example, having identified issues with IM encryption software they could investigate multiple types of software to see if the issues are common and generate a set of recommendations. Another option would be to simply run the above project a second time but with a different software being evaluated.


I am no longer accepting new registrations of interest as of Sunday
1st April for this project because I will be out of town part of the
next week and will not be able to meet with students.
goal: Perfom a human-computer-interaction evaluation of an existing privacy or security technology, propose improvements, and evaluate the effectiveness of the improvements.
completion_criteria: The student must complete an evaluation of a security or privacy technology, produce a mock-up of an improved system, and evaluate the improved system.

title: Model-based classification of neurons in the retina
description:
If we present a simple visual stimulus, e.g. a sequence of lights and darks, to a mouse retina, we observe that some retinal ganglion cells (RGCs, the output neurons in the retina) mostly respond to the light stimulus (ON cells), whereas others mostly respond to the dark stimulus (OFF cells). In addition, a range of different behaviours exist, such as cells responding to both dark and light stimuli (ON-OFF cells), with variable degrees of preference for either dark or light [1]. These are properties that can be better understood using a model-based approach, where simple filter models are fit to the recorded data [2].

It has recently been shown that there may be more than 30 different cell types in the mouse retina [3]. The project will address the question t what extent ganglion cells can be functionally classified based on their responses. As a first step, simulated spike data will be generated, and fit with appropriate models. Once this works, data recorded from the retina by our experimental collaborators, with many 100s of neurons recorded simultaneously, will be used.
goal: To fit models to simulated and experimentally recorded responses from retinal neurons and evaluate these functionally.
completion_criteria: Fitting at least simulated, and ideally real data, using the models and algorithms in reference 2.

title: Exploring Geographic Networks
description: The Vistorian (http://vistorian.net) is an interactive online platform for visualizing dyanmic multivariate and geographic networks. This project sees visualization and interaction techniques to allow exploring cluttered networks, where nodes have (changing) geographic positions. The project requires creativity and a good understanding of problems related to data visualization and user interface design. The student will be asked to design and investigate several techniques to visualize relationships, geography, and time. Eventually, the techniques should be implemented as part of The Vistorian.
goal: Implement visualization techniques
completion_criteria: Design and implement visualization and interaction techniques.

title: 3D surface approximation using continuous functions based on StaticFusion data
description:
Motivation: enabling compatible visual perception data for planning robot locomotion.

Goal: find continuous and differentiable surface functions to represent the environment.

Prior work: dense surfel -based reconstruction using RGB-D data; StaticFusion: Background Reconstruction for Dense RGB-D SLAM in Dynamic Environments.

Approach: given point cloud data from the prior work (StaticFusion), build continuous and smooth 3D surfaces that approximate the point could surfaces with minimum error.

Technical aspects

  1. Pre-processing point cloud data, filtering, noise reduction;
  2. Build library of continuous surface functions;
  3. Use optimization algorithms to optimize parameters of the surface functions;
  4. Design optimization objective that is suitable for accurate surface approximation, ie minimizing the errors;
  5. Experiments of some test scenarios, eg different terrains and floors, collect experimental data;
  6. Analyse and benchmark the approximation accuracies.

Expected outcomes: given a test scenario, scan the environment, generate continuous surfaces (C2 continuous, differentiable) that approximate the environment, with standard deviation within centimetre scale; possible initial integration with footstep planning algorithms.
goal: Use optimization to optimize parameters of continous surface functions to approximate 3D point cloud
completion_criteria: Generate continuous surfaces that approximate the environment, with standard deviation within centimetre scale.

title: Footstep planner for Valkyrie robot
description:
The NASA Valkyrie is one of the most advanced humanoid robots in the world. The robot was constructed by NASA-JSC in 2015 and delivered to the University of Edinburgh in Spring 2016. Weighing 125 kg and standing 1.8m tall, Valkyrie will enable breakthroughs in humanoid control, motion planning and perception. PhD Students and researchers from Edinburgh Centre for Robotics will carry out research using the robot.

The aim of this project is to develop efficient and effective automatic footstep planner given high-level command, eg joystick or wearable devices, for operating the Valkyrie robot. This automated process will enable robot autonomy. Therefore, there is a huge potential to improve our human-in-loop performance by giving robot more autonomy and reducing the load of human supervision.

The project requires the student to team up with other students in our Edinburgh Centre for Robotics and accomplish the following work:

  1. Successful installation and validation of demos of the Valkyrie simulation in ROS+Gazebo environment (see the links in references);​
  2. Alternatively, IHMC java based Valkyrie simulation environment (see the links in references);​
  3. Develop basic footstep planning on flat ground;
  4. Develop self-collision check for the planning algorithm;
  5. Troubleshooting, code quality test, and validation in the simulation environment.

* All developments will be done in Linux only.

Note: students are encouraged to send their CVs by emails for pre-screening the suitability.
goal: To develop algorithms of planning footsteps for the walking controller of Valkyrie humanoid robot
completion_criteria: In the end of the project, a user should be able to successfully command a robot locomotion by a joystick to realize forward/back/side walks as well as turning.

title: Learning dynamic behavior of a quadruped robot
description:
Motivation and background

Compared to the human walking, many walking gaits realized by humanoid robots based on current engineering approaches are still very awkward and unnatural. Despite the engineering control approach is deterministic and analytic, as demonstrated by the Boston Dynamics' new Atlas robot, it still lacks of the elegance and energetic efficiency.
