A good way to develop a complex control system is to design a high-level objective at the task or performance level, then give the authority to the optimization process to figure out the details. This optimization process can by realized either by a model-based approach, ie using mathematical optimization tools to optimize the dynamics model; or by a model-free approach, using machine learning to build up a statistical model and control policies via trials. This is similar to biological movements in nature that follows optimality principles, since they are shaped by iterative optimization processes, ie evolution.

Goal: dynamic locomotion of a quadruped robot that traverses a variety of rugged terrains

Prior work: DeepMind Control Suite, OpenAI gym (see reference)

Approach: Robot model -- ANYmal robot in Mujoco physics simulator (see reference); method -- deep reinforcement learning algorithms

Technical aspects:

  1. Learn how to use  Mujoco physics engine;
  2. 2D-Model of the ANYmal robot in Mujoco simulator​ with the same physical parameters, based on the existing Cheetah robot;
  3. Retrain the deep reinforcement learning in DeepMind Control Suite for the ANYmal model on the flat ground, achieve balanced locomotion;
  4. Add Lidar scanner in ANYmal model;
  5. Create obstacles in Mujoco simulator​;
  6. Retrain the deep reinforcement learning using the height map scanned by Lidar.

Expected outcomes: the simulated robot (2D) should be able to trot or bounce on the flat ground, and negotiate with simple obstacles with a Lidar sensor.

Note: students are encouraged to send their CVs by emails for discussing the suitability.
goal: Control of dynamic legged locomotion/behavior of a quadruped robot to traverse a variety of rugged terrains
completion_criteria: Successful implementation of  the simulated robot should be able to trot or bounce on the flat ground, and an outstanding completion will be negotiating with simple obstacles with a Lidar sensor.

title: App for Gathering Experiment Data on Set Recommendation for Multiagent Coordination (Back End)
description:
Sharing economy applications need to coordinate humans, each of whom may  have different preferences over the provided service. Traditional approaches model this as a resource allocation problem and solve it by identifying matches between users and resources. These require knowledge of user preferences and, crucially, assume that they act deterministically or, equivalently, that each of them is expected to accept the proposed match. This assumption is unrealistic for applications like ridesharing and house sharing (like airbnb), where user coordination requires handling of the diversity and uncertainty in human behaviour [1].

The aim of this project is to produce an App Front and Back End that will fascilitate data gathering in sharing economy applications, when users are recommended sets/lists of options, and where each individual user's (independent) choice affects the outcome for all (or a subset of all) users. A specific problem can be chosen to guide the development, but the Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) should be kept as generic as possible.

This project focusses on developing the Back End.

Similar projects have been put up for Android Front End and iOS Front End. The project  can be taken at an individual level or as a group project, where students can coordinate their actions. If this is not possible, then the  student would be expected to develop a simple App Front End to demonstrate Back End functionality.
goal: To program a phone app that will recommend users with sets/lists of items, allowing for easy data gathering from user selections of items in those sets/lists. Focussing mostly on the Back End.
completion_criteria: Program a backend that will:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  +

- output set/list recommendations                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +

- anticipate user selections (and error/cancellation signals) from the app                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +

- compute 'solutions' from user selections                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +

- inform users of their final 'solutions'                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     +

- store information from past interactions                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +

Program a phone app (Android and/or iOS) that will:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           +

- receive sets/lists of items from the backend                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                +

- present the information to users                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            +

- allow the users to interact with the lists (at least allow for selecting an item)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           +

- send this information to the backend                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        +

- anticipate and receive final 'solutions' from the backend                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   +
Compile a Demo from your work.

title: Computing multipebble simulations symbolically with BDDs
description: Buchi automata are automata on infinite words. Various simulation preorders are defined on Buchi automata. They under-approximate language inclusion, but are easier to compute. These notions of simulation (direct, delayed, fair) differ in their handling of acceptance conditions.These simulations are generalized by the addition of multiple pebbles, which lead to larger relations at the expense of higher computational effort (i.e., there is a trade-off). Simulations can be expressed by formulae in fixpoint logic (mu-calculus) and thus calculated symbolically by using binary decision diagrams (BDDs) to describe large sets.The task is to implement these algorithms in Java, using a standard BDD library and evaluate the performance of the algorithm.The project requires fluency in automata theory, and the ability to study advanced concepts in the literature like BDDs, multipebble simulations and fixpoint logics.
goal: Implement an algorithm to compute direct multipebble simulation symbolically with binary decision diagrams (BDDs) in Java, and evaluate its performance.
completion_criteria: Completion: Implementation of an algorithm for symbolic computation of direct multipebble simulation in Java. Performance evaluation on test cases. Comparison to an existing explicit-state implementation that computes under-approximations of these multipebble simulations.                                                                                                                                                                                              +
Possible extensions: similar algorithms for delayed/fair multipebble simulation.

title: App for Gathering Experiment Data on Set Recommendation for Multiagent Coordination (Android Front End)
description:
Sharing economy applications need to coordinate humans, each of whom may  have different preferences over the provided service. Traditional approaches model this as a resource allocation problem and solve it by identifying matches between users and resources. These require knowledge of user preferences and, crucially, assume that they act deterministically or, equivalently, that each of them is expected to accept the proposed match. This assumption is unrealistic for applications like ridesharing and house sharing (like airbnb), where user coordination requires handling of the diversity and uncertainty in human behaviour [1].

The aim of this project is to produce an App Front and Back End that will fascilitate data gathering in sharing economy applications, when users are recommended sets/lists of options, and where each individual user's (independent) choice affects the outcome for all (or a subset of all) users. A specific problem can be chosen to guide the development, but the Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) should be kept as generic as possible.

This project focusses on developing an Android Front End.

Similar projects have been put up for iOS Front End and a Back End. The project can be taken at an individual level or as a group project, where students can coordinate their actions. If this is not possible, then the student would be expected to develop a simple Back End to demonstrate App functionality.
goal: To program a phone app that will recommend users with sets/lists of items, allowing for easy data gathering from user selections of items in those sets/lists. Focussing mostly on the Android Front End.
completion_criteria: Program a backend that will:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  +

- output set/list recommendations                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +

- anticipate user selections (and error/cancellation signals) from the app                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +

- compute 'solutions' from user selections                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +

- inform users of their final 'solutions'                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     +

- store information from past interactions                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +

Program a phone app (Android and/or iOS) that will:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           +

- receive sets/lists of items from the backend                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                +

- present the information to users                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            +

- allow the users to interact with the lists (at least allow for selecting an item)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           +

- send this information to the backend                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        +

- anticipate and receive final 'solutions' from the backend                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   +
Compile a Demo from your work.

Compile a Demo from your work.

title: Structured Data Resources for Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD)
description:
Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASDs) affect 1 in 68 children worldwide with boys 4x more likely to have Autism than girls. The disease is hugely heterogeneous with complex co-morbities (associated diseases/features) including Fragile X, Epilepsy, Gastrointestinal/digestive disorders, Feeding, Anxiety disorder, Bipolar disorders, ADHD, Tourette Syndrome and OCD. It is currently the fastest growing developmental disorder and has a huge medical and societal cost. So far over 800 genes have been implicated in ASDs but crucially little is known about their relative importance or association with clinical/physiological features confounding translation of what we know of ASD genetics into clinically actionable information.


In this project you will further develop aspects of our ontology annotation tool (OntoSuite) and use it to annotate ASD relevant ontologies with concept terms extracted from a range of Biomedical data resources. You will use gold-standard sets and manual curation to validate the new association datasets and then use these to begin creating labelled property graphs (LPGs) covering small subsets of the ASD information space. If time allows you will explore methodological development options for the construction and query of LPGs for ASDs.
goal: To develop preliminary association data from ASD data corpora against selected basic science and clinical ontologies
completion_criteria: - application of OntoSuite to ASD ontologies such as Autism DSM-ADI-R ontology (ADAR) and Autism Spectrum Disorder Phenotype Ontology (ASDPO)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +

- estimation of annotation accuracy by comparison to gold-standard data and manual inspection                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +

- parsing and analysis of the Simons Foundation SPARK and SSC autism patient datasets                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         +
- development of a basic ASD-LPG (labelled property graph)

title: Data Mining of Biomedical Literature Resources for Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD)
description:
Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASDs) affect 1 in 68 children worldwide with boys 4x more likely to have Autism than girls. The disease is hugely heterogeneous with complex co-morbities (associated diseases/features) including Fragile X, Epilepsy, Gastrointestinal/digestive disorders, Feeding, Anxiety disorder, Bipolar disorders, ADHD, Tourette Syndrome and OCD. It is currently the fastest growing developmental disorder and has a huge medical and societal cost. So far over 800 genes have been implicated in ASDs but crucially little is known about their relative importance or association with clinical/physiological features confounding translation of what we know of ASD genetics into clinically actionable information.

In this project you will develop approaches for screening Biomedical literature sources to identify those entries that likely contain information on ASDs with a special emphasis on those papers that report clinical and physiological data (i.e. not necessarily genetic data). Once identified the project will use text-mining, NLP and other tools to extract concept-terms and data objects from papers, abstracts, full-texts, tables, figures and images. This pilot curation system will retrieve hard-to-fetch data that is currently not well represented in existing systems that are likely to provide a vital link between genetic and clinical features for ASDs.
goal: To develop an approach for extraction of ASD relevant terms and data from literature resources.
completion_criteria: - parsing of the latest full PubMed dataset to identify ASD relevant papers                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   +

- development of a method to extract data from tables within PDF and HTML journal papers and structure that data into a suitable storage format (e.g. RDF)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +
- development of an approach to identify causality in ASD statements from paper abstracts (e.g. "is associated with", "is not related" etc)

title: Developing a novel approach for combining output in multi-classifier systems
description:
Systems involving multiple classifiers (also known as ensembles) have been widely used as a method of improving performance for
classification tasks in many fields, including medicine and economy [1, 2, 3]. They rely on the principle that one can obtain superior performance to single classifier systems by combining the output of numerous (usually poorly) performing models. Much of the existing research focuses on which specific types of ensembles to use (Random Forrest, AdaBoost \& Co.) [2], whilst there is comparatively little work on finding novel ways of combining the output of multiple classifiers. Recent attempts include using algorithms and techniques widely employed in different areas of mathematics and informatics, such as evolutionary algorithms [4] and game theory-based approaches [5]. The student will start by creating a methodology of testing performance of such systems, generating a baseline performance for different kinds of ensembles, using different kinds of combination performances. Next, the student will use analysis of the dataset to identify the weaknesses of the baseline approaches and they will develop a novel approach that addresses those weaknesses and improves performance. For instance, one widely used approach is based on the majority vote of the classifiers, and assigning different weights to each vote. A possible outcome would be creating a new system for assigning such weights. \newline \newline Possible continuations for Part 2 of the MInf project include developing new combining techniques from scratch and using more modern approaches to tailor feature selection and preprocessing to the strengths of different classifiers used in ensembles.
goal: Improve performance of classifier ensembles by creating a new method to combine the output of the individual classifiers employed in the ensemble.
completion_criteria: Creation of an improved model, building on existing approaches, or proof that changing the details of current approaches does not provide a reasonable improvement in performance.

title: Active learning across different tasks
description:
There is a tension between choosing the actions that maximize the information we gain and those that are most likely to provide immediate rewards. This is known as the explore-exploit trade-off. This trade-off exists in a wide range of scenarios in science, medicine, industry, finance, policy making or robotics.

We have developed a simple online game to understand how people manage these trade-offs, and are interested in seeing how people compare to modern methods for reinforcement learning and optimization, as well as simple heuristic policies.

This project can support multiple students taking different approaches, e.g., focusing on Bayesian optimization, reinforcement learning, or psychologically inspired heuristics. Students undertaking the project may focus on trying to reproduce and predict human behavior, or on trying to solve the task as well as possible.

This project is recommended for students for are strong programmers, and are interested in machine learning, human cognition, and decision making. Students may be asked programming questions in an interview to assess suitability.
goal: Build and evaluate systems that can discover and exploit structure in a simple game
completion_criteria: Building a system to play a simple game with hidden underlying structure, and systematically evaluating that system against human behavior, other systems, or both.

title: Probabilistic programs in Cognitive Science: A Comparison
description:
In recent years, there has been an explosion of tools and languages for probabilistic inference (see http://probabilistic-programming.org/wiki/Home for examples). With this large and growing set of options, each of which uses a different combination of syntax and underlying inference methods, it's unclear which of them a new practitioner should use for a given problem.

This project is designed to make that decision easier, focusing on models and tasks that are relevant to computational cognitive science -- building probabilistic models to understand the human mind and solve difficult prediction and generalization problems. Specifically, the project aims to systematically compare at least three popular probabilistic programming languages (or libraries), along the dimensions of:

1. Speed, or computational efficiency.
2. Parsimony: The number of lines or characters that are necessary to express a model.
3. Accuracy: Different approaches to probabilistic inference lead to different kinds of approximations and errors.

The ideal candidate for this project will be a skilled programmer who is familiar with different methods for probabilistic inference (e.g., variational inference and different approaches to Monte Carlo sampling), and comfortable learning new languages quickly.

Candidate languages (choosing 3-4):

* WebPPL: http://webppl.org
* Stan: http://mc-stan.org/
* Figaro: http://www.cra.com/figaro
* Anglican: http://www.robots.ox.ac.uk/~fwood/anglican/
* PyMC: https://github.com/pymc-devs/pymc

The examples can be drawn from existing demonstrations or models, e.g., from:

* http://probmods.org/v2/
* http://www.manning.com/pfeffer/
* http://www.robots.ox.ac.uk/~fwood/anglican/examples/index.html
goal: Compare at least three probabilistic modelling frameworks in terms of computational efficiency, parsimony and ease-of-use, and correctness, using several examples from computational cognitive sciences.
completion_criteria: A complete project will take several examples written in one probabilistic programming language and implementing them in other languages in as straightforward a way as possible, keeping efficiency in mind. For each example, benchmarks will be collected, including run time, processor utilization, generalization accuracy (e.g., using k-fold validation), and program length.

title: Detecting Paraphrases Based on Abstract Meaning Representation
description:
Abstract meaning representation (AMR) parsing provides an attempt at semantic parsing that includes canonicalization. This means that the AMR formalism attempts to abstract away from the surface form in which meaning is conveyed, and present the meaning of the sentence in a canoncialized form using a graph.

The goal of this project is to see whether AMR can be used to detect paraphrase relations. In a ``perfect world'' using AMR to test for a paraphrase relation of two sentences should be simple. It would require finding the two AMR parses for each of the sentences, and then checking whether they are identical. Since AMR is aimed at abstracting away from the surface form which is used to express meaning, two sentences should be paraphrases only if they have identical AMRs.

However, in practice, things are different. First, there are no known AMR parsers that really completely abstract away from meaning. For example, predicates which have interchangeable meaning use different concepts, and there are errors that exist because of the machine learning techniques that are used for learning the parsers from data. In addition, even using human annotations would not yield perfect AMRs, as the interannotator agreement reported in the literature for AMR is far from 100%.

Finally, meaning is often contexual, and it is not fully possible to determine the corresponding AMR parse just by looking at a given sentence. Entity mentions denote different entities in different contexts, and similarly predicates and nouns are ambiguous and depend on context.

The goal of this project is to see whether AMR can somehow be ``softly'' used, for example, as features in a classifier, to detect paraphrase relations.

For more information about the AMR parser, see here: http://kinloch.inf.ed.ac.uk/amreager.html
goal: development of an algorithm that detects paraphrases based on AMR
completion_criteria: development of an algorithm for detecting paraphrases based on an AMR parser

title: Assessing existing computational models in Computational Psychiatry
description:
Computational psychiatry is a very young field in rapid development. 

Some mental disorders have been well studied, such as schizophrenia and autism, including by studies in our lab. 

Others are much less well understood, such as PTSD, Panic disorder, Borderline and Bipolar Disorder - or some forms of addiction such as alcoholism. 

In this project we will review the existing literature in one of those less -studied disorders (students will choose which disorder they'd like to focus on), and implement one or several computational models, with a critical assessment of what they can explain or not. If time permits, also possible would be to develop behavioural experiments to task particular model predictions. 


-- Note that I'm working at UC Berkeley (California) until mid May 2018, so will have to interact remotely until then -
goal: examine and assess existing computational models in computational psychiatry in a variety of (less understood) disorders
completion_criteria: implementation and critical assessment of an existing model

title: A Software Tool for Recognizing Rule-based Ontology Languages
description: It is widely accepted that existential rules form a natural and convenient way for modeling ontologies. However, if we allow arbitrary existential rules to occur in an ontology, then the basic reasoning tasks, such as satisfiability and query answering, are undecidable. This has led to a flurry of activity for designing decidable ontology languages based on existential rules; see, e.g., [1, 2, 3]. The main ontology languages rely on three decidability paradigms: guardedness, acyclicity and stickiness. The goal of this project is to develop a software tool that assists users to design ontologies by (i) checking whether a given rule-based ontology complies with any of the above decidability paradigms, and (ii) if not, to help the user to modify the ontology in such a way that it complies with at least one of the above paradigms.
goal: To develop a software tool that checks whether a given rule-based ontology, which is essentially a first-order theory, falls in a known ontology language
completion_criteria: Develop a software tool as described above for the main rule-based ontology languages (i.e., linear and guarded existential rules, (weakly-)acyclic existential rules, and (weakly-)sticky existential rules)

title: 3D Face Reconstruction and analysis
description:
Get 3D construction of human faces from 2D images with the algorithm in [1], and compare with the 3D stereo image, identify the difference and analysis the result.

some detailed step:

1 3D reconstruction from the images:
 -- need an algorithm to trim away bad data


2 3D stereo image:
-- need to find features of face

-- need to turn 2D-> 3D data into 3D point cloud

-- registration algorithm and robustness


3 identify the difference between the 3D reconstruction and the 3D stereo images:

-- need to estimate the scales and direction of the faces

-- look at different distance matrics

-- look at different ways to display differences


4 analysis the result:

-- try to assess which method is more accurate

-- consider the scene effect that cause errors

-- apply to large data set ( subset of 10*60*500 images in [2] ) to get statistics on error



5 some possible extensions:

-- apply the 3D faces construction/ 3D stereo image on human face reorganization

-- combine the 3D construction of the images to computer graphics : make some change in face features (could be used in cartoon movies) 

    or make some art effect on images(for example convert the image to different art forms)
goal: reconstruct 3D faces and analysis with 3D stereo image
completion_criteria: Included in description, do the basic analysis, and make some extensions.

title: Measuring and modelling cognitive biases such as the confirmation bias, or optimistic bias
description:
The Confirmation bias  is the tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that confirms one's preexisting beliefs or hypotheses, while giving disproportionately less consideration to alternative possibilities. For example, very optimistic people will continue holding high hopes of winning the lottery, even if the data, or even their own experience, shows that the odds are against it. Similarly, people who believe in conspiracy theory will see evidence for it everywhere in their environment, while people with the opposite belief will on the contrary interpret similar data as proof of their own beliefs. The confirmation bias is type of cognitive bias and a systematic error of inductive reasoning. People display this bias when they gather or remember information selectively, or when they interpret it in a biased way. It can be modelled in terms of suboptimal Bayesian updating. 

The confirmation bias might be relevant to the understanding of mental illness and as such, is of interest to the new field of "computational psychiatry".

The optimism bias has been described as a form of confirmation bias, as well as a Bayesian prior on the likelihood on future rewards. The optimism/pessimism bias is also thought to be relevant to mood disorders (depression and anxiety). 

These projects will continue experiments that we have conducted previously looking at both types of biases. They will most probably involve collecting and modelling new data in human participants. 


-- Note that I'm working at UC Berkeley (California) until mid May 2018, so will have to interact remotely until then -
goal: Designing an experiment/simulated environment to quantify such cognitive bias in humans

title: Impairment of Bayesian inference in Autistic Spectrum Disorder And Schizotypy
description:
We have previously shown that in a visual task involving statistical learning of motion stimuli, participants with autistic traits behave differently from controls [1]. They are less biased by previous expectations and have more veridical perception. This is consistent with previously published literature. However, previous literature suggested (without being able to prove it) that this diminished effect of expectations was related to having weaker perceptual priors. Our modelling work using the framework of Bayesian inference showed instead that this was due to the fact that their perceptual likelihoods were sharper than in people with low autistic traits, i.e. that people with autistic traits have a more precise representation fo the sensory inputs.

In this project we will test similar ideas either with different variants of our statistical learning task or using a more cognitive paradigm, e.g. one that has been used to study schizophrenia [2] and in collaboration with these researchers (Sophie Deneve). The task is coded in Matlab/ Psychophysics toolbox. 

If two students are interested in this project, one student's task could be to recode this task for the internet, to test on the amazon turk, using JPsych [3,4].

The project will involve testing a number of healthy participants (whose personnality traits, such as autistic traits, will be measured using psychological questionnaire), analysing and modelling the results. 

Other variants of this project/task are possible, in people with autistic traits or schizotypy. 

-- Note that I'm working at UC Berkeley (California) until mid May 2018, so will have to interact remotely until then -
goal: Establish whether people with autistic traits/schizotypy differ in how they integrate prior information with incoming new information
completion_criteria: collecting data on at least 30 participants

title: Analyse the security of a software Bitcoin wallet
description:
A bitcoin wallet is a piece of software (sometime coupled with a device) that allows a Bitcoin user to manage his Bitcoin funds. It allows its owner to receive, store and spend his Bitcoins. A Bitcoin wallet will store the private keys that give access to the user’s Bitcoins and digitally sign with these keys transactions issued by the user. A Bitcoin wallet can either be an app, a web application or a dedicated device. 

The goal of this project is to analyse the security of one (or more) software wallets. The student will try to find vulnerabilities in it. The project will be judged based on the vulnerabilities found, so there is no guarantee of success with this project (as with any other attack-oriented). The considered software wallet(s) may prove to be very secure, and the student might end up finding no vulnerabilities. However, if the student has an interesting approach to looking for vulnerabilities, or provides a formal proof of the security of the wallet, then this will also be a successful project even without finding real vulnerabilities.
goal: Analyse the security of a software Bitcoin wallet
completion_criteria: Thorough analysis of the security and privacy guarantees of one or more software Bitcoin wallets

title: Sentiment Analysis from Twitter and Microblog Data
description:
Microblogging is prevalent in today's social media. People share their sentiment and opinions about products, events and organisations in a large mass. The goal of this project is to build a sentiment analysis system for Twitter data and other microblogs.

The system will not only use the microblog text itself to do the classification into sentiment, but is also required to follow "links" into articles and pages that are linked from the main microblog text to assist in the classification into sentiment.

There will be two domains for which the system will be developed: (1) the financial domain (information about companies); (2) the domain of news events (mostly political).

This project will also require annotating small amounts of data with their sentiment. The annotation is expected to be quick and should not be a major part of the project. The final output of this project should be an interface to classify tweets into their sentiment according to guidelines that will be provided by the project specification.
goal: To develop a sentiment analysis corpus and classifier for twitter data
completion_criteria: Development of a sentiment analysis corpus and a sentiment analysis classifier.

title: Exploring Euler's Foundations of Differential Calculus in Isabelle/HOL using nonstandard analysis
description:
In the first part of his book Institutiones Calculi Differentialis (Foundations of Differential Calculus), first published in 1755, Euler discusses the theory of differential calculus. He introduces the notions of first and higher order increments (for variables), called differences, which he then extends to differentials ("infinitely small" increments) and uses to examine changes in functions when their variables are increased or decreased. Through deft manipulations (such as the division of infinitely small quantities) and intuition, he obtains many interesting results about derivatives of functions (e.g. trigonometric functions represented as power series) that most modern mathematicians would frown upon and regard as lacking rigour (or even view as being careless but lucky).

The aim of this project is to produce an historical, machine-driven investigation of some of the concepts and reasoning introduced in (the translated version of) Euler's book by formalising them in the proof assistant Isabelle. Formal notions of infinitely large and infinitely small (infinitesimal) numbers will be introduced using nonstandard analysis, which is available as a library in Isabelle. 

This formalisation will require clarifying potential ambiguities not only in Euler's original text but possibly in the translation. Anyone interested in this project must be very comfortable with logic and formal reasoning. Existing experience with a proof assistant (preferably Isabelle) is a must. 

Note: Any interested student must discuss the project with the supervisor in order to be considered for it.
goal: Investigate, represent and formalise Euler's reasoning about differential calculus formally using Isabelle/NSA
completion_criteria: Representation of the notion of orders and formalisation of a substantial part (if not all) of the paper.

title: Extending a social, open, peer review web platform
description:
The aim of this project is to extend a platform, developed as part of a UG4 project in 17/18 [5], that aims to allow researchers to register and submit their papers (e.g. pre-prints), and then receive feedback/reviews from other registered users. 

The web platform is built around the publishing capabilities of WordPress, the comment features of BBPress and the social network capabilities of Buddypress. It currently allows a registered user to publish and tag PDF documents, and for comments/reviews to be added and rated. By the end of the current UG4 project it should also allow users to rate the reviews/feedback and thus potentially provide a means of building a reputation system for reviewers too  (but the extent to which this can be done will be assessed at the start of this new project). 

Other aspects that are specific to paper reviewing (e.g. self-assessment of confidence by reviewers and their expertise, possibly curated directly from their user profiles) will need to be incorporated. Existing systems such as arXiv, Easychair and OpenReview.net can be used to work out further requirements for such as platform. 

Note: This project is marked as easy but could become hard if sophisticated functionalities are considered. It will require becoming familiar with plugin (and, probably, theme) design and development for Wordpress. Also, an understanding of the graph theoretical concepts for reasoning about social networks will be need to be acquired. Any interested student must discuss the project with the supervisor in order to be considered for it.
goal: Designing and implementing further features for a Wordpress-based peer review platform with social networking aspects
completion_criteria: A prototype, web platform using Wordpress/Buddypress that enables open reviews of papers based on the usual peer-review criteria.

title: Algorithmic Patterns and High-Performance Code Generation for GPUs with Lift
description:
Lift is a novel intermediate language for expressing data-parallelism developed in Edinburgh. The language is based on a small set of primitives such as map, zip, reduce, and is mainly based on lambda-calculus. The language has been designed to enable the generation of high-performance GPU code.

In this project we will focus on one or more high-level algorithmic patterns commonly found in functional programming (e.g. scan, filter). We will investigate how they can be efficiently compiled and executed on parallel devices such as GPUs. The Lift language and the Lift OpenCL compiler backend will then be extended to support the new primitives on the GPU.

Depending on the student interest, we might look at different classes of algorithms (divide-and-conquer, fixed-point, stencil, ...). We will explore how a parallel implementation can be automatically derived from a high-level functional description of the algorithm. A prototype code generator will be implemented within our existing compiler framework developed in-house (written in Scala).This project will be the opportunity to learn more about parallel programming, compilers and the application of functional principles for exploiting parallelism.
goal: Develop and explore new algorithmic patterns that are amenable to high-performance code generation on GPUs
completion_criteria: Augment our current GPU code generator to support a new range of algorithmic patterns

title: Batching strategies and balancing for recurrent neural network training
description:
Neural network training uses batches: a bunch of training examples are processed at once.  This makes more parallel use of a GPU. Ideally, batches should have examples of the same size (so no computation is wasted) and as large as possible subject to GPU memory constraints.  However, many natural language processing applications use sentences for training.  And sentences have variable length. 

A simple baseline is sorting sentences by length.  So sentences of length 1, 2, 2, and 4 might go into the same batch while another batch has sentences of length 5 and 6.  Since each batch rounds up its computation to the longest sentence in the batch, this arrangement minimizes for a system that takes in one sentence on one GPU. 

In machine translation, the problem is even worse because training examples are a pair of sentences, one in the source language and one in the target language.  So now we have two dimensions on which to form batches.  This becomes an optimization problem. 

But then it gets more interested when we have multiple GPUs.  If the GPUs are run synchronously, then we have to wait for the slowest one each time.  How do you select batches that will take approximately the same time?  A simple way we currently use is just do batches of about the same length.  But what if we knew that 20 sentences with source language length 6 and target language length 7 took about the same time as 12 sentences with source language length 13 and target language length 11?  Then we could run both on two different GPUs and expect they'd finish at the same time.  

A rough outline of how you might do the project:

  1. Gather speed and memory usage data by running batches with various sizes​
  2. Model performance so you can predict how long things will take
  3. Develop an optimizer that decides what sentences to batch and when
  4. Optionally, address the multi-GPU case
  5. Measure how well your batching strategy works in practice


No neural network knowledge needed.
goal: Make training faster by modeling time taken and creating batching strategies
completion_criteria: Devised two or more batching strategies and measured their impact on performance.

title: Mobile measurement of urban interference and spectrum utilisation patterns
description: Coverage or signal strength allows inferring mobile performance only at lightly loaded network conditions. More commonly, the extent and nature of network load (in terms of number of users, their distribution and service requirements) play a vital role in determining user-perceived mobile performance. This can be better understood via more detailed characterization of interference in realistic and challenging mobile network scenarios as in dense urban areas. Increasing density of mobile infrastructure with small cells and the greater heterogeneity of cell types (macro, pico, femto, etc.) as well as impending use of unlicensed spectrum by mobile networks makes interference a bigger and complex concern. With this in mind, the goal of this project is to conduct a measurement study in Edinburgh using commodity Android smartphones augmented with spectrum analyser capability and leveraging the mobility of public transport vehicles.
goal: Measurement based characterization of interference and spectrum usage in dense urban areas
completion_criteria: Spectrum measurement methdology design, measurement collection and analysis of data to draw insights.

title: Data Analysis for Large Social Networks (Variable difficulty)
description:
Network science is the study of large graphs or networks. Networks appear in almost all domains, for example: social networks, biological networks, economic or financial networks, world wide web and Internet, as well as networks of computers, scientists, movie actors etc. Thus, networks are fundamental to datascience, and are intimately connected with most areas of computer science including algorithms, machine learning, IoT and computer systems. In this project you have the freedom to work on any aspect of network analysis according to your interest, and combine with ideas from your favourite subjects.

An honours project requires study of background material and some preliminary investigation to define exactly what to do in the project and how. In this case, we will cover these aspects in the course Social and Technological networks. Thus, you will be able to use your knowledge from the course as your background for your project. The course involves a small project, which will let you gain a better handle on your area of interest and relevant techniques.

This structure of the project gives you an opportunity to make a more informed decision on the topic of your project. As you gain more knowledge during the course, you will be better equipped to define and conduct an interesting and original project of your choice, with help from the supervisor. The project will analyse network data from some particular domain to develop insights and analytic methods suitable for the area.

The STN course involves mathematical and probabilistic analysis of networks. You may want to look at the materials of the course here: http://www.inf.ed.ac.uk/teaching/courses/stn/files1718/lectures.html
The introduction slides give an overview of the course and network science: http://www.inf.ed.ac.uk/teaching/courses/stn/files1718/slides/intro.pptx.pdf

Next year the course will be revised to include more material on computation, and machine learning for network analysis.

Some typical types of projects can be, to analyse particular network datasets to develop insights and techniques, for example, from:
* Social networks
* Scientific collaboration networks
* Road networks
* Linguistic networks
* Biological networks
* etc..


Students should contact the lecturer.
goal: Analyse network datasets for a particular domain to develop insights and techniques
completion_criteria: Analyse a network dataset. Find some properties that can be used to extract non-trivial insights in general from such datasets. Write a software to do this in general for such data.

title: Linking a rigorous C interpreter to compiled C libraries
description:
The C programming language is widely used for systems programming but suffers from large areas of undefined behaviour, such as using memory after freeing it. These are important for compiler optimisations, but can be tricky for programmers to spot and easy to accidentally invoke. This can lead to programs with subtle security vulnerabilities, or that exhibit different bugs depending on the precise compiler used.

Research work on formal verification has led to the development of precise descriptions of C, several of which can also be used as very strict C interpreters. By running a C program in one of these interpreters most occurrences of undefined behaviour can be detected automatically. However, they can only run the C source code they are given, and cannot use precompiled libraries.

This project would add the ability to call some library code from one of these interpreters to allow more realistic C programs to be tested by them. The main challenge would be to translate between the interpreter's abstract representation of memory and the concrete memory used by compiled C.  The difficulty of the project would depend on the approach chosen — more ambitious methods will be able to handle a larger range of programs.

Note that you would not need to work in the theorem provers that the descriptions of C were originally produced in; instead you would be working with the interpreters derived from them, which are in the OCaml programming language, and in C.
goal: Extending an existing strict C interpreter with the ability to call compiled C library code
completion_criteria: The ability to run a selection of example C programs in an interpreter using (for example) functions from the C standard library, including some which demonstrate the detection of undefined behaviour.

title: Modelling processor errata
description:
Formal instruction set models are descriptions of the behaviour of processor instructions that are written in a high level language. Unlike traditional processor simulators, they emphasise clarity over execution speed. They are useful for proving properties of instruction sets (such as isolation properties of memory protection), software verification, processor hardware verification and experimenting with architectural changes.

However, despite extensive testing and validation efforts, processors still contain bugs, some of which are visible as malfunctioning instruction sequences which compilers have to avoid. For example, there were bugs in the ARM Cortex-A53 design that are serious enough that compilers such as GCC had to alter the code they generate.

This project is to add specifications for some errata to a processor model and explore possible applications of the extended model. A simple example would be to show that using the model as a simulator detects unsafe code. A more ambitious example would be to show that the extended model can be used in software verification.
goal: Incorporate processor errata into a formal instruction set model and demonstrate erroneous behaviour
completion_criteria: Implementation of errata in a model; demonstration of applications of errata modelling.

title: Chase Termination for Linear Existential Rules
description: The chase procedure is considered as one of the most fundamental algorithmic tools in database theory. It takes as input a relational database D, and a set of existential rules (a.k.a. tuple-generating dependencies) R, and it constructs a (possibly infinite) instance J that satisfies R. The chase procedure has been successfully applied to different database problems such as data exchange, and query answering and containment under constraints, to name a few. One of the central problems regarding the chase procedure is all-instances termination, that is, given a set of existential rules R, decide whether the chase under R terminates, for every input database. It is known that this problem is, in general, undecidable [1]. However, it has been shown that for some special classes of existential rules, the above problem is decidable [2]. More precisely, if we focus on linear existential rules, a central class of existential rules with several applications, the problem is NL-complete (assuming predicates of bounded arity). The algorithm for establishing the NL upper bound relies on a graph-based syntactic characterization of the fragment of linear existential rules that guarantees the termination of the chase. The goal of this project is to provide an effective implementation of the chase termination algorithm in question.
goal: Implementation of a graph-based algorithm for deciding whether the chase algorithm terminates under a set of linear existential rules
completion_criteria: 1. An effective implementation of the chase termination algorithm for linear existential rules.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               +
2. Experimental evaluation of the implemented algorithm.

title: Formalizing dual numbers and notions of automatic differentiation in Isabelle/HOL
description:
Dual numbers [1,2] extend the real numbers by adjoining a new element ɛ such that ɛ*ɛ=0, in a similar way that complex numbers adjoin the imaginary unit i with the property i*i=-1. So the typical representation of a dual number takes the form x+y*ɛ, where x and y are real numbers, sometimes called the real and dual parts respectively.

These numbers find application in a number of areas ranging from algebraic and differential geometry, where they can be viewed as angles between lines, to machine learning [2] as they naturally lead to a forward mode of automatic differentiation whereby they can be used to compute a function evaluation and its first derivative simultaneously. 

The aim of this project is to formalise the notion of dual numbers and various mathematical operations on them in the proof assistant Isabelle/HOL. The latter range from basic arithmetic (such as addition and multiplication) to more complex ones such as exponentiation and trigonometric functions. Time permitting, more advanced notions related to the verification of machine learning algorithms may be explored. 

Note: Any interested student must discuss the project with the supervisor in order to be considered for it.
goal: Formalise dual numbers and their associated mathematical properties
completion_criteria: A formalized theory of dual numbers, with definitions of arithmetic and "higher" operations on them along with proofs of their properties.

title: Enhancing a theorem prover for cyber-physical systems
description:
Cyber-physical systems are systems which involve computational elements interacting with the physical world in real time. Cyber-physical systems are ubiquitous in society today and our safety frequently depends on them. Examples include all kinds of transport systems (cars, boats, trains, planes, spacecraft), robots, chemical plants, and medical devices (e.g. heart pace-makers and life-support systems).There has been significant research interest recently in developing formal verification techniques than can be used to ensure safety and other desirable properties of cyber-physical systems. In formal verification we mathematically prove system correctness, soensuring higher degrees of confidence in a system than if we use testing or simulation-based verification approaches. One formal verification approach involves deductive reasoning in a special calculus of rules that are tailored to the characteristics of cyber physical systems. These rules allow one to reason about how some times the state of a cyber-physical system evolves continuously according to differential equations and other times switches between different modes. The aim of this project is to take aspects of work in a recently-completed Edinburgh PhD on enhancing the deductive rules [2,3] and implement them in a new interactive theorem prover KeYmaeraX [1] which is specifically designed for deductively verifying cyber-physical systems. Once implemented, the project could explore further improvements to these rules. KeYmaeraX is implemented in Scala and makes extensive use of the Mathematica computer algebra system to provide essential automation in support of some of the deduction rules. A student undertaking this project would have to work both in Scala and Mathematica. Any student interested in listing this project as one of their choices is strongly recommended to first meet with the proposer to discuss the project further and check if their background is appropriate.

A variation on this project is to explore realising the rules in implementations of the KeYmaeraX rule calculus in the Isabelle or Coq theorem prover [4]. 

This project could be undertaken by more than one student if each student were to choose a different prover.
goal: To implement and evaluate new rules for reasoning about cyber-physical systems in a deductive theorem proving framework
completion_criteria: An implementation of several enhanced rules\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +

An implementation of further improvements to one or more of these rules.\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +
An evaluation of the performance of the implemented rules.

title: Adding subtypes to a theorem prover language
description:
Theorem provers are computer systems that support the semi-automatic checking of logical and mathematical arguments. They find many uses, including the verification of hardware and software.For example, Intel and AMD uses theorem provers to verify all the floating-point microcode on their CPUs.The logic (HOL) used by theorem provers such as Isabelle/HOL provides a quite restricted language of types. For example, one has a type of natural numbers, but no type {i..j} of all numbers between i and j.It is desirable to have a more expressive type language to enable the more accurate and more concise statement of definitions and lemmas.Hurd has extended the HOL theorem prover to deal with predicate subtypes [1] which simulate a richer language of types some whatsimilar to that provided in the PVS system [3]. The aim of this project is to implement an analogous system for Isabelle/HOL, a related version of higher order logic implemented in the generic theorem prover Isabelle [2].This project will likely involve:

  • understanding the issues involved in providing predicate subtyping for HOL and Isabelle/HOL
  • gaining a thorough understanding of Hurd's work in HOL. In particular, the student will need to study and understand the various aspects of the formal framework (e.g. subtypes constructors and rules, subtype derivation algorithm etc.)
  • implementing a predicate subtyping package and integrating it into Isabelle/HOL. This will involve progamming in the SML functional language.
  • time permitting, investigating the usefulness of the package through a suitable case study.

A similar alternative project would involve the use of the HOL Light prover instead of Isabelle/HOL. The implementation here would likely be more straightforward, leaving more time for exploring extensions and carrying out a case study.
goal: To add PVS-style predicate subtyping to the Isabelle/HOL theorem prover
completion_criteria: Demonstration of a working predicate-subtyping package for Isabelle/HOL or HOL Light.

title: Examining security and privacy vulnerabilities of smart meter communications infrastructure
description: The UK government has mandated that every home gets a smart meter by 2020 in an effort to promote more awareness of household energy consumption among consumers, accurate billing, etc. This rollout of smart meters is currently underway. In recent years, the emergence of inexpensive and easy to use software defined radios (SDRs) have led to their use both for the creation of open mobile/wireless networks as well as to exploit the vulnerabilities of these networks. Given smart meter communications infrastructure is yet another wireless network, although specialized and composed of different wireless segments, the goal of this project is to leverage cheap software radios to assess the robustness of the smart meter communications infrastructure. This would involve devising ways to identify the wireless technology used in different segments and testing the vulnerability in those segments. This would then form the basis for analyzing privacy risks.
goal: Examine security and privacy vulnerabilities with current smart meter deployments with the aid of inexpensive software radios
completion_criteria: Develop an SDR platform to monitor smart meter communications and report on the vulnerability analysis of the smart meter communications infrastructure using it.

title: Pretty Printing for BNFC-meta
description:
BNFC-meta is a fantastic Haskell library written by Duregard and
Jansson. It exploits Template Haskell to embed BNF Converter
grammars, parsers, and printers in Haskell. The purpose of this
project is to extend BNFC-meta so that in addition to parsers (which
convert strings to internal trees) and printers (which convert
internal trees to strings) it also generates pretty printers (which
convert internal trees to strings with layout and indentation that
makes them easier to read). The project will build on both BNFC-meta
and Wadler's pretty-printing library. The result will be to extend
a widely used libary for Haskell to make it even more powerful,
a benefit to the world and a nice addition to the student's resume.
goal: Extend  BNFC-meta to support not only generation of parsers and printers but also of pretty printers.
completion_criteria: An updated, tested version of BNFC-meta, that can be installed with Hackage and Cabal.

title: A compiler for Links
description:
Links is a functional programming language for creating web applications. From a single source program Links produces JavaScript for the client, SQL for database access, and an interpreted intermediate language for the server.

Three previous student projects have implemented compilers that translate the Links intermediate language into either OCaml source code or, most recently, the OCaml backend. Alas, none of the existing compilers handles all of the features of Links.

The central aim of this project is to build a compiler that supports all Links features. The key challenges are fully supporting SQL generation and serialisation of code. SQL generation requires access to abstract syntax at run time in order to support query normalisation. Serialisation requires similar reflection facilities. A previous compiler implementation provided partial support for query normalisation by pairing up all run-time values (including functions) with a corresponding syntactic representation. For this project the task should in theory admit a cleaner implementation as Links now performs closure conversion, which means it should be sufficient to generate two versions of each top-level function.
goal: Implement a complete compiler for Links
completion_criteria: An implementation of a compiler for Links that supports all features including query compilation and serialisation of code.

title: Handling effects in WebAssembly
description:
WebAssembly is emerging as a fully formalised and portable
  compilation target for the Web. In contrast to JavaScript, it has
  been explicitly designed as a compilation target for other
  languages. It is being standardised by a team including
  representatives from Apple, Google, Microsoft, and
  Mozilla. Ultimately the WebAssembly team are committed to making it
  language agnostic, but presently it is skewed towards low-level
  programming languages like C. Correspondingly it lacks a number of
  low-level abstractions which would enable the efficient
  implementation of abstractions offered by high-level programming
  languages. The aim of this project is to add support for expressive
  control abstractions known as effect handlers, which generalise
  exception handlers, and can be used to implement a wide range of
  high-level abstractions including generators, asynchronous
  programming, and probabilistic programming.

  Effect handlers occupy a sweet spot in the design space of
  abstractions for effectful computation. By separating abstract
  effect signatures from their implementation, effect handlers provide
  a high degree of modularity, allowing programmers to express
  effectful programs independently of the concrete interpretation of
  their effects. An effect handler is an interpretation of the effects
  of an abstract computation. Effect handlers are steadily gaining
  popularity, being available in many functional programming languages
  either directly (e.g. in Eff, Frank, Koka, Links, and Multicore
  OCaml) or indirectly as a library (e.g. in F#, Haskell, Idris, and
  Scala).

  The aim of this project is to add effect handlers to the WebAssembly
  specification and implement them in the reference interpreter,
  providing an artefact which can ultimately influence the future
  direction of WebAssembly.
goal: Augment the WebAssembly specification and reference interpreter with effect handlers
completion_criteria: * A specification of effect handlers for WebAssembly                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          +
* A working implementation of effect handlers in the WebAssembly reference interpreter

title: A WebAssembly backend for Links
description:
WebAssembly is emerging as a fully formalised and portable
  compilation target for the Web. In contrast to JavaScript, it has
  been explicitly designed as a compilation target for other
  languages. It is being standardised by a team including
  representatives from Apple, Google, Microsoft, and Mozilla. Despite
  its name, WebAssembly is a not an assembly language in the
  traditional sense, rather, it is low-level bytecode that is run on
  top of a stack-machine. Ultimately the WebAssembly team are
  committed to making it language agnostic, but presently it is skewed
  towards low-level programming languages like C. The goal of this
  project is to compile a functional programming language to
  WebAssembly.

  Links is a functional programming language for creating web
  applications. From a single source program Links produces JavaScript
  for the client, SQL for database access, and an interpreted
  intermediate language for the server. The Links compiler already has
  much of the necessary infrastructure in place, including the
  JavaScript backend which can be used in conjunction with a potential
  WebAssembly backend to compile interesting web applications.

  The aim of this project is to implement and evaluate a WebAssembly
  backend for Links.
goal: Implemenent and evaluate WebAssembly backend for Links
completion_criteria: * A working implementation of a WebAssembly backend for Links                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +
* An evaluation of the implementation

title: A typed pay-it-forward Ðapp with smart contracts
description:
The Ethereum blockchain allows developers to publish code modules called contracts onto the Ethereum blockchain, allowing this code to be executed by anyone with an Ethereum address. The purpose of these contracts is to allow Ethereum users to make payments in the ether cryptocurrency to one another. Smart contracts are applications which are written in the Solidity programming language, which formalise the business logic of what sort of payments are made, and under what conditions. Solidity is a Turing-complete programming language, meaning that the business logic of a smart contract can be as complex as the developer wishes. Solidity can associate cryptocurrency costs with executing a function in a smart contract, thereby allowing the transfer of ether from one address to another, as payment for using the service which the function provides.

An Ethereum Ðapp (decentralised app) uses the web3.js JavaScript library to provide a front-end to a Solidity contract, meaning that developers can build web-based front ends which allow users to send information to, and receive information from, the blockchain.

One possible use of this technology is to implement a pay-it-forward system with typed currency, meaning constrained money which can only be spent when buying certain goods and services, unlike the unconstrained fiat currencies in general use today. One application of such a system would be to allow donors who use the ether cryptocurrency to make targeted charitable donations to a particular recipient, backed by the constraint that the money given will actually be spent for the purpose for which it was given, because it can neither be spent against type, nor converted into general-purpose currency. Donations may also be time-limited in that if they are not spent within a particular time horizon they may be returned to the donor, or transferred into a general typed account which is not associated with any specific recipient.  Other ideas could also be investigated, such as budget controls which prevent the recipients of donations from spending too much in a particular category too quickly.

The purpose of this project is to explore the viability of a pay-it-forward system with typed currency through the creation of a prototype Ðapp which implements the idea.
goal: To create a decentralised app to investigate the idea of a pay-it-forward system which uses typed currency.
completion_criteria: Produce a decentralised app as a prototype to explore the idea of a pay-it-forward system which uses typed currency.

title: A Parallel Approach to Maximum Clique Finding
description:
Graphs occur in many places in the real world and often contain interesting and useful information. However, there are some things that are very hard to find when performing analysis on graphs, NP-hard things. In particular, finding the maximum clique (the largest fully connected subgraph) of a graph or even just the size of that clique. Knowing the size of it and where it is located is useful in a diverse set of fields including in chemistry, bioinformatics, economics, mathematics, and of course computer science.

Most algorithms for finding maximum cliques rely on heuristics as well as branch-and-bound techniques. Work has been done in performing these tasks across a small number cores but the aim of this project is to develop a method which takes greater advantage of parallelization. This should be done with the intent being to target a graphics processing units (GPUs).
goal: Develop, implement, test, and analyze an algorithm which utilizes parallelization to efficiently find the maximal clique of a graph
completion_criteria: Full implementation of a maximum clique finding algorithm accompanied by testing and analysis of its performance

title: Self-tallying and coercion resistance in electronic voting
description:
Voting is a fundamental procedure in democratic societies. With the technological advances of the computer era, voting processes can also benefit to become more secure and efficient and as a result more democratic. Indeed, compared to previous manual procedures, electronic voting systems can offer more efficient elections with higher voter participation, better accuracy, while also providing higher security guarantees, such as vote-privacy and voter-verification even in the face of untrusted election authorities. For this reason, over the last two decades, several proposals of cryptographic protocols, such as Helios [1], JCJ/Civitas [2], Scantegrity [3], Demos [4], or Prêt-à-Voter [5] to name just a few, have been made and implemented for electronic voting.

An important requirement for voting schemes is coercion resistance. As informally explained in [6], "this would mean that a coercer, e.g., a vote buyer that offers a voter money in exchange of his vote for some candidate c, is not able to verify whether the voter indeed voted for c or for some other candidate. In other words, the voter cannot use his transcript as a receipt that he voted for c."
