In [7], the concept of self-tallying voting-scheme was introduced. Such schemes "allow any casual third party to perform the tally computation and in general the post-ballot-casting phase. Consequently, there are no authorities or voters involved in the post-election phase that becomes an open procedure. Self-tallying, suggests that the post-ballot-casting phase is an open procedure that can be performed by any interested (casual) third party."

The goal of this project is to rigorously investigate if self-tallying and coercion resistance are compatible properties. The student will either respond by the positive by exhibiting a self-tallying voting protocol that provably satisfies coercion resistance, or by the negative by mathematically proving that no self-tallying protocol can satisfy coercion resistance.
goal: The goal of this project is to rigorously investigate if self-tallying and coercion resistance are compatible properties
completion_criteria: 1. Review existing definitions of coercion resistance in voting                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               +

2. Formalise the class of self-tallying protocols                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +
3. Establish if self-tallying and coercion resistance are compatible properties

title: Graph Analytics on Many-Core Processors
description:
Graph analytics applications operating on large graph datasets suffer from poor cache locality caused by random memory access patterns over a vast memory space. Emerging many-core processors, such as the Intel Xeon Phi - Knight's Mill, IBM Power 8, and Oracle T5, offer many hardware threads, which is great for concurrency, but have limited cache capacity that limits performance due to frequent cache misses. 

This project will evaluate a contemporary graph analytics framework on one of the many-core processors listed above (Intel Xeon Phi would be a preferred choice) to understand the memory access patterns and how they affect performance. Based on the findings, an outstanding project will further propose and evaluate changes in the framework or graph dataset placement/partitioning with the aim of improving application performance. 

Update (Mar 16): due to the possibility of necessary hardware not being available, the project will not run.
goal: Evaluate and improve performance of graph analytics applications on a state-of-the-art many-core processor
completion_criteria: 1. Evaluate an existing graph analytics framework on a many-core processor and understand where the performance bottlenecks are.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              +
2. Investigate whether changes in the application and/or data placement can improve performance.

title: Object segmentation from satellite images with deep neural networks
description:
This project involves applying object segmentation[1] and detection [2] algorithms to satellite images. The goal of this project is to automatically learn to understand geological features such as flooding events, faulty scarps from satellite images by using standard computer vision techniques.

The project will require you to understand and implement a convolutional neural network in a deep learning environment (e.g. pytorch, tensorflow), to develop learning formulations and network architectures, and to assess the performance of your method in standard computer vision benchmarks.

Due to high interest in machine learning projects, one-to-one meeting is not feasible. Thus I will organise a group meeting towards the end of the student  selection period to discuss about the project details. If you like to contact me for the project, please use [UG4/MInf-project][Satellite] (with brackets) in your email.
goal: To learn to segment floodplains and earthquake fault lines from satellite images
completion_criteria: The project will require you to understand and implement a convolutional neural network in a deep learning environment (e.g. pytorch, tensorflow), to develop learning formulations and network architectures, and to assess the performance of your method in standard computer vision benchmarks.

title: Random generation of Ramanujan graphs
description:
Ramanujan Graphs, named after an Indian mathematician Ramanujan, are families of sparse graphs with the optimal expansion property. Since an expansion property relates to reliability of a network occurring in practice and sparsity corresponds to construction cost, explicit constructions of Ramanujan graphs have wide applications in network design. In a more theoretical side, a deterministic construction of Ramadan graphs is one of the major open questions in Theoretical Computer Science, and Discrete Mathematics.

In this project, we will study different randomised algorithms for constructing graphs with good expansion property. In particular, we will experimentally study how often a random Ramanujan graph is generated under different randomised construction algorithms.
goal: Experimental studies of the probability that a random graph is a Ramanujan graph
completion_criteria: Conclusive results by experiments about the occurrence of a random Ramanujan graphs under different constructions and constraints.

title: Learn to play Coup
description:
Coup is a card game where every player has two cards called 'influences'. Each influence gives the player a set of legal actions. Each turn a player can claim to have any influence (whether or not they actually have that influence) and use one of their legal actions. Other players can at that point choose to challenge that player claiming they do not have that influence. If the player challenged does not have the card they claimed then they must reveal one of their influences other wise the challenger must reveal one of theirs. Players lose when both their influences are turned over. The last player with at least one influence still not revealed wins.

More rules and card descriptions here:
https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/131357/coup

From the perspective of game theory, Coup is an extensive multi-agent game with incomplete information: you don't know your opponents' 'influences' and thus the game states are not fully observable.
Online learning of optimal policies is often tackled using a technique known as Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_tree_search), but the standard version of this only handles games where the states are fully observable.
There are two alternative extensions to MCTS that handle partially observable game states: one is developed by the PhD student Mihai Dobre (Belief MCTS or BMCTS) and the other is a more established technique known as Partial Observable Monte Carlo Planning (POMCP).
The task is to adapt an existing implementation of both of these models that is currently used to learn to play the board game Settlers of Catan and to test which method works best for learning to play Coup. A gaming environment for Coup will need to be developed as well.
goal: To implement a Coup playing environment, and to design, implement and evaluate an agent that learns to play it via online sampling methods
completion_criteria: Implemented gaming environment for playing Coup; implementation of heuristics-baesd agents (the baseline); implementation of POMCP and BMCTS for learning to play Coup, adapted from existing code; evaluation of these agents via game simulations.

title: A graphical playground for Haskell
description: Many systems contain support for users to interactively write programmes, keeping track of what they have created. The granddaddy of such systems is Notebooks in Mathematica. Other examples include the graphical facilities in Dr Racket, and Playgrounds in the recently released Haskell for Mac.\r +
goal: Build an interactive web site to aid programmers in trying out Haskell, especially interactive graphics.
completion_criteria: An implementation of a web service that allows users to type in Haskell expressions that denote pictures, and will display the result in HTML.

description: The goal of this project is to build a similar facility for Haskell, using a web browser as the graphical interface. It should be similar to the existing interactive facility at haskell.org (see where it says "Type Haskell expressions in here"), but also provide graphical primitives, as for Dr Racket (see the tutorial "Quick: An Introduction to Racket with Pictures"). The project may reuse the existing implementation from haskell.org, and combine it with an existing graphics library (adapted to produce graphics output in HTML).\r +
While not easy, this is a straightforward project that should lead to release of open-source software that can be used in education, and may lead to a publication in the Haskell Symposium.

title: Hardware-assisted debugging leveraging Intel Processor Trace (Intel PT)
description:
Wenever a system fails, it is important to understand the root cause behind the failure. If it is a software bug, then this bug needs to be identified and removed to prevent the observed failure from reoccurring. If it is a hardware problem or unexpected environmental condition, the probability of its reoccurrence needs to be assessed and, depending on whether this probability is considered acceptably low or not, counter-measures for handling the exceptional case may be added. The process of understanding the cause-effect chain in a system leading to a system failure is called *error propagation analysis (EPA)*.


EPA is commonly based on analyses of the execution trace of a failed execution, i.e. a record of the instructions that have been executed and on which data prior to the failure. To spot the point when an execution trace is deviating from a correct execution of the system, the failed execution trace is compared against a previously recorded execution that did not fail. This correct execution is called a golden run.


While such trace based error propagation analysis is effective, it has two important limitations. First, execution tracing incurs massive runtime overheads. In addition to their execution, each machine instruction needs to be logged to persistent storage. Second, execution traces are of limited utility for EPA of multithreaded programs, as scheduling non-determinism may cause trace deviations that are unrelated to the system failure.


This project addresses the two limitations by

1. applying Intel's PT ISA extensions for execution tracing and

2. utilizing static program analyses to differentiate valid from invalid permutations of trace instructions
goal: To design Intel Processor Trace (Intel PT) based Efficient Error Propagation Analyses
completion_criteria: To design and build a tool based on Intel PT for efficient EPA.

title: Triangulating Context Lemmas in the Coq Proof Assistant
description:
Recent work at Edinburgh on reasoning in programming languages has identified a novel triangulation method for proving results about when two programs have equivalent behaviour. Researchers conjecture that this method can be applied to a range of programming language features. The method has been validated by machine-checked proof in the Agda language, using a recently-developed type-and-scope-safe representation technique.

The Coq proof assistant is another widely-used system for machine-assisted proof. A research group in Saarbrücken have explored using this type-and-scope-safe representation in Coq, with a view to using it in the Autosubst reasoning framework.

The aim of this project is to model the triangulation method in Coq. The work from Saarbrüken seems a good place to start, with Autosubst and the type-and-scope-safe representation likely to play significant roles.

All of the background technology for this is described in recent research papers and there is considerable local expertise in this field here at Edinburgh. Building on this, there are many possible routes to take and a substantial part of the work will be to explore these choices and shape the details of final project objectives.

This is challenging work at the frontier of current research. It is an excellent match for the courses Automated Reasoning, Types and Semantics of Programming Languages and Formal Verification. Any student taking all three of those will be well-prepared for this project.
goal: Construct a Coq implementation of the triangulation method for proving context lemmas.
completion_criteria: Implementation in Coq of the triangulation proof method, or substantial components of it.

title: Using the Z3 Automated Theorem Prover for Constraint Solving in HOL4
description:
Z3 is powerful automated theorem prover from Microsoft Research that given a set of mathematical constraints will attempt to either find a solution or show that no solution is possible. The language of constraints includes first-order logic and theories such as arithmetic and reasoning about arrays.

HOL4 is an interactive theorem prover, used to assist humans in the correct construction of complex mathematical proofs. HOL4 has some support for using Z3 to prove theorems, principally by refuting the statement that a theorem is false. This project would extend that support to use Z3's ability to find solutions to constraints and pass those into HOL4 theorems.

This project is an excellent match for the Honours courses in Automated Reasoning and Formal Verification and would suit students taking either or both of these.

The project supports current research at Edinburgh in validating HOL4 models of processor instruction sets, where we need to solve a set of constraints to identify test programs that will run to completion. Currently we use an older competitor to Z3, Yices 1, and on completing support for Z3 there would be an opportunity to compare the behaviour of the two provers.

In addition, as Z3 uses the standard SMT-LIB format for input, this project could also explore use of other automated provers (collectively known as SMT Solvers).
goal: Extend the existing HOL4 support for Z3 to find solutions, not just refutations.
completion_criteria: Demonstrating the round trip from HOL4 to constraint solving in Z3 and translation of solutions back into HOL4.

title: Translation of Instruction Set Architecture Models
description:
High quality instruction set models are important for a range of tasks, such as evaluating architectural design choices and verifying software. However, the languages for these models (often called Architecture Description Languages) have not been standardised. Different groups use different languages, and architectural manuals tend to use informal pseudo-code.

This project is to develop automatic translation between two modelling languages: ArchC used by the systems research group in Edinburgh in the creation of high performance simulators, and the Sail language also used in Edinburgh but for formal verification and processor testing.

Both languages are domain specific — that is, they are specialised to describing instruction sets, with features to handle the processor state and identify the code responsible for particular instructions. A crucial part of the project would be to both preserve most of this structure and to use it to simplify the translation.
goal: Develop an automated translation between two different languages used to describe processor instruction set architectures
completion_criteria: Identification of an appropriate subset of the languages to translate; choice of a direction for translation; and an implementation of that translation for some code.

title: Randomised Testing of an Embedded Microprocessor
description:
As part of a continuing research project on verification of embedded systems, we are evaluating mathematical models of the ARM Cortex-M0 microcontroller and an experimental MIPS processor hosted in the HOL4 proof assistant. These can be used to check the correctness of machine code: but to be certain that this verified code will work correctly, we need to know that the processor model matches real chips.

So far we have validated the model using short randomly-chosen instruction runs. This requires choosing a starting state for registers and memory such that code will execute safely. We are able to do this using an automatic constraint solver (specifically, the Yices SMT solver) but this generates very stylised states — for example, it will usually reuse a memory location rather than pick a new one.

The aim of this project is to investigate methods for generating a large set of appropriate initial states for testing. One approach would be to generate extra constraints to force the solver to pick different solutions. A more ambitious direction would be to try and find a way to generate more variation in states while respecting the existing constraints.

This project is an excellent match for the courses Automated Reasoning and Formal Verification and would suit students taking either or both of these.
goal: Improve randomised testing of a formal model of the ARM Cortex-M0 microcontroller by exploring a larger state-space.
completion_criteria: Proposal and implementation of a method to generate a wider range of initial system states.

title: Machine Formalisation of a Biochemical Process Language
description:
The Continuous pi-Calculus (c-pi) is a process algebra for modelling behaviour and variation in biochemical systems. Essentially, it is a declarative concurrent programming language to describe interacting processes from molecular biology. Key features are its expressive succinctness; a dynamic communication topology between process elements; and a mathematical semantics in ordinary differential equations (ODEs).

There is an accompanying Logic of Behaviour in Context (LBC) which expresses possible properties of these processes as they react over time. Once a biological system has a description in c-pi it is possible to automatically check whether or not it exhibits those properties: applying the technique of model-checking from hardware and software verification to investigate biochemistry.

This calculus and logic are the subject of current research in Edinburgh, with examples from systems biology and tools for simulation and analysis.

At present, continuous pi and LBC have implementations in tools, and mathematical descriptions with pencil and paper. The goal of this project is to formalise and check this pencil-and-paper semantics in an appropriate proof assistant.

There are several possible choices for proof assistant, ranging from traditional proof-oriented systems like HOL, Isabelle and Coq, through to ones like Agda or Idris which are closer to general-purpose programming languages. Modelling continuous pi requires a mix of features — structural operational semantics, named communication channels, real-valued arithmetic, and ordinary differential equations — which will make an interesting combination for any of these proof assistants.

The basic objective of the project will be to build a formal model of continuous pi-calculus terms and their execution. More advanced objectives would be to prove lemmas about the formalised system, to additionally model the Logic of Behaviour in Context, or to prove properties of specific examples of biological systems encoded in continuous pi.

This project would suit students who have taken some or all of the courses Automated Reasoning, Types and Semantics for Programming Language, and Formal Verification.
goal: Build a machine-checked formalisation of the Continuous pi-Calculus, a concurrent language for modelling biochemical systems.
completion_criteria: A machine formalisation of continuous pi-calculus terms and some property of their semantics.

title: Verifying Transformations of Functional Programs
description:
Compilers often carry many successive transformations of program code as they work to generate a target executable. For example, the CakeML verified compiler makes a series of 38 code transformations on the way from ML source code to machine code binaries. Many of these transformations involve terms with variable binding or some kind of lambda-abstraction: these can be challenging to work with as they do not fit the classic algebraic datatypes.

One method to reason about systems with binding is the type-and-scope-safe representation of Allais, Chapman, McBride and McKinna [1]. Introduced last year, it gives a straightforward way to model such systems and carry out machine-assisted proofs about them. For example, it was used earlier this year to verify the triangulation proof method [3] that is the topic of project 2874.

This project is to explore the effectiveness type-and-scope-safe methods for verifying transformations used in compiling of functional languages. This will probably be done in the dependently-typed Agda language [4]. A paper by Wang and Nadathur [2] carries out a similar exploration for techniques based on higher-order abstract syntax: they examine typed closure conversion, code hoisting, and transformation to continuation-passing style.

This is challenging work at the frontier of current research. It is an excellent match for the courses Automated Reasoning, Types and Semantics of Programming Languages and Formal Verification. Any student taking all three of those will be well-prepared for this project.
goal: Model and verify transformations of functional programs using the type-and-scope-safe representation method.
completion_criteria: Implementation in Agda of a compiler transformation using the type-and-scope-safe representation method.

title: Hiearchical Attack Trees
description:
Attack trees are a simple notion used for threat modelling.  A basic attack tree is an AND-OR tree whose root is the goal of an attacker.  The attack is decomposed into steps which must (AND nodes), or may as alternatives (OR nodes), be carried out to achieve the attack.  The leaves are actions that may help lead to an attack.  Edges in an attack tree can be labelled with probabilities or costs, to reflect risk modeling.

Various extensions of attack trees have been studied in the academic literature, for example, modelling defences as well as attacks, and distinguishing between steps which must be carried out in order from those that can occur in any order.  But so far the real-world use of these extensions has been limited; current commercial tools used in industry present a more spreadsheet-oriented view, losing the rich semantic information about the structure of attacks.

The aim of this project is to:

  • study a new modular structuring notion, which may help build larger and more realistic attack trees, and
  • extend the research prototype tool ADtool, to add hierarchical modules

The notion of hiearchical attack tree is being developed in ongoing research.  The idea of this project is to work with the researchers to help evaluate the design of hiearachical attack trees, by implementing an extension to ADtool, a graphical modelling tool implemented in Java, to add modules (boxes around subtrees), so large trees can be broken up into pieces, possibly recursively (nested modules).  The user of the tool should be able to zoom into and out of boxes, or fold/unfold them.

For a student interested in theoretical foundations, there may also be a chance to contribute to the development of the underlying theory of the tool (which would extend the difficulty to Hard/Challenging).   The underlying theory is being developed by combining the approaches mentioned in the academic papers cited on hiearchical proof trees [2] and attack trees with sequencing [3].   Understanding these papers completely is not needed for the programming-only version of this project.

IMPORTANT NOTE: Please register interest in this project early. If there are interested students I will arrange a group discussion, before the selection deadline.
goal: Study Attack Trees with nested modules, extend a Java-based modeling tool to implement modules and zooming
completion_criteria: An extension of ADtool which implements operations to "box" a collection of nodes, and allows "zooming" in and out by opening/collapsing the box.

title: Learning word embeddings for autocompletion of computer programs
description:
*Please note*: I am away from Edinburgh this semester, so I cannot meet to discuss the project. I will be happy to answer questions over email.

You'll know from your coursework that writing code is time consuming and error-prone. This is true in industry as well. You'll also know that there are hundreds of millions of lines of high-quality source code available online. Can we apply machine learning to all of this code to make software development easier?


This project concerns autocompletion, which is when your development environment automatically suggests what token you should type next


based on the first few characters, and perhaps some surrounding context. We would like to improve autocompletion systems by training machine learning methods on large corpora of code that has already been written.



Word embeddings, like word2vec, are an important technology in deep learning for text. They aim to map words to a continuous space in a way that nearby words in the continuous space are likely to appear in a similar sentences.



The goal of this project is to use the FastText system from Facebook to learn word embeddings for computer programs. Then we would like to evaluate if these embeddings can be used for autocompletion, that is, given the embeddings from the previous few tokens, can we predict the embedding of the next token. The hope is that a system based on word embeddings will be much faster than one based on more heavyweight technologies like recurrent neural networks.



FastText: [fastText](https://fasttext.cc/)



Learning from Examples to Improve Code Completion Systems: http://www.monperrus.net/martin/Learning-from-Examples-to-Improve-Code-Completion-Systems.pdf



[Naturalize](http://groups.inf.ed.ac.uk/naturalize/)
goal: Develop a machine learning system that could be used to make suggestions to software developers
completion_criteria: Develop a system for making suggestions and evaluate its effectiveness in a "synthetic" evaluation by replaying existing code. It's perfectly fine simply to build and evaluate the suggestion engine in isolation without attempting to integrate it into a real IDE. Both building and integrating to engine is too much work for a single project.

title: Deep learning to automatically write computer programs
description:
*Please note*: I am away from Edinburgh this semester, so I cannot meet to discuss the project. I will be happy to answer questions over email.

You'll know from your coursework that writing code is time consuming and error-prone. This is true in industry as well. You'll also know that there are hundreds of millions of lines of high-quality source code available online. Can we apply machine learning to all of this code to make software development easier?

The idea behind this project is to try to reduce the number of tokens that a programmer has to type in order to make clear to a computer what program that a developer has in mind.

For example, if a programmer types in this to a Java editor

```
Object[] reverse(Object[] array) {
 new Object[] out
 for i out out = array length - return
}
```

Can we make a machine learning system that will output a function to reverse an array?

```
Object[] reverse(Object[] array) {
    Object[] out = new Object[array.length];
    for (int i = 0; i < array.length; i++) {
              out[i] = array[array.length - i];
  }
  return out;
}
```

The idea will be to build a system based on deep learning. We have obtained a corpora of code from Github in several languages, such as Python and Java. Then you can train a neural language model on this corpus, such as a character level LSTM.

This model will let you generate random code. Then the harder part of the project will be to implement a search procedure, like A* search, that will output the highest probability string that contains all of the tokens that the user has typed.

An exciting application of this might to help software developers who have disabilities that make it difficult for them to use traditional IDEs. This could allow such developers to write more code with less keyboard or voice input.

References:

[1502.01410 A Study of "Wheat" and "Chaff" in Source Code](https://arxiv.org/abs/1502.01410). Martin Velez, Dong Qiu, You Zhou, Earl T. Barr, Zhendong Su. arXiv preprint 1502.01410.

Andrej Karpathy. [The Unreasonable Effectiveness of Recurrent Neural Networks](http://karpathy.github.io/2015/05/21/rnn-effectiveness/)
goal: Build a system that automatically guesses the code of a function based on a small number of tokens
completion_criteria: Building an evaluating a system for the above.

title: Understanding the "change history" of Wikipedia Infoboxes
description:
Everyone will be aware that the evolution of the Wikipedia site is the common effort of global annotators, and that anyone has edit permission for Wikipedia pages.  This crowdsourced project had a powerful influence of the availability of general knowledge round the world.    

This project is a data-driven project based on a public dataset containing the edit history of 1.8 million infoboxes in Wikipedia pages. These are the structured set of information on the top right of Wikipedia pages in many popular categories. Attributes on Wikipedia change over time, and some of them change more than others. Understanding attribute change is important for extracting accurate and useful information from Wikipedia.  

In this project, we will take an ML approach to understand patterns of attribute-change, based on temporal, geographic, and other features of the data. The initial stage of the project will involve understanding the data and setting some hypothesis and objectives; then we will apply ML methods to learn from the data.   Some suggestions that have been made for predictive tasks (for this dataset) include predicting which data items are most likely to be updated (based on the "category" of the page, the record key, the last update, etc.  This potentially has the application of alerting Wikipedia editors to data items that may need updating soon, or alternatively to alert an editor that another user has made a suspicious revision to data items usually stable over time (there is a real-life example here).  There have been suggestions of applying time-series analysis, but I'm open to a variety of Machine Learning techniques.  

The data set (in json) itself can be found at the following internal link /afs/inf.ed.ac.uk/group/ANC/IRDS/miniproject-data/wikipedia-changes

It is 126Gb so make sure you have adequate space (and bandwidth) before thinking of copying it.

This project is listed as easy, but can certainly be made more challenging than that if the right student wants to do that.
goal: To apply ML techniques to learn temporal and geographical patterns in the Infoboxes of Wikipedia pages
completion_criteria: To develop a couple of precise objectives for prediction/learning problems on this data set, then apply various ML techniques and evaluate their effectiveness.

title: Hardware-assisted memory safety
description:
In this project, we will investigate the design of a hardware-assisted memory safety approach for unsafe languages such as C/C++.

Memory safety issues, such as buffer overflows, are the root cause of most security and reliability problems in the traditional software systems stack. The state-of-the-art software-based memory safety approaches, such as AddressSantinzer, SoftBounds, etc. have not been adopted in practice because of the high overheads. 

To overcome the limitations of software-based approaches, Intel recently introduced hardware extensions for memory safety, namely, Intel Memory Protection Extensions (Intel MPX). However, we found that Intel MPX fails to improve performance overheads. 


In this project, we wish to investigate an alternative design for memory safety by leveraging the concept of tagged pointers, and wide 128-bit registers (similar to SGXBounds). The project will entail to build the entire software stack (the hardware extensions, compiler and operating system support).
goal: To design hardware support for enforcing memory safety for unsafe languages C/C++
completion_criteria: To build the entire software stack (hardware, compiler and OS support) for enforcing memory safety.

title: Next Generation Onionoo Service
description:
Onionoo is a web-based protocol to learn about currently running  Tor relays and bridges. Onionoo itself was not designed as a service for human beings—at least not directly. Onionoo provides the data for other applications and websites which in turn present Tor network status information to humans.[1]

The Onionoo service currently requests Tor relay data from the CollecTor[2] and makes it available via a (public facing) REST API. This API is used, for example, by Tor Metrics[3]. It does this by dumping the jsonified data onto disk and serving it when requested. Therefore, only the most recent descriptor data is available. This is a very unelegant solution.

The core goal of this project is to introduce a proper database backend that will also hold historical data. This will enable "time travel" (eg. What did the descriptor data look like at time X?) as well as better support for aggregated searches.
goal: To port the Tor Project's Onionoo Service and add a proper database backend and "time travel"
completion_criteria: MVP:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          +

Summary and Details API                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       +

Completion:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   +

All API frontends implemented, time travel proof of concept                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   +

Stretch Goal:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +
Derive guard, middle and exit probabilities from consensus weight fraction and other variables, Implementation of Time-Travelling into Metrics frontend.

title: Exploring visual processing using a convolutional neural network
description: The human visual system is characterized by its division and its vertical axis of symmetry. The left half of the visual hemifield is initially and exclusively projected to the right hemisphere of the brain, and conversely for the right visual field and left hemisphere. This division of the brain is arguably the central characteristic that generates the development of human cognition, if we take it that each hemisphere learns to 'second-guess' the activity of the other hemisphere. The current project has as its background this extensive psychological claim about the nature of human cognition. In this project we will use a divided architecture based on a convolutional neural network (see Zhang et al. 2016). The general principle is to require the one half of the model to predict the processing going on in the other half of the model. There are various ways of doing this, such as requiring one visual channel (e.g the processing of the greyscale version of the image) to predict the processing of another channel (e.g the processing of the colour version of the image), or such as requiring the processing of the contents of one visual hemifield to make predictions about the processing of the contents of the other visual hemifield. Our goal in the project is to select some aspect of human visual processing of some genre of images (e.g. faces, outdoor scenes, texts, etc) and to model the relevant behaviours.
goal: The goal is to model some aspect fo human visual processing using a particular divided processing architecture
completion_criteria: (1) To have characterized the human behavioural data from the relevant psychological literature.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              +

(2) To have created a training set for use with a version of a split CNN architecture.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        +
(3) To have compared the behaviours of the model with the relevant human behaviours.

title: Implementation of Parallel Skeletons in Rust
description:
Writing parallel programs which are correct and efficient is widely
acknowledged to be a challenging task. The use of parallel algorithmic
patterns (or “skeletons”) to abstract and simplify this challenge is
growing in popularity. Each pattern captures the core structure of a
class of parallel algorithms in the form of a higher-level function or
a type. The programmer provides argument for specialization of the
pattern to a particular use case, which the library then optimizes and
executes.

The goal of this project is to design and implement additions to the
Rust open-source library ecosystem which provide parallel skeleton
functionality. The language's safety guarantees will make sure that
any code executed by the library will not have memory errors. The
library's performance should then be measured and analysed.
goal: To build and evaluate the performance of a Rust skeleton-based parallel programming library.
completion_criteria: A basic completion would involve a simple library, with at least one skeleton-oriented bulk data type, two or three of the classic skeletons, some examples of these in action, and a parallelized implementation which achieves modest speed-ups on multicore DICE lab hardware.

title: Using reinforcement learning to train a team for RoboCup 2D Half Field Offense
description:
A second group meeting for this project will take place on Wednesday 4 April at 2pm in room 2.06, Informatics Forum.

Note to interested students: There will be a group meeting for this project during which interested students can ask questions. The meeting will take place on Thursday 15 March at 10am in room 2.06, Informatics Forum.

The RoboCup 2D simulation domain is a widely used platform for research in AI, machine learning, and multi-agent systems. Half Field Offense (HFO) is a tub-task of the full domain which uses half of the playing field and focuses on the task of controlling an offence team that is trying to score a goal agains a defence team. A paper by Hausknecht et al. describes an open-source framework for HFO which can be used to experiment in this domain.

In this project, the goal is to design and train a team of offence players in HFO using reinforcement learning techniques, and to evaluate the team's performance in simulations. This involves the following tasks:

  1. Familiarise yourself with the HFO framework
  2. Specify a set of defence behaviours (some default behaviours are provided in the framework)
  3. ​Specify one or more learning algorithms to train the agents in the offence team
  4. Implement and train your algorithms in the HFO framework
  5. Evaluate your trained team in HFO simulations

The choice of reinforcement learning algorithms is flexible and may include methods based on hierarchical learning and deep learning. The challenge is how to apply these algorithms to learn effective policies for the offence team.
goal: To design, train, and evaluate a reinforcement learning team for the Half Field Offense domain
completion_criteria: At a minimum:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +

- Specify a set of defence behaviours                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         +

- ​Specify learning algorithms to train the agents in the offence team                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         +

- Implement and train your algorithms in the HFO framework                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +
- Evaluate your trained team in HFO simulations

title: Machine Learning Algorithms for Analysis of Social and Technological Networks
description:
Network science is the study of large graphs or networks. Networks appear in almost all domains, for example: social networks, biological networks, economic or financial networks, world wide web and Internet, as well as networks of computers, scientists, movie actors etc. Thus, networks are fundamental to datascience, and are intimately connected with most areas of computer science including algorithms, machine learning, IoT and computer systems. In this project you have the freedom to work on any aspect of network analysis according to your interest, and combine with ideas from your favourite subjects.

An honours project requires study of background material and some preliminary investigation to define exactly what to do in the project and how. In this case, we will cover these aspects in the course Social and Technological networks. Thus, you will be able to use your knowledge from the course as your background for your project. The course involves a small project, which will let you gain a better handle on your area of interest and relevant tools and techniques.

This structure of the project gives you an opportunity to make a more informed decision on the topic of your project. As you gain more knowledge during the course, you will be better equipped to define and conduct an interesting and original project of your choice, with help from the supervisor. Its type can range from theoretical work on mathematical properties of networks to designing original algorithms or data analysis techniques.

The STN course involves mathematical and probabilistic analysis of networks. You may want to look at the materials of the course here: http://www.inf.ed.ac.uk/teaching/courses/stn/files1718/lectures.html
The introduction slides give an overview of the course and network science: http://www.inf.ed.ac.uk/teaching/courses/stn/files1718/slides/intro.pptx.pdf

Next year the course will be revised to include more material on computation, and machine learning for network analysis. 

Some typical types of projects can be:
* Develop machine learning techniques to apply to network data
* Develop faster algorithms for network analysis
* Develop techniques to analyse specific network types, such as social, linguistic, biological, financial, computer, or road networks


Students should contact the lecturer.
goal: Develop a method for analysis of large network data, based on algorithms, machine learning, mathematics, or other techniques of the student's choice
completion_criteria: Define a suitable problem in network data analysis. Develop a technique or algorithm. Evaluate appropriately -- through theoretical analysis or experimental evaluation on large datasets.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning to control an RC car
description:
Deep Reinforcement Learning is a method that combines Reinforcement Learning and Deep Neural Networks, which allows visual understanding via Reinforcement Learning. It enables Reinforcement Learning to scale to problems that have high-dimensional state and action spaces, therefore has been increasingly applied in domains such as robotic control.

In this project we will apply Deep Reinforcement Learning algorithms to train a policy to optimize control of a simulated vehicle (RC car) going around a race track. The vehicle will have a camera mounted on it and will be simulated using Gazebo. This way the policy will be trained directly from the image pixels.

This project will allow us to try different exploration strategies as well as design different reward functions to choose the optimal policy with regards to different requirements (e.g. fastest lap time or highest accuracy). Furthermore, it would be possible to test the robustness of different methods when dealing with unexpected disturbances, such as wind or a patch of ice on the race track.

We are going to compare the performance of the policy learned directly from pixels with other learned from low-dimensional observations (such as speed and coordinates). We expect to see that the policy learned from pixels would be more robust under observable disturbances such as an icy patch on the track.

Time permitting, the policy could also be tested on a real RC car (given the School is able to provide the resources).
goal: Train an agent to drive an RC car around a race track
completion_criteria: 1. Set up a simulation environment                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            +

2. Train a policy to drive the RC car around the race track from low-dimensional observations                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +

3. Train a policy to drive the RC car around the race track from image pixels                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +
4. Compare the performance of different policies

title: A multi-objective optimization software for allocating student projects
description:
After an analysis of existing resource allocation models, one or more suitable to the task algorithm will be implemented. The end-product will be a web-based application, which would allow users to authenticate into the system, propose projects, and register interest in project from a list of proposals.

The same would apply to lecturers. They would be able to authenticate into the system and would have higher privileges than their students. They would have to set the maximum number of students/projects to be assigned to. As with the students, the lecturers will be able to place the projects that they will supervise in a preferred order. 

A software will be implemented which, given certain constraints, will allocate a project to each student such that the overall satisfaction of students and lecturers is maximised.

Ideas which would increase the difficulty:

  • Some side's satisfaction could have a greater importance(either students' or lecturers')
  • Implement several allocation model designs and allow the client to choose from either one
  • Place a bias towards some type of variable(​for example, a bias towards self-proposed projects)

A "successful" project allocating software could be used by 

  • universities, when a huge volume of provided and self-proposed projects should be distributed among student
  • firms, when there are a number of opening positions that have to be distributed among new applicants
goal: Develop and analyse a student project allocator
completion_criteria: Provide an end-to-end student project allocation software as described above.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 +
Analyse its biases and try to mitigate/control them.

title: Instructing agents with embodied conversation
description:
Wang et al (2016) propose a model that jointly learns how to ground the terms in a natural language instruction and how to optimise one's actions in the domain.  The task they address is one where the agent can manipulate shapes to create towers etc, but the agent doesn't know what the final tower should look like.  The human user, who can see the goal state but can't manipulate the shapes to make that goal state true, instructs the agent on what actions to perform. The kind of instructions it can learn to interpret include things like "remove red", "remove the blue block", "put the blue block on the red one" and so on.   However, this model has never been tested in the kinds of instructions that people give in the two-person manipulation tasks of Carletta et al (2010).  Here, the final assembly task is quite complex, and the shape of the final item might look like a chair, or an elephant, or a rocket.  But like the task in Wang et al (2010), one human can see the goal state but not manipulate objects to create it, while the other human can manipulate objects but not see the goal state.  So the instruction giver says things like: "put the blue triangle on the red oblong to make a rocket".  Wang et al's (2016) model isn't tested on interpreting phrases that describe properties of the intended result of the action.  This project would extend the signalling games in Wang et al (2016) to cover such cases.


This project would be loosely related to the work that 2 Phd students, Yordan Hristov and Mattias Appelgren (who are supervised by Ram Ramamoorthy and me) are doing on robots learning complex tasks through a combination of trial and error and extended embodied conversations with a human expert.  Anyone that is interested in this project needs to meet with all of us to discuss it.
goal: To extend an existing model that jointly learns embodied linguistic meanings and optimal plans to include utterances where the goal of the action is described.
completion_criteria: Develop the planning environment, consisting of objects of various shapes and colours, and goal states for putting those shapes in various configurations (see Carletta et al (2010)). Implement an extended version of the signalling games from Wang et al (2016) to support interpreting phrases that describe the result or the effect of your current action.

title: Generate web-based user interface code based on sketches
description:
Quoting article in references:

"As it stands now, every step in the design process and every artifact produced is a dead end. Work stops whenever one discipline finishes a portion of the project and passes responsibility to another discipline. Projects progress from stakeholder meetings to design to engineering; requirements become explorations, explorations become mockups and prototypes, and these are handed off to developers to become final products. But each of these cumbersome steps is, at its core, a translation of shared meaning to a different medium in progression toward a common goal, with skilled experts in each domain acting as translators."


This project tries to reduce the time of prototyping and validating (testing) user-interfaces. 

We can address this problem by building a tool that does the following:

  • Accepts following inputs: Picture or Webcam feed (these inputs represent hand-drawn wireframe)
  • The tool processes the input and splits the image into individual user interface elements (blocks, rows, columns, image, button, text, slider,...)
  • Returns reconstructed wire-frame in HTML/CSS representation that reflects the "almost" final user-interface to be used in testing.
goal: Generate HTML/CSS code given picture or webcam feed of hand-drawn wireframe
completion_criteria: Build a functional tool that accepts a picture or webcam feed of hand-drawn wireframe that reconstructs the and returns HTML/CSS prototype code.

title: Measurement-based Hacking of Video Lightfield Parameterisations
description:
Visible light that floods our environment can be physically described as energy that varies over space (3D), time (1D) and direction (2D).  Photographs (printable since 1826) capture 2D slices of this distribution and Videos (since 1889) capture 3D spatio-temporal slices.  Lightfields (since 1996) are a generalisation of this idea. A lightfield captures the spatio-direcional distribution of light [2]. Lightfield videos therefore record the variation of light energy across all three domains -- space, time and direction.  As you might imagine, there are various ways to encode the high-dimensional data for efficient recording, storage, computation/processing and rendering.  

In this project, you will be provided access to a camera that is capable of capturing lightfields at 180 frames per second. Unfortunately, the manufacturer of the camera does not provide the code specifying how the data is encoded. However, they do provide an API for reading the raw image recorded by the camera, as well as a few high-level functionality. The data recorded by the lightfields is encoded using a scheme that is weakly specified by [1]. ​The goal of this project is two-fold:

1) Determining the encoding. In this step, you will observe images of known patterns (calibration) and use the images and knowledge of the construction of the camera lenslet array [1] to determine the (s,t,u,v) [2] parameterisation associated with each pixel. 

2) Gathering a dataset. The second 'fun' step will involve gathering a number of slow-motion datasets of interesting phenomena. The lightfields obtained will be decoded using the parameterisation proposed in 1.   

3) Rendering the datasets. Finally, you will need to render the datasets gathered using the hacked parameterisation to enable effects such as refocusing [3] and view itnerpolation [4]. 


If you are interested in this project, and have the required skills (below), please contact me at k.subr@ed.ac.uk. by 19th March 2018.
goal: To reverse-engineer (hack) the parameterisation of Raytrix lightfield cameras and to test it on a newly acquired dataset
completion_criteria: Step 1: An algorithm to generate (s,t,u,v) parameters corresponding to each pixel in a raw image.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +

Step 2: A dataset of at least 3 different transient effects recorded in slow-motion                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           +
Step 3: Rendering the dataset using refocusing and interactive viewing.

title: Deconvolution of processes underlying DNA mutations observed in cancer genomes
description:
There are trillions of cells in the human body each with nearly identical copy of DNA during infancy. But as we grow, diet (burnt meat), exposure to environmental factors (UV radiation from sunlight) and lifestyle ( tobacco smoke and alcohol) and genetic factors, damage our DNA. The cells have various DNA repair proteins that can fix this damage but due to bad luck or inherited defects in these proteins, the DNA damages are converted into mutations. If these mutations give cells a growth advantage, the cells grow uncontrollably forming a tumour.  

Recently a vast database of mutational from hundred of patients from over 30 types of cancers have been generated with the ultimate hopes of identifying processes that contribute to these mutations and uncovering lifestyle risk factors. Avoiding risk factors can be helpful reduce incidences of cancer. The objective of this project is to exploit the data on mutations such as their location and their context to determine the contribution of various processes that best explain the observed mutations. Many of the processes generate well-defined spectrum and non-random mutation types. 

The most popular method in use today exploits non-negative matrix factorization (Alexandrov et al 2013). However, there are various simplifying assumptions and limitations in the nature of input data required that can be improved upon.
goal: Develop an algorithm that uncovers the weight of linear combinations of various known and unknown environmental and cellular processes causing DNA mutations observed in cancer
completion_criteria: - Fitting simulated and real data using models described in Reference 1.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      +
- Implementing bayesian hierarchical model to compare mutations across different cancer types

title: Android app: making photo organising fun
description:
We all have literally thousands of photos on our phones, making it difficult to find just the one we're looking for. Organizing photos into albums or assigning tags is slow and tedious, so most of us don't bother, especially once we are sitting on a 10K-deep pile of old photos. 

The aim of this project is to develop a fun, swipe-based interface (think Tinder) for organising photos on an Android phone. While I have some ideas for the UI and expected functionality, I expect that whoever gets this project will bring their own ideas, creativity and passion that will greatly influence the end product. 

Information Session
Date: Thur, Mar 22.
Time: 3-3.30pm
Place: Informatics Forum 1.16

I will not be able to hold individual meetings, so please attend the information session if interested in the project.
goal: Develop an android app to organize pictures
completion_criteria: A fully-functional Android app for organising and viewing photos

title: Probabilistic and inference method for identification of DNA aberrations in cancer cells
description:
Cancer is an evolutionary process and the tumour phylogeny problem is to reconstruct the tree like relationship between cells from its genomic alterations which represent timing, relationship and evolutionary history of a cells within the tumour. This information can be used to time the tumour growth, identify tumour driving (instead of passenger) mutations and find cancer stem cells which can be targeted therapeutically. Two frequent aberrations in tumour cells are single nucleotide variation (SNV) and copy number alterations (CNA). 

Using simulated and real sequence data from tumour cells, the project will require formulating and implement either a probabilistic and/or a hidden markov model based approach to identify SNV and CNA while accounting for noise in the single cell data due to several technical biases such as low coverage or sparsity and non-uniformity in capture and biological biases such as allele specific expression and cell cycle phase that can lead to both false negatives and false positives. If time permits, tree like relationship between single cells form the same tumour biopsy will be inferred.
goal: Develop and implement an algorithm based on hidden markov model to aberrations in DNA  in single cell data
completion_criteria: - Testing performance of published method (Monovar) on simulated and real data                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                +

- Adapting the method to single cell RNA-seq data and fining CNAs                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +
- Finding relationship between cells based on aberations

title: Pseudo-temporal ordering to relate clusters and infer dynamic from static single cell data
description:
Single cell omics data makes it possible to infer dynamic information such as cell cycle and cell differentiation from a single time point snap shot data. Such dynamic processes can be modeled using trajectory inference methods also known as pseudotemporal ordering methods which use single cell profiles from a population in which the cells are at different unknown points in the dynamic process. These methods computationally order the cells along a trajectory topology that can be linear, bifurcating or have a tree or a graph structure. These methods provide an unbiased understanding of cellular dynamic process allowing identification of new cell subsets, inference of regulatory interaction and previously hidden developmental relationships amount cell-types.

We have developed a new approach for pseudotemporal ordering based on probabilistic archetype analysis. This project will involve implementing, assessing and iteratively improving this method based on simulated and several published datasets with known trajectory relationships.
goal: To implement and evaluate accuracy and performance of a novel pseudo-temporal and trajectory inference method based on probabilistic archetypes
completion_criteria: - Implementation of the novel method in python or R                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           +
- Assessment of accuracy compared to published methods using simulated and real data

title: ThisThat's ranking questions process inspired by rating systems
description:
Understanding of the Elo rating system is not a pre-requisite for this project.


ThisThat is a smartphone app based polling platform, where users can ask and answer polls, participate in debates and gather statistics on binary questions. We are currently beta testing our iOS MVP and launching on the App Store in August 2018.

This project was inspired by the Elo rating system ( fun description), a method for calculating the relative skill levels of players in zero-sum games, which has been adopted by World Chess Federation, commonly used as a rating system for multiplayer competition in video games, and was famously utilised for FaceMash in the film “The Social Network”. 

Getting public engagement in ranking a list of answer options larger than 5 is hard, while engagement is much easier to obtain for multiple binary questions such as “This or That?”. The idea of ThisThat’s ranking process is to enable a fast and fair ranking of such long lists.

In the app any user can ask a ranking question with p>2 poll answer options, where each respondent of the poll is asked to choose a preference out of two answer options. To frame this into Game-Theory one can interpret poll answer options as players, and each users' preference of a choice of two such players as zero-sum games. Assuming we can collect a lot of data of these pairwise comparison games we want a function that aggregates this data to give each player ratings which can be used to rank these poll answer options.

There are two core difficulties with this ranking process. First this aggregation function can not convert the ranked preferences of individuals into a community-wide (complete and transitive) ranking without violating one or more fairness criteria of Arrow’s impossibility Theorem. Second there are pC2 (number of players choose 2) type of games which can bring rise to a lot of pairwise comparison types. It isn’t always feasible to expect pC2 or more responses for a question. For instance if a user wants 15 pictures ranked to choose which 5 should go in an album then they have 15C2 = 105 type of pairwise comparisons which they could broadcast as binary questions. The difficult herein is trying to reduce the amount of necessary responses for valid statistics.

The goal of this project is for the student to address the two core difficulties; social choice theory and optimisation. It is recommended that the student looks at how rating systems for two-player games such as Elo and Glicko consider Social Choice Theory (if at all) and begin extending such systems to do something sensible in this domain, perhaps by weakening the notion of independence to side-step the Impossibility Theorem. Then they should tailor such a self-correcting and sequential rating system for a ranking process on ThisThat.


Possible extension(s):
Together with ThisThat's technical team the student could implement this ranking feature in the app. Further the student could create a learning algorithm that tailors its regression of the data in the rating system in order to make more accurate predictions of winners of future rounds. The student could also explore the three main mathematical concerns relating to the original work of Elo, namely the correct curve, the correct K-factor, and the provisional period crude calculations.


http://www.thisthatapp.co.uk - join beta testing


Internal supervisor is Dr Kousha Etessami
goal: Create a ranking process plug in for ThisThat, inspired by the Elo rating system, which considers social-choice theory and ranks poll answer options based on sequential rounds of paired comparison
completion_criteria: Prototype plug-in that has been tested, with a discussion on results and future research priorities.

title: ThisThat's user behavioural clustering for optimising distribution of public polls
description:
ThisThat is a smartphone app based polling platform, where users can ask and answer polls, participate in debates and gather statistics on binary questions. We are currently beta testing our iOS MVP and launching on the App Store in August 2018.

It is the student’s task to create an algorithm that prioritises the order in which polls are shown in each user’s Flow page (the page where public polls are visible in a card slider format), where prioritisation is measured with a prediction of highest user engagement. 

Predicting user engagement is a hard problem and while optimising the distribution could be done exactly through co-operative game-theory, such work would be intractable and thus the student is recommended to look in to utilising heuristics. ThisThat have a proposed approach and recommend the student considers this.

ThisThat's proposed approach: Make the core of this project determining unique user coordinates in a multidimensional space that is created from ThisThat's database attributes, in which clusters of identifiable traits should be formed. These user coordinates provide a similarity distance measure of users. Given that polls are created by users, we can infer a measure of engagement of a poll through users' relative distances, and hence respectively determine broadcasting speeds of polls'. 

The process of obtaining user coordinates is recommended to go as follows: First define a space from the  normalised attribute data of ThisThat's database and for efficient computation reduce the dimension of the large matrix containing this data using some order reduction method (e.g. PCA). Then create clusters by grouping the users in a manner that attempts to identify some relationship between them and find the optimal coordinates for the cluster centres. As new data becomes available, user coordinates should be updated and as a consequence the cluster centres should be adjusted accordingly.

Possible extension(s): 

  1. The student can consider a multiplier feature emulating tinder's boost feature, where a higher multiplier results in a quicker response collection from the public for a given user’s own publicly posted polls. In other words this multiplier could multiply the speed at which their polls are distributed to other users. Such a multiplier value would sequentially be updated based on the users' response rate to the public polls and thereby incentivise them to answer questions from the public. 
  2. The student can help ThisThat's mission of bridging society by minimising groupthink. While user-coordinates (as mentioned above) reveal similarity in users and hence help tailor distribution of polls to increase engagement, these co-ordinates may also reveal homophilies of opinions. Indeed interpreting the distance from user to user as the strength of users' links, where users are the nodes, we can identify clusters of similar opinion and weak ties for groups of different opinion. We'd like to create more links between such weak ties to diversify knowledge and opinions and see an opportunity in doing so by taking inspiration from exploration vs exploitation in Reinforcement Learning literature. Providing the user with the ability to choose a percentage of how tailored their polls are to them and translate this to the ratio at which we exploit (broadcast polls at a speed relative to user-coordinates) or explore (randomly broadcast polls). The aim is that users hereby engage in conversation with polls coming from weak ties.


http://www.thisthatapp.co.uk - join beta testing
goal: Produce a learning algorithm that determines how ThisThat public polls are distributed among users
completion_criteria: Prototype algorithm that has been tested, with a discussion on results and future research priorities.

title: Graph clustering with constraints
description:
Note: There are many students expressed interest towards this project. Although new registration is welcome, I expect that an interested student would consider other projects I proposed.

Graphs occurring in the real world usually reveal a high level of order and organisation: higher concentration of edges within the same group of vertices, and lower concentration among different groups. In order to analyse these graphs, a common approach is to partition the vertex set of a graph into clusters (subsets) according to some measurement. Graph clustering has been widely applied in discovering communities in social networks, webpages dealing with similar topics, and proteins having the same specific function in protein-protein interaction networks. 

Most existing algorithms for graph clustering partitions the vertex set of the input graph into multiple clusters purely based on structure information of the input graph. However, for many applications additional constraints about the clustering information can be observed by a user, and needs to be satisfied for the clustering task. In this project you'll develop a reasonable formulation of graph clustering with constraints, and efficient algorithms for solving this problem. 

A successful completion of the project will certainly lead to a publishable result in Algorithms or Machine Learning.
goal: Develop a reasonable formulation of graph clustering with constraints, and efficient algorithms for solving this problem.
completion_criteria: Design and analysis of an efficient algorithm for graph clustering with constraints

title: Enabling distributed high-performance key-value stores
description:
Distributed key-value stores (KVS) are the data-serving workhorses behind today's highly scalable services at companies like Facebook, Google and Amazon. These KVS systems rely on high-performance networking and data replication technologies to achieve high throughput, low latency and strong consistency guarantees. We have developed our own high-performance KVS that uses state-of-the-art network technology (RDMA) and advanced caching policies to achieve these objectives. There are several interesting and useful extensions to our research KVS that interested student(s) could investigate in a year-long project. These include:

  • Comparing the performance of an existing RDMA-based implementation with TCP/IP. The latter implementation would need to be added and tuned for performance. Reference [3] provides a bit of a background (the actual project is different from [3]).
  • Identify "hot" items from a large dataset that should be cached and implement a protocol for notifying servers of caching decisions. 
  • Provide a high-level API on top of RDMA to simplify the programming model -- see references [1,2] below as examples. 

IMPORTANT: these are implementation-heavy projects that will require working with an existing distributed KVS implementation (decrypted meaning: complex, communication-heavy code). You have to have good software skills and genuine interest in systems programming to take this on. The pay-off is a potential contribution toward a research publication and an incredible experience of working on state-of-the-art KVS technology.  

Information Session
Date: Thur, Mar 22.
Time: 3.30-4pm
Place: Informatics Forum 1.16

I will not be able to hold individual meetings, so please attend the information session if interested in the project.
goal: Prototype caching and networking technologies for a distributed KVS
completion_criteria: Depends on the exact project, but a working prototype and high-quality reusable code are a must.

title: Search and recommendation techniques to enhance rich media in education
description:
Current educational practice is full of examples of resources being made available with little consideration for how they will be used. Lectures, for instance, are recorded and put on the web, with little support for re-use other than simply playing through them. This project is about making these resources more useful by helping to locate and connect other related materials.

Videos are available from many sources, but are usually not usefully linked to other material. Documents, notes, slides, are often available but again allow only very limited use. These resources tend to arise from old conceptions of learning based on relatively passive consumption of information. We see a need to support active development of learning, encouraging inquiry-led processes in which information is sought out and transformed, assisting finding and exploiting materials that can be reworked and integrated.

The objective of this project is to investigate intelligent search and recommendation techniques, specifically in relation to educational rich-media materials.
