This will involve surveying the types of resources that exist, and working to develop methods for automated analysis of them. This can include e.g. topic modelling, event segmentation, methods based primarily on analysis of speech, text or images

Another potential focus is around ontology construction. Recruited materials will need to be integrated into a developing context in which learners are creating their own conceptualisation of a learning domain. To the extent that resources may have metadata when found, it will require adaptation; in many cases, metadata will have to be constructed. This will not occur within a fixed ontological framework, but rather in relation to one that is dynamically emerging. Therefore, techniques of ontology acquisition and adaptation will need to be extended.
goal: To investigate intelligent search and recommendation techniques, specifically in relation to educational rich-media materials
completion_criteria: Negotiable. A substantial feasibility study would be very valuable. Some practical development work is certainly also desirable. This project will take place in the context of existing research in the area.

title: Port FreeBSD to an Explicit Data Graph Execution (EDGE) Instruction Set Architecture (ISA)
description:
In this project you will port FreeBSD to an Explicit Data Graph Execution (EDGE) Instruction Set Architecture (ISA). FreeBSD uses LLVM as it's compiler and there is an existing LLVM toolchain for EDGE available from Microsoft Research. For an overview of EDGE architectures and EDGE compilers see [1]. 

The goal of this project is to modify Microsoft's LLVM compiler for EDGE to support FreeBSD and to use the modified LLVM compiler to build and link the FreeBSD kernel for EDGE. It is not expected that you will boot the kernel as that requires setting up a number of things like interrupt handlers, timers, a uart for console output, the memory management unit for virtual memory and exception handling support. This is a significant amount of work for one person but if two people sign up for the project then we can make a plan to boot the kernel.

The instructions for building FreeBSD with LLVM are available online [2]. The first step in getting started would be to setup a git repository with the FreeBSD sources and then build the kernel for one of the existing targets (x64, Arm etc). The next step would be to create a branch in your FreeBSD git repository for your new EDGE port and then modify the FreeBSD build system to add a new processor. Then you would try to compile the kernel for this new target and see what errors you get. The errors will tell you what support is missing in LLVM and needs to be implemented. Often you will be able to copy the existing code in LLVM for one of the targets that already support FreeBSD.

In addition to the FreeBSD and LLVM changes, you will write the Application Binary Interface (ABI) for FreeBSD on EDGE. This document will contain information such as the calling conventions, register usage, frame layout and information about types (i.e. is 'long' 32b or 64b? how are fields in structs aligned? the ABI answers these questions and more). There is an existing ABI document for Linux on EDGE that you can use as a starting point.
goal: Link the FreeBSD kernel for EDGE
completion_criteria: Changes to LLVM to support compiling and linking FreeBSD for EDGE; Changes to FreeBSD to link the kernel for EDGE; A document describing the Application Binary Interface (ABI) for FreeBSD on EDGE

title: 3D Object detection from point clouds (LIDAR)
description:
Detection of object from 3d point clouds is an important computer vision problem for various real-world applications such as self-driving cars, landscape modeling and housekeeping robots. Compared to object detection from 2d images, LIDAR provides reliable depth information. However, LIDAR point clouds can be sparse and not randomly sampled.


This project will require implementing an object detection system for LIDAR points by developing a deep learning method such as Faster RCNN that can take a set of 3d points and outputs a set of 3d box coordinates and their corresponding confidence scores.

Due to high interest in machine learning projects, one-to-one meeting is not feasible. Thus I will organise a group meeting towards the end of the student selection period to discuss about the project details. If you like to contact me for the project, please use [UG4/MInf-project][3D-detection] (with brackets) in your e-mail.

Group meeting will be organised on March 20 Tuesday between 13.30-14.15 at Informatics IF1.41a.
goal: To learn to detect objects from 3d point clouds
completion_criteria: The project will require you to understand and implement a convolutional neural network in a deep learning environment (e.g. pytorch, tensorflow), to develop learning formulations and network architectures, and to assess the performance of your method in standard computer vision benchmarks.

title: Identifying user interactions on mobile devices
description:
Mobile devices are the future of modern embedded computing. Many software and hardware solutions are currently being developed by both industry and research in order to make it faster, better and more energy efficient. One major area that has to be understood in detail for this effort are mobile workloads. What does the system I want to improve actually run?

In previous work[1] a methodology is introduced that greatly helps with analysing interactive mobile workloads on Android. This is done by capturing system events and video output of workloads running on an Android device. The collected data is then analysed offline and evaluated with the goal of improving user experience and energy efficiency of the device by tuning the CPU frequency governor. The ultimate goal is to apply this technique at runtime. Essential for the success of this runtime approach, however, is the ability to identify interactions in order to make a correct decision about which frequency point to take for the upcoming system response.

The goal of this project is to understand in what way the Android operating system handles user interactions so they can be identified at runtime. A tracing system must be developed that gives detailed information about which user interactions were executed at what point during an executed mobile workload. Generating this digital "interaction fingerprint" can potentially be done following different approaches such as:

  • annotating function calls to interaction handlers in the Android SDK
  • instrumenting application APK files before they are executed [2]
  • instrumenting Android runtime tools responsible for application execution such as ART or Dalvik [3]

The techniques mentioned above potentially require modifying, building and deploying the Android operating system which can by done by using sources from the Android Open Source Project [4].


GROUP MEETING: There will be a group meeting setup to discuss your suitability for this project. Please study the provided references to know what to expect.

The group meeting will be on Tuesday the 3rd of April 4pm - 5pm in AT 3.07.

If you could be so kind as to fill in this short form regarding your skill set. It will give us a head start for the meeting:

https://goo.gl/forms/nBt1M57P7QJrXPeH3
goal: Automatically generate unique identifiers for touch screen interactions executed on an Android mobile device
completion_criteria: A working implementation of a system able to generate unique interaction fingerprints for a given set of workloads.

title: A real-time messaging app with cross-language support
description:
The University of Edinburgh works closely with refugees from Syria, providing support to primary and secondary school students who have trouble managing their studies because of the language barrier and other difficulties [1]. Currently, these school students go to a two-hour workshop towards the end of the week which is led by University of Edinburgh students. The workshop focuses on providing support to help the students with their homework, and the purpose of this project is to provide an app which extends this support beyond the confines of the workshop.

The intention is to develop a bilingual Android app which provides a hub for each student who can update the work that they have been given which the designated teachers can see.  This will help them to prepare beforehand. The app should also provide a chat service where students can immediately seek a response from any available teacher, or the teacher of their choice, along with a forum where students can ask questions and expect replies from other students/teachers.

Crucially, the app will provide natural language translation support so that those who are not proficient in Arabic can also take part in assisting students, allowing students to post questions in Arabic, have these read in an English translation, and then have a reply which was written in English translated back to be served as a reply in Arabic. The expected technology to use would be Firebase [2] to provide authentication and back-end support and Google Cloud functions to perform the language translation [4].  A similar technology could be used for the forum where messages are archived with translation support available. The Firestore [3] NoSQL database could be used to implement this forum.

Locally on the Android device, the app should use modern Android design using architecture components and the lifecycle-aware LiveData model [5] working with Observer objects to provide a well-engineered client app.  The app should be tested with the schoolchildren who participate in the University of Edinburgh Teenage Syrian Refugee Tutoring Project.


Note: This project requires proficiency in the Arabic language.  Please do not apply for this project unless you meet the "Essential skills" specified below for this project.
goal: To create an Android app which supports real-time messaging with translation between the languages used by sender and receiver.
completion_criteria: Producing a prototype app exhibiting the language translation described above.

title: Image2Video: Predicting future frames with deep generative networks
description:
The goal of this project will be learning to generate future frames from a given sequence of frames (or video clip). Interestingly, this task does not require any manual supervision from a human annotator, at the same time, it can posed as a supervised learning problem, as we have access to all the frames of given videos.

This project will require you to understand and implement a generative adversarial network or a variational autoencoder in a deep learning environment (e.g. pytorch, tensorflow), to develop original learning formulations and network architectures, and to assess the performance of your method in standard computer vision benchmarks.

Due to high interest in machine learning projects, one-to-one meeting is not feasible. Thus I will organise a group meeting towards the end of the student selection period to discuss about the project details. If you like to contact me for the project, please use [UG4/MInf-project][Image2Video] (with brackets) in your e-mail.

Group meeting will be organised on March 22 between 14.15-15.00 at Informatics IF1.41a.
goal: The goal will be learning to generate plausible future frames from a given sequence of frames (or video clip)
completion_criteria: This project will require you to understand and implement a generative adversarial network or a variational autoencoder in a deep learning environment (e.g. pytorch, tensorflow), to develop original learning formulations and network architectures, and to assess the performance of your method in standard computer vision benchmarks.

title: A User-friendly Interface for Teleoperating Valkyrie Humanoid Robot
description:
The NASA Valkyrie is one of the most advanced humanoid robots in the world. The robot was constructed by NASA-JSC in 2015 and delivered to the University of Edinburgh in Spring 2016. Weighing 125 kg and standing 1.8m tall, Valkyrie will enable breakthroughs in humanoid control, motion planning and perception. PhD Students and researchers from Edinburgh Centre for Robotics will carry out research using the robot.

The aim of this project is to develop efficient user interface for operating the Valkyrie robot, in addition to the existing GUI. In many circumstances, using a graphic interface and mouse is neither efficient for quick responses, nor convenient for untrained users. There are lots of techniques developed in game industry that use joysticks and some wearable devices as the interface between the agents and users. Therefore, this project focuses on developing suitable operation/teleoperation methods towards a better shared autonomy.

The project requires the student to team up with other students in our Edinburgh Centre for Robotics and accomplish the following work:

  1. Successful installation and validation of demos of the Valkyrie simulation in ROS+Gazebo environment (see the links in references);​
  2. Integrate existing motion planning libraries developed in the group;
  3. Develop efficient user-interface for teleoperation;
  4. An alternative project outcome can also be the human-robot interface that provides the robot's sensory feedback to users (see MIT HERMES project in references);
  5. Troubleshooting, code quality test, and validation in the simulation environment.

Note: students are encouraged to send their CVs by emails for discussing the suitability.
goal: To develop a more user friendly and efficient interface for teleoperating Valkyrie humanoid robot
completion_criteria: In the end of the project, an ordinary user should be able to successfully command a robot motion by using the newly developed user-interface. The commanded motion can be walking, arm reaching, manipulation or a whole body motion.

title: Neural Machine Translation for Closely-Related Languages
description:
Neural Machine Translation is a novel approach to machine translation that has recently become the new state of the art, but performs more poorly in low data conditions [1]. For phrase-based statistical machine translation, it has been shown that translation between closely related languages can be learned with modest amounts of training data [2].

This project will develop neural translation for closely related language pairs. Building on top of an open-source toolkit for neural machine translation [3], it will explore which language representation is most suitable for translating closely related languages, and explore ways to improve quality over a baseline system under low-data conditions, for instance by biasing the alignment model towards monotonic alignment and using unsupervised pre-training.
goal: Development of neural machine translation systems for closely-related languages
completion_criteria: - Build and evaluate a baseline system for neural machine translation between closely-related languages                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       +

- Build and evaluate experimental systems that use alternative language representations, model architectures, and/or auxiliary training data to improve performance for NMT between closely-related languages.

title: Reproduction Study in Neural Machine Translation
description:
Neural machine translation has developed into a large research area, with hundreds of papers yearly proposing architectural and algorithmic improvements that lead to gains over baseline NMT systems. However, experiments are often performed with a relatively weak baseline, on only one or a few datasets, and with little analysis, and it is often unclear if improvements will carry over to other datasets and stronger systems [1], and how different methods interact with each other.

In this project, we will select recent published research in neural machine translation (or a recent general machine learning technique) and perform a reproduction study. As a starting point, you will re-implement the proposed algorithm or architecture into the Nematus toolkit for neural machine translation, and perform experiments on a standard dataset and with a strong baseline. The next steps depend on the outcome of these experiments:

  • if the improvement is successfully reproduced, perform an analysis in what respect translation is improved, and test if the improvement carries over to different settings, e.g. a language pair that is typologically very different from that in the first experiment, or a language pair with substantially different amounts of training data
  • if first experiments are unsuccessful, try to make the experiments more similar to the original paper: use the same dataset, similar baselines, or even code from the original authors. Identify which factors affect the success of the proposed method. For instance, you might find that it is only helpful in low-resource conditions, or over a weaker baseline system.

The balance between implementation, experiments and analysis is flexible, and partially depends on the complexity of the architecture or algorithm that you choose to investigate.
goal: re-implement, evaluate and analyze recent research for machine translation
completion_criteria: - implement a recent research paper in the Nematus toolkit                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +

- train MT systems and evaluate performance on standard datasets with strong baseline                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         +

- explore differences between original paper and your own experiments that can explain why first results are (probably) different. Experiment with different baselines, code bases and datasets.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              +
- analyze the results

title: Privacy Preserving Deep Learning
description:
Deep learning methods are data hungry, however, those data usually contain some private information. Things become worse if the company that stores the data is not the one that carries out the modelling, e.g., they outsourced the work to a third-party company. A possible solution is to run deep learning on the encrypted data, and this project is to investigate how this affects training and inference (e.g., accuracy, speed).


Notes: 


1. Recently, ML related projects have a high number of applicants, more than I can feasibly meet individually. Therefore I will arrange a group meeting with everyone who has registered interest on 28th March 2018 in order to discuss the project. For the same reason I will strictly enforce the pre-requisites.


2. FYI, This project will mainly be supervised by my postdoc Yongxin Yang.
goal: Carry out an empirical study of privacy preserving deep learning.
completion_criteria: An empirical study on applying various deep learning models jointly with encryption technique for one or more large-scale tasks.

title: Adversarial Attacks against Deep Learning
description:
Machine learning is increasingly widely used across society, but it is not always robust to adversarially designed inputs. 

https://blog.openai.com/adversarial-example-research/

This has led to research on:

  • Methods to generate adversarial inputs which break machine learning systems, either in black-box or white-box manner.
  • Designing defences against adversarial inputs. ML models that are robust to adversarial attacks.

This area of research has primarily been conducted on standard classification neural networks, but adversarial examples in other areas has more interesting nuances. As we showed in a recent paper, they can be used to gain insight into the hidden "beliefs" of more complicated models such as Visual Question Answering really function. (LINK TODO)

This is a flexible project. We could explore:

  1. Methods for generating attacks (eg reinforcement learning)
  2. ​Methods for defending attacks
  3. Application to further exploration of implicit beliefs in related language or vision & language models (QA, VQA, Captioning, VRE, etc)



Notes: Recently, ML related projects have a high number of applicants, more than I can feasibly meet individually. Therefore I will arrange a group meeting with everyone who has registered interest on 28th March 2018 in order to discuss the project. For the same reason I will strictly enforce the pre-requisites.
goal: Explore adversarial attacks against deep learned models
completion_criteria: Explore generation, defense, or beleif implications of adversarial examples in deep learning.

title: Inferring RNA splice isoforms from single cell RNA-seq data
description: Although all the cells in the human body have the same DNA, the combination of the parts of the DNA (called "genes") that each cell expresses differs and defines that cell's identity. Interestingly, however, even the same gene can have different forms (called "splice isoforms") which can change during development or disease. The goal of this project is to exploit data from single cells that we are generating in the lab from various cancers to infer splice isoforms. Although there are many methods developed for identifying splice isoforms from bulk or average data from a large number of cells, few methods exist for identifying them from single data which suffer from missing values and large noise. One idea is to first group single cell data from identical states and then use the data from this group to identify splice isoforms.
goal: Develop a method to infer prevalence of various forms of RNA transcripts from RNA sequencing data
completion_criteria: Good knowledge of programming (python and R). Good understanding of basic machine learning and statistics. Basic knowledge of biology

title: Participatory Budgeting and Social Choice
description:
Participatory budgeting is a mechanism that enables a number of contributors

to provide input on whether a given set of submitted proposals will be funded.  In this project,

 a number of models will be investigated for participatory budgeting resulting to the design

of a treasury system for blockchain protocol. For reference, an existing cryptocurrency

that provides a first instance of this is DASH. Social choice theory provides

tools for evaluating mechanisms such as those used in participatory budgeting. 

A security and  game theoretic analysis, will be conducted, related 

experiments,  as well as an implementation of the 

budgeting mechanism in the form of a smart contract in Ethereum.
goal: Investigate participatory budgeting mechanisms and implement them.
completion_criteria: Mathematical model. Analysis including experiments. Implementation and Demonstration.

title: Sensing Spaces: A Study in Mapping Air Pollution in Public Spaces using Personal Exposure Monitors
description:
[This project is in two parts and students can choose to work on either one of the them, with the two students working independently yet collaborating loosely]


The Centre for Speckled Computing has developed the AIRSpeck personal exposure monitors powered by specks with sensors for counting airborne particulates, and for measuring temperature and relative humidity. The specks process the data in situ, and the results are uploaded wirelessly to a server tagged with time and GPS information.

This project is concerned with mapping and visualising the air quality in public spaces based on the spatio-temporal data uploaded from numerous personal Airspeck monitors using the social media. The data from personal monitors will be mapped onto a GIS to provide up-to-date air quality information in central Edinburgh.  Comparisons can be made with the air quality predictions for central Edinburgh using the ADMS modelling software [1]  from Cambridge Environmental Research Consultants or equivalent modelling software.

The Airspeck provides counts for airborne particulates of different sizes in 16 bins ranging from 0.38 microns to 16 microns. Outdoor pollution sources such as automobile exhaust, dust, burning of waste, and pollen, and indoor pollution sources, such as different types of cooking (roasting, boiling), dusting, open fires, have their unique spectrum of particulate counts across the 16 bins. This part of the project will implement a system to recognise the signature to identify the different types of sources. The same principle can be extended to classify the urban spaces into different types such as a busy or quiet roads, traffic junctions, and parks, based on the AIRSpeck bin count readings.
goal: A study in mapping air quality in central Edinburgh using crowd sourcing methods
completion_criteria: 1. The ability to visualise the airborne particulate pollution in a GIS for central Edinburgh.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                +

2. Comparisons with predictions from the ADMS-Urban-model.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +
3. Recognition of air pollution sources based on the particulate bin counts from the AIRSpeck monitors.

title: Heat flows in graphs: an experimental study
description:
Heat flows are one of the most fundamental concepts in physics, and relate to graph theory through matrix representation of graphs. However, after extensive studies about heat kernels in graphs, computer scientists' current understanding about the powers and limits about heat kernels in algorithm design is still quite limited.

In this project, we will visualise the dynamics of heat flows in various graphs, and study the properties of heat flows by experiments. The main goal is to provide researchers with the first set of visualisation platforms about heat flows in graphs. For a student with excellent mathematical skills, there is a chance to further study the problem in a more theoretical way, whose outcome could potentially lead to a publishable result in algorithms and machine learning.
goal: To investigate the relationship between heat changes in a graph and graph's structure property
completion_criteria: The software that visualises the heat changes in an arbitrary graph

title: The Big Sleep - Analysis to investigate the association of body orientation and sleep apnoea
description:
Sleep, or the lack of it, impacts our health and general well-being.  Chronic lack of sleep has been associated with health problems such as high blood pressure, weight gain and reduced effectiveness of the immune system. 

“The Big Sleep” project is concerned with collecting population-wide big data sets from subjects wearing miniature wireless sensors for research in sleep medicine .  

This study is concerned with analysing changes in the orientation of the body during sleep. For example, this information has implications for pregnant mothers; recent findings [1][2][3] have demonstrated an  association between lying on the back and a 2.3 fold increase in risk of late stillbirth.  The results were based on data collected from mothers filling in a detailed questionnaire on their sleeping routines.

Rather than relying on the subject's recall, this project proposes to use the RESpeck device, worn as a plaster on the chest, to record changes in the orientation of the body during sleep, such as supine (lying on the back), on the left-hand side or the right-hand side. The RESpeck data is transferred wirelessly to a mobile phone for onward transmission to the server for storage and analysis. 

The project will involve the following:

(1) An application currently exists for collecting data wirelessly from the RESpeck on an Android phone.  This should be extended to include functionality to view graphically hourly summary of the body orientation in terms of percentage of time spent in the three positions.

(2) Execute data collection from a sample of 25 volunteers with sleep apnea wearing the RESpeck during sleep for one week.

(3) Analyse the data to identify patterns in the sleep positions 

(4) The RESpeck provides respiratory rate and flow and one can Investigate associations between sleep positions and restrictions in the breathing as found in conditions such as sleep apnea when there are episodes of the subject pausing in breathing or periods of shallow breathing.
goal: The collection of  sensor data from the wearable RESpeck device to analyse changes in body orientation and sleep apnoea
completion_criteria: A  mobile application with summary of the body orientation during sleep; analysis of the body orientation and breathing data

title: Game theoretical aspects of blockchain protocols
description:
Blockchain protocols like the one used in bitcoin are important to be analysed from a game theoretic

perspective. Currently the game theoretic tools available are still limited to specific blockchain protocols

mostly related to proof of work ledgers. 

In this project, we will investigate a model for game theoretic analysis of blockchain protocols and apply

it to an existing proof of stake blockchain protocol that has a number of features including delegation

of stake to stakeholders and flexible reward mechanism design. We will use as starting point

recent work in blockchain mining games. The objective is to explore relevant mechanism design

mechanism that incentivise a desired behaviour.
goal: Provide a game theory model, mathematical analysis, and experimental analysis of a blockchain system
completion_criteria: Mathematical analysis, experimental results.

title: A Swift Playground app teaching children how to code with Marty the Robot
description: (none)
goal: (none)
completion_criteria: (none)

title: Investigating distributed multi-agent swarm coordination for coastal surveying
description: (none)
goal: (none)
completion_criteria: (none)

title: ThisThat's latent user demographics classification
description:
ThisThat is a smartphone app based polling platform, where users can ask and answer polls, participate in debates and gather statistics on binary questions. We are currently beta testing our iOS MVP and launching on the App Store in August 2018.

With Market Research at the core of ThisThat, a business need is to enable researchers to tailor their questions to demographics. We aim to have 60+ demographics to choose from, enabling researchers to select individual values (i.e. gender, age group, and location) to refine their respondent pool, or select a full demographic to compare results by value.

It is the student’s task to create algorithms that classify users latent demographics based on users’ content creation and actions on ThisThat’s platform, such as gender, age, regional origin, political leaning and so on. These learning algorithms are recommended to be set up such that their results can be updated dynamically as new data becomes available.

Recommended consideration of users’ data include:

  • Their dictionary of private data
  • Their network of Followers and Following
  • Their own polls, which include a picture, a question, answer options, a caption and commenting
  • The history of their responses to polls, commenting on polls, and up and down voting of comments from other users on polls

Possible extension(s): The student could determine any other number of user demographic type that they may find interesting such as spam users or bots.


http://www.thisthatapp.co.uk - join beta testing
goal: Produce a learning algorithm that creates user demographic classifications
completion_criteria: Prototype algorithm that has been tested, with a discussion on results and future research priorities

title: Smartphone Auditor for the “DEMOS” End-2-End Verifiable E-voting
description:
Electronic voting (e-voting), compared with paper voting, a resolutely 19th-century election approach, has advantages in a number of aspects. Among those benefits, the ability to audit the electoral process at every stage is the most important one. In an end-to-end verifiable e-voting system, the voter can obtain a receipt after ballot casting that allows him/her to verify that his/her vote was (i) cast as intended, (ii) recorded as cast, and (iii) tallied as recorded. Moreover, any external third party auditor should also be able to verify that the election procedure is executed properly.

This project aims to design and implement a smartphone app that can be used to verify the integrity of the DEMOS e-voting system. DEMOS is the world first end-to-end verifiable e-voting system without any setup assumptions [1,2].

References:

[1] A. Kiayias, T. Zacharias, and B. Zhang. End-to-End Verifiable Elections in the Standard Model. EUROCRYPT 2015: 468-498.

[2] A. Kiayias, T. Zacharias, and B. Zhang. DEMOS-2: Scalable E2E Verifiable Elections without Random Oracles. In CCS 2015: 352-363.
goal: Smartphone Application for E-voting
completion_criteria: Demonstration of the smartphone application. Report on the theory of verification.

title: Finding translations on the web
description:
The web has lots of translations on it, like user interfaces for hotel booking sites.  The web is also full of garbage. 

Machine translation systems learn from good translations, but noise can harm quality.  We want to find ways to increase the signal to noise ratio in data extracted from the web.  Ultimately this will be evaluated by quality of the translation system. 

You'll be provided with:

- An existing pipeline for the method described in http://statmt.org/wmt16/pdf/W16-2365.pdf

- Data for some EU languages http://paracrawl.eu/releases.html

- A baseline machine translation system.  The goal is to improve performance of this system.  You can also use it as part of your pipeline e.g. to score things. 

Things you could try:

- Are some web domains better than others?

- How do we detect and remove machine translation so we don't train on our own bad output?

- What if we score with language models or a baseline machine translation system?  Are we at risk of throwing out hard but correct translations?
goal: Raise machine translation quality by improving corpus processing
completion_criteria: Program to process corpora from the web and experiments with a machine translation system, ideally showing improvement.

title: Machine translation for a low-resource language: English->isiXhosa
description:
Xhosa (aka isiXhosa) is one of the 11 official languages in South Africa. In this project, you'll improve translation quality for English to Xhosa translation.  The ultimate goal is a translation app for medical doctors who usually speak English, but within the scope of this project we're looking for translation quality.  You don't need to speak any Xhosa to do this project. 

Our project with the University of Cape Town gathered 458,000 sentences or 2.5 million words worth of translations, which makes it a low-resource language (for context, Finnish has about 2.6 million sentences).  In there is localization for GNOME, for KDE, a project with the South African Navy, the bible, and chat conversations about health topics.

In the project, we mostly optimized Xhosa->English translation.  Some things that worked are pretending Zulu is Xhosa, using monolingual data from the web, and deep neural networks. I can send you a report on what worked and didn't work on request (it's not on a website). 

You'll learn:

  1. How to use a machine translation system and score its performance
  2. Tricks for low-resource languages, such as ​monolingual data [1,2] and multilingual translation [3]
  3. Devising your own strategies


The easier form of this project is just applying strategies that are known to work and measuring their impact.  The harder form of this project is coming up with improvements to test.
goal: Improve translation from English to isiXhosa by applying low-resource techniques
completion_criteria: A table with lines for each improvement added and BLEU scores showing quality changes. Software implementation.

title: Identifying features that explain gender specific differences in cancer succeptibility
description: It is known that for many types of cancers, prevalence in unequal for both genders. Some of the reasons for this include lifestyle/occupation differences between men and women. For example, lung and liver cancers are high in males due to smoking and alcohol. But for some, there is no clear reason why: For example, a type of brain tumour called glioblastoma has a 1.4:1 male to female incidence ratio; similarly, thyroid cancer is more prevalent in females. We hypothesize that there are host specific differences that could explain the disparity. For example, microglia (a type of immune cells in the brain) appear to be different molecularly in males and females. The goal of this project is to integrate data from cancer genomes across 30 different cancer types as well as data from single cell RNA-sequencing of cells from different organs, to learn genomics and clinical features that are different in males and females, filter out features are tissue independent differences and have trivial explnations such as lifestyle, body mass, hormones and then use machine learning to predict (and then validate) tumour types that should be different in men and women.
goal: machine learning of cancer genomics data to predict factors that predict cancers for whose susceptibility should be different between males and females
completion_criteria: Integrate published data, develop methodology to extract features, evaluate various deep learning/machine learning methods to predict succeptibility

title: ThisThat's classifier algorithm for eligibility of poll pairing
description:
ThisThat is a smartphone app based polling platform, where users can ask and answer polls, participate in debates and gather statistics on binary questions. We are currently beta testing our iOS MVP and launching on the App Store in August 2018.

ThisThat aims to give groups that campaign for change a stronger platform to be heard from and aims on doing so through its paring feature. This feature amalgamates two polls (both asking the same question) that have been conducted by separate ThisThat users. This procedure hence combines poll statistics, a form of meta-analysis and can be iterated across all polls asking the same question, increasing the rate of speed at which polls collect responses.

Process of pairing a poll:  A user who wants to pair their poll with another user's poll requests to pair. Upon requesting the other user is notified and can choose to accept or decline.

This project's goal is to create an algorithm which learns how to identify polls that should be merged. Since the polls can have extremely diverse content this problem becomes very difficult. However, we can assume that when two users agree to merge their polls, then those polls are suitable for that. The latter can be used as training data for the creation of a neural network able to identify similar polls. These similar polls are then used to create suggestions for pairing which the user will be able to see in the app.

The purpose of suggesting paring to users with polls eligible for pairing, identified by this neural network, is to diversify the sample of votes and the sample of users which pair.

The hope is that this neural network will be able to detect:
  •  similarity in polls such as:
    • “Brexit?”: “fan” or “not a fan” and
    • “Should we leave the EU?”: “Yes” or “No”  (irrespective of the poll’s picture)
  •  differences in polls such as:
    • “what should I get?” “this” or “that” (picture of two different shoes) and
    • “what should I get?” “this” or “that” (picture of two different cars)


http://www.thisthatapp.co.uk - join beta testing
goal: Produce a neural network that learns to measure similarity in two ThisThat Polls.
completion_criteria: Prototype algorithm that has been tested, with a discussion on results and future research priorities.

title: Rubbish Microsoft's Chinese-English translation press release
description:
Microsoft put out a press release disguised as an academic paper claiming that their Chinese-English system had reached "human parity:" https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/publication/achieving-human-parity-on-automatic-chinese-to-english-news-translation/ .  Machine translation has not reached human parity. 

We know there are some problems and would like to measure their impact.  Or find your own problems; don't worry there are more. 

One problem is that they complain about the quality of translation from Chinese to English in the original test set.  The test set does in fact have bad human translations.  But in 50% of the cases the English is the original, in which case they should be complaining about the quality of translation to Chinese.  Did that impact their evaluation? 

Another place to look is the evaluation metric.  As a rule of thumb, if your NLP system is better than humans at human-defined task, it's probably the metric that's broken.  Are people preferring fluent sentences in cases where the translation is good over the original sentence?  Is this covering for bad translations?  We can study this by looking at the human judgments made. 

This project can be done by multiple students.  Google's press release is also rubbish if you'd prefer to work on that, but they didn't release the data: https://arxiv.org/abs/1609.08144 .
goal: Explain to scientists, and possibly to a journalist, how Microsoft cheated and report correct results
completion_criteria: Studying at least one, ideally more, flaws in the paper.  Redoing the experiment correctly where feasible.

title: Escrow protocols for Bitcoin transactions
description:
Blockchain technology is rapidly emerging; in the coming years we will see widespread adoption of apps running on blockchain-based platforms (BitCoin, Ethereum) as replacements for conventional transaction media.

An important consideration for cryptocurrencies is how to safely purchase physical goods via transactions on the blockchain. A similar issue exists today, with platforms like EBay allowing users to digitally pay for physical items: a common solution is escrow, or having a trusted third party hold the funds until the user can confirm they received the purchased goods.

Escrow protocols for cryptocurrencies at the moment are similar to conventional escrow: either the market in question will hold the funds, or a third party service such as Escrow My Bits will mediate the transaction. The Lightning Network, a controversial payment protocol operating on top of the blockchain, claims to conceptually allow for off-chain transactions to be enforceable on-chain, but the project is still under development, and while the technology is live for simple transactions, there is no evidence of success.

The goal of this project is to investigate blockchain-based protocols that could serve as replacements for conventional escrow. Specifically, what problems need to be solved in order to use blockchain technology (specifically smart contracts) to imitate escrow? How do cutting-edge technologies like the Lightning Network approach this issue? Can we create or implement a protocol using smart contracts that eliminates the need for a trusted third party to hold funds during transactions?
goal: Investigate blockchain-based protocols that could serve as replacements for conventional escrow
completion_criteria: Investigate blockchain-based protocols that could serve as replacements for conventional escrow

title: De-identification and re-identification of healthcare data
description:
The opportunities for applying machine learning to address important problems in the healthcare industry are vast. Potential applications include determining the risk of a patient being readmitted to a hospital within 30 days of discharge, determining the likelihood of developing potentially life threatening illnesses, and many more.  In order to build models on healthcare data, it must first be de-identified in order to protect the privacy of individual patients and comply with healthcare industry regulations.  It is often necessary to quantify the risk of re-identification on de-identified data sets.

Unfortunately the very power of machine learning that makes the data useful, can be turned against the privacy that one aims to achieve using de-identification. For instance one could try to match a database of public movement patterns with timing information against movement patterns obtained from de-identified healthcare claim data. There are grave dangers of de-identifiction.  

Common approaches for de-identification include methods such as k-anonymity and differential privacy.

Project deliverables are as follows.

  1. Investigate means for re-identifying healthcare datasets that were de-identified. The de-identified data might satisfy some level of k-anonymity or differential privacy, but does this prevent de-identification?
  2. Investigate reasonable formal measures of re-identification risk, and if such measures are found, implement means of masking particular data elements to get the re-identification risk below a specified threshold.

This is an industry supported project.

About Craneware, Inc. Craneware is the market leader in software and supporting services that help healthcare providers improve margins so they can invest in quality patient outcomes. Learn more at craneware.com. They will likely provide synthesized healthcare claim data for conducting the study.
goal: Means for re-identifying de-identified healthcare data. Measuring the risk of re-identification, and improving de-identification.
completion_criteria: * Demonstrate that k-anonymity does not necessarily guarantee de-identification/anonymity.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +

* Investigate alternative measures for de-identification.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     +
* Implement means of masking particular data elements to satisfy the measure.

title: End-to-End Service based 5G Mobile Network Infrastructure and Use Cases
description: 5G mobile networks are currently undergoing research and standardization with rollouts expected around 2020-22. The vision of 5G as a multi-service mobile network infrastructure sets it apart from previous generations of mobile networks; Currently deployed 4G mobile networks in contrast only cater to just one service - mobile broadband. Network slicing is a concept that brings together infrastructure virtualization and network softwarization and is expected to enable the multi-service 5G infrastructure in a cost-effective manner. The goal of this project to realize end-to-end slicing in an open source based mobile network infrastructure testbed driven by a particular use case. This would involve focusing especially on the core network and service orchestration entities.
goal: To realize an end-to-end 5G service infrastructure from the perspective of a 5G service/use case
completion_criteria: Realizing an end-to-end service over a slicing enabled 5G infrastructure prototype.

title: Formal analysis of Zerovote
description: Zerovote is a decentralized self-tallying e-voting protocol that could be implemented on the blockchain. The protocol is based on the ideas of Zerocoin. Zerovote is formally proven to preserves voter privacy. Given the public setting of the protocol, we believe that a proof of (individual and universal) verifiability would be possible and not too different from the treatment for privacy, though the need for incorporating verification requests could make it more complex. A less explored avenue for potential future work would also be in verifiability of eligibility (as opposed to only satisfying eligibility as part of the correctness properties). The goal of the project is precisely to formally analyse Zerovote with respect to verifiability-type properties.
goal: The goal of the project is precisely to formally analyse Zerovote with respect to verifiability-type properties
completion_criteria: 1. Either prove that Zerovote is end-to-end verifiable: provide a formal proof                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                +
2. Or disprove that Zerovote is  end-to-end verifiable: provide an attack and propose improvements to the scheme

title: Graphically provable security
description:
Digital security is notoriously hard to get correct. Security protocol notation was designed to make explicit which agents have access to which information. It enables formally stating threat models, including simple eavesdropping, man in the middle attacks,
binding attacks, replay attacks, masquerading attacks, reflection attacks, oracle attacks, type flaw attacks, chosen ciphertext attack, and so on. But even then, provable security- where security can be formally proven relying only on assumptions about the primitive operations used- is elusive. All this is based on classical assumptions about the adversary's capabilities. If the adversary happens to have e.g. a quantum computer it is unclear how this can be incorporated into the threat model.

In this project, we enrich security protocol notation into a graphical language that captures more structural features of the protocols and attacks in question, and combine threats to find consequences, in the sense of provable security. This graphical language is based on monoidal categories, and hence can easily be extended to a quantum setting.
goal: 1. Translate security protocol notation into a graphical language. 2. Use the new notation to derive some properties or model some situations. 3.  Extend to a quantum setting.
completion_criteria: Complete at least Task1 and as much as possible from tasks 2 and 3.

title: Developing classical mathematics in a rich type theory
description:
The Lean interactive theorem prover is a new theorem prover highly suited to the formalisation of mathematics. Key features include:

  • A significantly richer type theory than current popular theorem provers such as Isabelle/HOL, introduced in the Automated Reasoning course. A rich type theory is useful for precisely and elegantly capturing mathematical concepts, making the maths easier to read and understand.  The type theory is similar to that used by the Coq theorem prover.
  • The incorporation and collection together of a novel set of procedures for supporting the elegant input language and automating reasoning.
  • Good support for classical logic. Before Lean, most theorem provers with rich type theories required mathematics to be formulated in a constructive logic, a logic which does not provide the law of the excluded middle (For any proposition P, either P holds or its negation holds). Classical logic underpins virtually all the maths that those with good mathematical backgrounds are familiar with.

The aim of the project is to explore the prover's capabilities byundertaking a case study development of some topic in maths, perhaps from algebra, analysis or number theory, using as a starting point an existing development in Isabelle/HOL or some other interactive theorem prover. Any student interested in listing this project as one of their choices is strongly recommended to first meet with the proposer to discuss the project further and check if their background is appropriate.
goal: To formalise a development of some mathematical topic in the Lean interactive theorem prover.
completion_criteria: Production of a new mathematical development in the Lean theorem\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            +

prover. \r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +

An evaluation of the development process and of the qualities of the\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        +
development.

title: Tools for teaching Computation and Logic
description:
The Computation and Logic strand of Informatics 1 introduces students to logic and finite state machines. 

This project concerns the development of tools to support conceptual understanding of the formal manipulations that students are required to master. 

There have been several successful projects in previous years, but these have been stand-alone implementations 

The goal for this year is to 

develop tools that are integrated with the Learn environment and link directly with the Haskell content of the course.


These could draw on previous implementations such as the 
  • FSM workbench https://hepburn.codes/fsm-workbench/index.html (Hepburn 2017), or 
  • Karnaugh-mapp https://karnaugh-mapp.herokuapp.com (Mikolajczak 2018), 
or address other parts of the syllabus.
  • Development of a self-paced collection of exercises with automated marking and feedback.
  • A graphical 'blocks-world' style tool that will allow students to develop an understanding of syntax and semantics. 
  • A Haskell toolkit and exercises to help students visualise, interact with, and understand DPLL and relate algorithms.
  • Extending Matthew Hepburn's FSM tool to develop understanding of the relation between regex and FSM.
goal: To develop tools that will support teaching and learning in INF1-CL
completion_criteria: Basic completion will require the development of an interactive tool that allows users to drive the chosen formal manipulations.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              +

A good project will develop models of user-understanding, and misconceptions, and use user-testing to develop interfaces that support learning.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               +
There is plenty of scope for an excellent project to go beyond this, for example with individualised user-modelling, or by providing feedback to instructors identifying common misconceptions.
